{"code":1,"isDone":false,"toInsertArticleList":[{"createdTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","updatedTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","title":"Jerrod Blandino's millennial makeup empire is going strong with Gen Z, too. He says entrepreneurs need to remember 4 things, most of all be unique.","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/cofounder-of-too-faced-gives-career-advice-for-aspiring-entrepreneurs-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f64ef1e323fc4001e0d7273?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Too Faced\" height=\"1440\" width=\"1920\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Jerrod Blandino (L) and Jeremy Johnson (R) are the cofounders of the popular makeup brand Too Faced.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Courtesy of Too Faced”</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Jerrod Blandino and Jeremy Johnson are the cofounders of the popular makeup brand <a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/toofaced/?hl=en\">Too Faced</a>.&#160;</li>\n<li>The company, founded in 1998, has grown to become one of the best-selling makeup brands at Sephora, and it has a whopping <a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/toofaced/?hl=en\">13.2 million followers on Instagram</a>.&#160;</li>\n<li>Blandino and Johnson told Business Insider about their career beginnings and give key pieces of advice for aspiring entrepreneurs.&#160;</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>&#160;</p><p>It's nearly impossible to enter a beauty retailer today and not see <a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/toofaced/?hl=en\">Too Faced</a> products lined up on the shelves.</p><p>The brand, cofounded by Jerrod Blandino and Jeremy Johnson in 1998, is known for its millennial pink aesthetic, \"Better than Sex\" mascara, and glittering eye shallow pallets. In 2016, <a href=\"https://www.allure.com/story/estee-lauder-bought-too-faced-cosmetics\">the brand was bought by Estee Lauder </a>for a staggering $1.45 billion.</p><p>Ironically, Blandino used to work at the Estee Lauder beauty counter back in the 1990s, a time when he says \"everyone was taking makeup way too seriously.\"&#160;</p><p>\"It was very regimented, very controlled, very step one, two, three, four,\" he told Business Insider. \"I just realized very quickly, being a guy working behind the counter, that they were missing the fun, creative dream aspect of beauty.\"&#160;</p><p>He said his experience behind the counter inspired him to cofound a brand that would inspire people to \"dream and to reinvent themselves every day to express themselves.\"&#160;</p><p>\"This is all about giving you self-confidence in the world to go conquer and do anything you want to do,\" cofounder Jeremy Johnson told Business Insider.</p><p>The branding of Too Faced has allowed it to remain a millennial favorite for over two decades. It's one of the best-selling makeup brands at Sephora, and has an acclaimed mascara that, for instance, <a href=\"https://www.allure.com/review/too-faced-better-than-sex-mascara\">won the 2020 Allure reader's choice poll</a>. But the brand is proving Gen Z-friendly, too. It has <a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/toofaced/?hl=en\">13.2 million followers on Instagram</a>, and had <a href=\"https://news.yahoo.com/too-faced-lip-plumper-tik-tok-213123041.html\">a lip plumper go viral on TikTok</a> back in the spring.&#160;</p><p>\"The world's getting smaller — the internet and social media, it's brought us all so much closer together,\" Blandino said. \"These social stars, these kids on YouTube, these fabulous and amazing makeup artists, these boys and men, who are wearing makeup in their own way — it's just such a whole new, amazing world of beauty that we're just so thrilled to be a part of.\"&#160;</p><p>But of course there are some aspects of business that are universal, and Blandino shared four pieces of advice for aspiring entrepreneurs looking to create their own robust brands.&#160;</p>\n<div id=\"slideshow\">\n\tLook to create a brand that is authentic\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f64f1ac57b7da001ee12802?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Too Faced\" height=\"3582\" width=\"4776\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Dave Kotinsky / Stringer / Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>Blandino said authenticity is very important for both brands and entrepreneurs looking to create a company.</p><p>In fact, creating something authentic should be at the heart of a business, as should developing authentic relationships with customers and brand partners. The latter, he said, are an important and \"incredibly\" powerful way to get brand messages across.&#160;</p><p>\"The days of just paying somebody to you show your product, while there is no relationship with the brand, are gone. I think people see through that and it's disingenuous,\" he said. \"It is so important to align yourself with social stars and influencers who you believe really vibes and is on the same beat as your brand.\"</p>\n\tEmbrace new technology — yes, even TikTok\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5ed50a855af6cc053b7e0c53?format=jpeg\" alt=\"TikTok\" height=\"1667\" width=\"2222\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Lionel Bonaventure/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>New technology platforms seem to pop up every decade or so, but Blandino said it's important to embrace each and every one of them.</p><p>\"It's just another layer of creativity, another layer of expressing your brand and connecting with your client in a very immediate way through something that's incredibly entertaining entertainment,\" he said.</p><p>\"It's incredibly similar and totally different in many ways, but in the end, it is just about connecting with your customer, with your client and sharing your brand through a really personal way.\"&#160;</p>\n\tAim for your company to have a unique perspective and purpose\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f64f29a57b7da001ee1280b?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Too Faced\" height=\"3999\" width=\"5333\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Presley Ann / Stringer / Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>It's also important for a company to have a unique perspective, vision, and purpose, Blandino said.&#160;</p><p>\"You must come in with something new, with something personal,\" he continued. \"Otherwise, the world doesn't need another Too Faced. You know, it exists.\"</p><p>He stressed that aspiring entrepreneurs need to have perseverance, and it's important to truly believe, not only in yourself, but also in the company you are trying to create.</p><p>\"You've got to have a belief deep down that the world needs you,\" he continued. \"It can't just be, 'I want to be rich.' You need to have a passion and a purpose to bring something to the world.\"&#160;</p>\n\tBeing an entrepreneur will knock you down — but it's important to get back up\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f64ef93323fc4001e0d7277?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Too Faced\" height=\"1536\" width=\"1920\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Courtesy of Too Faced</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>Blandino is all too familiar with stress, but said that it's imperative to never give up &#8212; even if there is a a new \"struggle\" every day.&#160;</p><p>\"From having a retailer in the very early days, declare bankruptcy and take a bunch of your products and not pay you, to figuring out when you have something super-successful &#8212; how can you order enough of it and catch up to catch up to the momentum?\" he said, recounting his experiences launching Too Faced. \"That's something we still still struggle with today, but you don't give up. You find a way, you don't give up. Failure's not an option.\"&#160;</p>\n</div><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f64eee9323fc4001e0d7270?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"1608f322116a4fad2740723bb0a53458","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn69@2020_6/2020/09/20/17-35-50-070_e5415a36abaef317.webp","destWidth":1536,"destHeight":1152,"sourceBytes":76756,"destBytes":76756,"author":"ddavis@businessinsider.com (Dominic-Madori Davis)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f64ef1e323fc4001e0d7273?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn100@2020_4/2020/09/20/17-35-47-847_a1946ee7788869b5.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f64f1ac57b7da001ee12802?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn95@2020_4/2020/09/20/17-35-48-627_8bdd91c254a442af.webp","https://i.insider.com/5ed50a855af6cc053b7e0c53?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn73@2020_4/2020/09/20/17-35-35-696_ab6a62eef642accc.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f64f29a57b7da001ee1280b?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn3@2020_6/2020/09/20/17-35-45-633_c8446edf502264ae.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f64ef93323fc4001e0d7277?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn63@2020_4/2020/09/20/17-35-40-447_552138c02a7c059a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn62@2020_4/2020/09/20/17-35-46-023_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=i9jGSaMSTi0:ZqVRyUChqrc:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn75@2020_6/2020/09/20/17-35-37-110_d8f878bbb984541c.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=i9jGSaMSTi0:ZqVRyUChqrc:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn87@2020_4/2020/09/20/17-35-48-639_3787c2239e2abf95.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=i9jGSaMSTi0:ZqVRyUChqrc:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn35@2020_2/2020/09/20/17-35-40-200_e3bdd2a2b886ec28.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/i9jGSaMSTi0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn8@2020_5/2020/09/20/17-35-47-156_ad063a3c1638bf08.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1600623333132},{"createdTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","updatedTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","title":"The EU wants to give itself the power to kick US tech giants out of Europe","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/eu-new-powers-tech-giants-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f67201a323fc4001e0d7501?format=jpeg\" alt=\"FILE PHOTO: European Internal Markets Commissioner-designate Thierry Breton of France speaks during his hearing before the European Parliament in Brussels, Belgium, November 14, 2019. REUTERS/Francois Lenoir\" height=\"3227\" width=\"4303\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>EU commissioner Thierry Breton.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Reuters</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>The EU is looking to give itself sweeping new powers to crack down on US tech giants, EU commissioner Thierry Breton told the FT in an interview Sunday.</li>\n<li>The regulatory blueprint includes massive penalties to force tech companies to sell off their European operations and even shutting them out of the European single market.</li>\n<li>Breton compared the power tech giants wield now to that of the banks before the financial crisis.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>&#160;</p><p>The EU is looking to give itself sweeping new powers to crack down on US tech giants, EU commissioner Thierry Breton revealed to&#160;<a href=\"https://www.ft.com/content/7738fdd8-e0c3-4090-8cc9-7d4b53ff3afb\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">The Financial Times</a>&#160;in an interview Sunday.</p><p>Breton told the FT the new powers the EU is seeking include punitive measures such as forcing tech companies to break off and sell their European operations should their market dominance grow too large.</p><p>Another massive penalty being considered is that the EU could boot tech firms out of the European single market altogether. Breton said these measures would only be used in extreme circumstances, but did not elaborate on what would qualify as extreme.</p><p>\"There is a feeling from end-users of these platforms that they are too big to care,\" Breton told the FT, comparing tech giants' market power to the big banks before the financial crisis. \"We need better supervision for these big platforms, as we had again in the banking system,\" he said.</p><p>Alongside these powers is a proposed rating system which would give companies scores on categories including tax compliance and how quickly they take down illegal content.</p><p>The proposals have not yet been finalized, and once they're submitted, they will have to be approved by the European Parliament and the European Council. Breton said the first draft of the new laws would be ready by the end of this year.</p><p>Europe isn't the only place where Silicon Valley is facing increased regulation.</p><p>President Donald Trump is&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-rigs-fcc-to-target-facebook-twitter-2020-9\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">trying to push through an executive order</a>&#160;he&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-signs-executive-order-threatening-twitter-facebook-conservative-bias-2020-5?r=eo-landing\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">signed in May</a>, which would weaken legal protections currently afforded to internet companies under a US law called&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/what-is-section-230-internet-law-communications-decency-act-explained-2020-5\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Section 230</a>. Part of the 1996 Communications Decency Act, Section 230 protects companies from being liable for illegal content posted by users, and gives them broad powers to moderate their platforms.</p><p>Breton told the FT the EU isn't seeking to make internet companies liable for their users' content.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a 2020 13:08:01 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f672d6557b7da001ee12a64?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"e068f834232ee23bc805166b33208878","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn76@2020_6/2020/09/20/17-35-51-059_ee3b7ef5dd599818.webp","destWidth":4406,"destHeight":3304,"sourceBytes":638510,"destBytes":638510,"author":"insider@insider.com (Isobel Asher Hamilton)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f67201a323fc4001e0d7501?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn34@2020_4/2020/09/20/17-35-47-552_e1335f9361990e4d.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn62@2020_4/2020/09/20/17-35-46-023_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=l0VImTDzCz4:UT0SrIfZx8Q:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn87@2020_5/2020/09/20/17-35-38-040_c8c1bdb033e00d61.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=l0VImTDzCz4:UT0SrIfZx8Q:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn90@2020_1/2020/09/20/17-35-39-092_9d4478be8006e742.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=l0VImTDzCz4:UT0SrIfZx8Q:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn48@2020_2/2020/09/20/17-35-49-066_4b2ef470a452a708.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/l0VImTDzCz4":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn43@2020_5/2020/09/20/17-35-40-149_b92fb63360ef5ab7.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1600623333136},{"createdTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","updatedTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","title":"A federal judge has temporarily blocked the Trump administration's WeChat download ban","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/federal-judge-blocks-wechat-ban-trump-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f675b38323fc4001e0d7511?format=jpeg\" alt=\"wechat ban trump order\" height=\"512\" width=\"1024\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A federal judge in California issued a temporary injunction preventing the Commerce Department from banning downloads of WeChat.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Sheldon Cooper/SOPA Images/LightRocket via Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>A federal judge on Saturday blocked the Trump administration's attempt to institute a download ban on Chinese-owned social media app WeChat.&#160;</li>\n<li>US Magistrate Judge Laurel Beeler in California granted \"the motion on the ground that the plaintiffs have shown serious questions going to the merits of the First Amendment claim, the balance of hardships tips in the plaintiffs&#8217; favor, and the plaintiffs establish sufficiently the other elements for preliminary-injunctive relief.\"</li>\n<li>The plaintiffs in the case argued that the Trump administration's WeChat download ban violated the First and Fifth Amendments, the Religious Freedom Restoration Act and that the ban \"was not a lawful exercise of the President&#8217;s and the Secretary&#8217;s authority under the International Economic Emergency Powers Act.</li>\n<li>The US Department of Commerce had announced the download ban, which had also included TikTok, on Friday.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>A federal judge in California on Saturday <a href=\"https://www.courtlistener.com/recap/gov.uscourts.cand.364733/gov.uscourts.cand.364733.59.0.pdf\">issued a temporary injunction</a> against the Trump administration's download ban on WeChat, the Chinese-owned social media messaging app, that was slated to begin Sunday.</p><p>\"The court grants the motion on the ground that the plaintiffs have shown serious questions going to the merits of the First Amendment claim, the balance of hardships tips in the plaintiffs' favor, and the plaintiffs establish sufficiently the other elements for preliminary-injunctive relief,\" read the Saturday ruling by Laurel Beeler, the&#160;US Magistrate Judge of the United States District Court for the Northern District of California.</p><p><a href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-09-20/trump-s-wechat-prohibition-in-u-s-put-on-hold-by-judge?sref=RYMQ1oil\">Bloomberg</a> first reported the news on Sunday. The plaintiffs in the case, known as the US WeChat Users Alliance, argued that the Trump administration's WeChat download ban violated the First and Fifth Amendments, the Religious Freedom Restoration Act and that the ban \"was not a lawful exercise of the President's and the Secretary's authority under the International Economic Emergency Powers Act.\"</p><p>As Bloomberg noted, the plaintiffs in the case had argued a ban on downloads of the app would lead to violations of the free-speech rights of Chinese-speaking Americans who rely on the app to communicate domestically and with their friends and family in China.</p><p>The US Department of Commerce on Friday <a href=\"https://www.commerce.gov/news/press-releases/2020/09/commerce-department-prohibits-wechat-and-tiktok-transactions-protect\">issued an order that would have required Apple and Google to remove WeChat</a> from their respective app marketplaces, claiming that the bans were in an effort \"to safeguard the national security of the United States.\"&#160;</p><p>The Commerce Department did not immediately return Business Insider's request for comment on Sunday.</p><p>The Friday order also included popular video-based social-media app TikTok, although <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/tiktok-download-ban-officially-delayed-2020-9\">the administration on Saturday postponed that ban by one week after President Trump said he gave his \"blessing\"</a> to a deal for Walmart and Oracle to acquire a portion of TikTok from its Chinese owner ByteDance.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/federal-judge-blocks-wechat-ban-trump-2020-9'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a Perrett)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f675b38323fc4001e0d7511?format=jpeg":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn62@2020_4/2020/09/20/17-35-46-023_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=ja8byPKSGbA:9oNtyuc8Iq8:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn79@2020_6/2020/09/20/17-35-48-416_817d3b4bfb008553.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=ja8byPKSGbA:9oNtyuc8Iq8:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn34@2020_6/2020/09/20/17-35-38-125_46e3c77a37a8901f.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=ja8byPKSGbA:9oNtyuc8Iq8:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn70@2020_1/2020/09/20/17-35-37-718_9f37d33e7bdb769b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/ja8byPKSGbA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn57@2020_5/2020/09/20/17-35-43-568_7c217f99df98006f.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1600623333161},{"createdTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","updatedTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","title":"A former 'Melrose Place' actress who already served time in prison is going back to jail after a judge said her initial sentence in 2013 was too lenient","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/melrose-place-actress-faces-more-jail-time-fatal-drunk-driving-crash-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f663e2357b7da001ee12a2f?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Amy Locane Bovenizer Melrose actree\" height=\"3264\" width=\"4352\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Former &#34;Melrose Place&#34; actress Amy Locane-Bovenizer was taken into custody in Somerville, New Jersey, after jurors convicted her of vehicular homicide in 2012.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Robert Sciarrino,/Associated Press</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Amy Locane, a former actress who appeared in 13 episodes of Fox series \"Melrose Place\" and several movies, was involved in a fatal drunken-driving car crash in 2010 and was sentenced to three years in jail in 2013.</li>\n<li>After several appeals and four sentencings, state Superior Court Judge Angela Borkowski agreed with prosecutors that Locane's initial sentencing was too lenient.&#160;</li>\n<li>Borkowski sentenced Locane to eight years in state prison. The former actress will have to serve more than four years <a href=\"https://apnews.com/4a9d6b8b053f17a4809fb119ebd55771\">before she's eligible for parole.&#160;</a></li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>A former \"Melrose Place\" actress who already served a sentence of more than two years is going back to jail after a judge agreed with prosecutors that her original sentence in 2013 was too lenient, <a href=\"https://apnews.com/4a9d6b8b053f17a4809fb119ebd55771\">Associated Press reported.&#160;</a></p><p>Amy Locane, who appeared on 13 episodes of the Fox series and in several movies, was convicted on several counts, including vehicular manslaughter for her involvement in a fatal 2010 drunken driving car crash in 2013.</p><p>When Locane was convicted in 2013, she faced a sentencing range of five to 10 years. However, a trial judge sentenced her to three years. Since then, this case has had several appeals and <a href=\"https://www.cbsnews.com/news/amy-locane-melrose-place-actress-prison-deadly-2010-crash/\">four sentencings in front of three judges.</a></p><p>On September 17, state Superior Court Judge Angela Borkowski sentenced Locane to eight years in state prison. The former actress will serve more than four years <a href=\"https://apnews.com/4a9d6b8b053f17a4809fb119ebd55771\">before she's eligible for parole.&#160;</a></p><p>Locane was intoxicated when she smashed her SUV into a sedan's passenger side in Montgomery Township, New Jersey,&#160;<a href=\"https://www.cbsnews.com/news/melrose-place-actress-amy-locane-bovenizer-gets-3-years-for-deadly-new-jersey-crash/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">CBS News reported.</a>&#160;</p><p>The driver that Locane hit, Fred Seeman, was&#160;<a href=\"https://www.cbsnews.com/news/melrose-place-actress-amy-locane-bovenizer-gets-3-years-for-deadly-new-jersey-crash/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">severely injured</a>, and his wife Helene, 60, died at the scene. Locane was not indicted for drunken driving, although her blood alcohol levels were three times the limit, <a href=\"https://apnews.com/4a9d6b8b053f17a4809fb119ebd55771\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">according to Associated Press.</a></p><p>\"You made a conscious decision to drink that day and continued to drink, recognizing at the onset that you needed a ride but didn't obtain one,\" Borkowski <a href=\"https://www.cbsnews.com/news/amy-locane-melrose-place-actress-prison-deadly-2010-crash/\">said at the hearing.</a> \"If you hadn't gotten behind the wheel of your vehicle on this night, the incident never would have happened.\"</p><p>Locane has <a href=\"https://www.cbsnews.com/news/amy-locane-melrose-place-actress-prison-deadly-2010-crash/\">45 days</a> to appeal her sentence. James Wronko, her attorney, is waiting to see if the New Jersey Supreme Court would hear his appeal. He called the new sentence \"outrageous,\" and criticized Borkowski for not considering the former 48-year-old actress' sobriety.&#160;</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a 2020 08:35:45 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f663e5f323fc4001e0d74d3?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"28df3dd2d0813f96599bb70b953b9c5f","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn16@2020_1/2020/09/20/17-35-50-403_e24e98380ede8934.webp","destWidth":1442,"destHeight":1082,"sourceBytes":38424,"destBytes":38424,"author":"wcheong@businessinsider.com (Weng Cheong)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f663e2357b7da001ee12a2f?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn57@2020_2/2020/09/20/17-35-47-659_cf3e6dca5ac5f810.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn62@2020_4/2020/09/20/17-35-46-023_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=Cqu7eOXdeFk:lMalJMbowec:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn37@2020_1/2020/09/20/17-35-46-650_b150e3879145de58.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=Cqu7eOXdeFk:lMalJMbowec:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn33@2020_4/2020/09/20/17-35-35-880_5fa5004315c02bcc.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=Cqu7eOXdeFk:lMalJMbowec:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn78@2020_1/2020/09/20/17-35-39-222_1a1bb8d053f97150.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/Cqu7eOXdeFk":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn71@2020_6/2020/09/20/17-35-36-973_21480da32d03ef25.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1600623333164},{"createdTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","updatedTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","title":"POLL: 58% of American voters think the Senate should not fill Ruth Bader Ginsburg's Supreme Court vacancy until after the election","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/poll-senate-wait-2020-election-supreme-court-ruth-bader-ginsburg-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f66a45557b7da001ee12a58?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Donald Trump\" height=\"1351\" width=\"1801\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>President Donald Trump delivers his acceptance speech as the 2020 Republican presidential nominee during the final event of the Republican National Convention on the South Lawn of the White House in Washington, DC, August 27, 2020.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Carlos Barria/Reuters</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>The death of Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg opened up a vacancy on the Supreme Court that President Trump said he will fill as quickly as possible.&#160;</li>\n<li>Insider conducted a national survey with 1,017 respondents following the announcement Friday that Ginsburg had died, asking the course of action Americans preferred for filling her seat.</li>\n<li>A plurality of respondents &#8212; 45% of registered voters &#8212; said that the president elected in November should fill the seat.</li>\n<li>Another 13% said the seat should not be filled until after the election.&#160;</li>\n<li>Only 28% of registered voter respondents said Trump should fill the vacancy before the election.&#160;</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>A new survey conducted by Insider on SurveyMonkey Audience found that the Supreme Court vacancy caused by the death of Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg has escalated the stakes of the 2020 election, and that most respondents disagree with President Trump's plan to fill the seat as soon as possible.</p><p>The majority of respondents to the survey said the seat should not be filled until after the election, and a plurality said the seat should be filled by the president elected on November 3.&#160;</p><p>The poll was of 1,017 United States adults, of whom 850 said they are registered to vote and 88%, or 881 respondents, who said they are likely to do so.&#160;</p><p>Respondents were asked, <strong>\"When should the United States Senate vote to confirm a new Justice to the Supreme Court to replace Ruth Bader Ginsburg?\"</strong> Among the registered voters:</p><ul><li>45% said, \"Whoever wins the election should appoint the next Justice and the Senate should not vote until the election is decided.\"</li><li>28% said, \"As soon as possible, before the 2020 election.\"</li><li>13% said, \"After the 2020 election but before the next inauguration, regardless if President Trump wins or loses.\"</li><li>14% said, \"I don't know.\"</li></ul><p>Among <em>all</em> respondents, 27% said a replacement should be voted upon before the election, 14% said the Trump nominee should get a vote after the election, 42% said that the winner of the 2020 election should appoint the next Justice, and 17% did not know.&#160;</p><p>Undecided voters are, lo and behold, even more uncertain about the best course of action. Among voters who indicated they were registered to vote and had not yet made a decision between Joe Biden and Donald Trump, or who said they intended to vote for a third party:</p><ul><li>30% of undecideds said the winner in 2020 should appoint the Justice.</li><li>32% of undecideds said before the election.</li><li>11% of undecideds said Trump's pick should get a vote after the election.</li><li>27% of undecideds said they did not know.</li></ul><p>The opening significantly increases the stakes of the 2020 election, but it's unclear how or if it will impact the state of the race. Could this bring conservative-leaning undecided voters who don't care for Trump to reject Biden? Or does it galvanize Democrats?</p><p>Based on the survey, it appears the impact on the race will be a significant escalation with only a fraction of respondents saying they're less certain about their decision now.&#160;</p><p>After respondents had indicated who they intended to support — definitely Trump, probably Trump, not yet decided, probably Biden, definitely Biden, a third party or none of the above — respondents were asked, <strong>\"Does the death of Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg and the vacant seat on the Court affect how you plan to vote this November?\" </strong>Among registered voters:</p><ul><li>47% said it makes them more certain.</li><li>42% said it does not change their intentions.</li><li>5% said it makes them less certain.</li><li>6% said they did not know.&#160;</li></ul><p>The 40 respondents who said they're less certain in their current choice is seriously approaching the margin of error, though among those respondents, 15 indicated current support for Biden, nine now backed Trump, 11 were undecided, and 5 were going third party.</p><p>Based on this survey, there's not enough evidence to claim that one candidate or another is seriously imperiled based on the opening of the seat, rather that current backers have seen their preferences intensify.&#160;</p><section data-track-content=\"\" data-post-type=\"post\"><p><em>SurveyMonkey Audience polls from a national sample balanced by census data of age and gender. Respondents are incentivized to complete surveys through charitable contributions. Generally speaking, digital polling tends to skew toward people with access to the internet. SurveyMonkey Audience doesn't try to weight its sample based on race or income. This survey had a total 1,017 respondents, a margin of error plus or minus 3 percentage points with a 95% confidence level.</em></p></section><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on 01:35:33","updatedTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","title":"The top 10 coding languages recruiters are looking for right now — and how to learn them online for free","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/top-coding-languages-recruiters-are-looking-for-right-now-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5ee7c2893f737024027c1d77?format=jpeg\" alt=\"coding computer software engineer\" height=\"3264\" width=\"4896\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Coding bootcamp company Coding Dojo analyzed recent job postings to find which engineering languages are the most sought after.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Shutterstock</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Knowing how to code is a valuable skill in today&#8217;s job market. If you&#8217;re interested in learning how to code, consider learning one of the most in-demand languages.</li>\n<li>Coding bootcamp company Coding Dojo analyzed recent job <a href=\"https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1FmYXzUvtrlPf_xPj4vewCNq8hC_9mLTeVo3MOCwAqe0/edit#gid=0\">postings from Indeed.com</a> to find out which languages recruiters are looking for most.</li>\n<li>From Ruby to JavaScript to C/C++, here are the languages recruiters are looking for, as well as where to begin learning them.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Software engineers will continue to be in high demand for years to come. The role is set to grow by 22% over the next 10 years, much faster than average job growth, according to the <a href=\"https://www.bls.gov/ooh/computer-and-information-technology/software-developers.htm#:~:text=Software%20developers%20typically%20do%20the,the%20pieces%20will%20work%20together\">Bureau of Labor Statistics</a>. And the job pays well, the median salary is $107,510.&#160;</p><p>If you're in the market for a new job or looking to switch roles, learning to code could set you on a path for a stable career.&#160;</p><p>Coding bootcamp company Coding Dojo analyzed recent job postings from <a href=\"http://www.Indeed.com\">Indeed.com</a>. Analysts combed through thousands of new entry level jobs for \"software engineer\" or \"web developer\" and found the top 10 languages that were most commonly cited in the descriptions.&#160;</p><p>Here are the languages recruiters are looking for right now.</p><h2>10. MATLAB</h2><p><strong>Number of jobs listed in the past 30 days on Indeed.com:</strong> 204&#160;</p><p><strong>Online courses to learn the language:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qGiKv3-02vw\">YouTube</a>, <a href=\"https://web.eecs.umich.edu/~aey/eecs451/matlab.pdf\">UMichigan</a>, <a href=\"https://www.coursera.org/learn/matlab\">Coursera</a>&#160;&#160;</p><p>&#160;</p><h2>9. Ruby</h2><p><strong>Number of jobs listed in the past 30 days on Indeed.com:</strong> 245</p><p><strong>Online courses to learn the language:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.codecademy.com/learn/learn-ruby\">Codecademy</a>, <a href=\"https://www.learnrubyonline.org/\">LearnRubyOnline</a>, <a href=\"https://medium.com/@grahamwatson/a-beginners-guide-to-ruby-classes-f8dec30d5821\">Medium</a>&#160;&#160;</p><p>&#160;</p><h2>8. PHP</h2><p><strong>Number of jobs listed in the past 30 days on Indeed.com:</strong> 307&#160;&#160;</p><p><strong>Online courses to learn the language:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/learning/topics/php\">LinkedIn Learning</a>, <a href=\"https://www.codecademy.com/learn/learn-php\">Codecademy</a></p><p>&#160;</p><h2>7. Assembly</h2><p><strong>Number of jobs listed in the past 30 days on Indeed.com:</strong> 342</p><p><strong>Online courses to learn the language:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ViNnfoE56V8\">YouTube</a>, <a href=\"https://www.tutorialspoint.com/assembly_programming/index.htm\">TutorialsPoint</a></p><p>&#160;</p><h2>6. C#</h2><p><strong>Number of jobs listed in the past 30 days on Indeed.com:</strong> 629</p><p><strong>Online courses to learn the language:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.codecademy.com/learn/learn-c-sharp\">Codecademy</a>, <a href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/learning/topics/c-sharp\">LinkedIn Learning</a>, <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GhQdlIFylQ8\">YouTube</a></p><p>&#160;</p><h2>5. Go</h2><p><strong>Number of jobs listed in the past 30 days on Indeed.com:</strong> 653</p><p><strong>Online courses to learn the language:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YS4e4q9oBaU\">FreeCodeCamp.org</a>, <a href=\"http://www.golangbootcamp.com/book\">GoBootCamp</a></p><p>&#160;</p><h2>4. JavaScript</h2><p><strong>Number of jobs listed in the past 30 days on Indeed.com:</strong> 1040</p><p><strong>Online courses to learn the language:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.khanacademy.org/computing/computer-programming/programming#concept-intro\">Khan Academy</a>, <a href=\"https://www.udacity.com/course/intro-to-javascript--ud803\">Udacity</a>, <a href=\"https://www.edx.org/course/javascript-introduction\">EdX</a>&#160;</p><p>&#160;</p><h2>3. Java</h2><p><strong>Number of jobs listed in the past 30 days on Indeed.com:</strong> 1215</p><p><strong>Online courses to learn the language:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GoXwIVyNvX0\">FreeCodeCamp.org</a>, <a href=\"https://www.udacity.com/course/java-programming-basics--ud282\">Udacity</a>, <a href=\"https://www.codecademy.com/learn/learn-java\">Codecademy</a></p><p>&#160;</p><h2>2. Python</h2><p><strong>Number of jobs listed in the past 30 days on Indeed.com:</strong> 1222&#160;&#160;</p><p><strong>Online courses to learn the language:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.codecademy.com/learn/learn-python\">Codecademy</a>, <a href=\"https://www.coursera.org/specializations/python\">Coursera</a>, <a href=\"https://www.udacity.com/course/introduction-to-python--ud1110\">Udacity</a>&#160;&#160;</p><p>&#160;</p><h2>1. C/C++</h2><p><strong>Number of jobs listed in the past 30 days on Indeed.com:</strong> 1370&#160;&#160;</p><p><strong>Online courses to learn the language:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KJgsSFOSQv0\">FreeCodecamp.org</a>, <a href=\"https://www.learn-c.org/\">Learn-C.org</a>, <a href=\"https://www.udemy.com/course/free-learn-c-tutorial-beginners/\">Udemy</a>, <a href=\"https://www.codecademy.com/learn/learn-c-plus-plus\">Codecademy</a>&#160;&#160;</p><div height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sun, 20 Sep 2020 15:00:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f5ac45d7ed0ee001e25eb26?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"2a51185b5985841366b12f8de4e18921","destWidth":4348,"destHeight":3261,"sourceBytes":402262,"destBytes":402262,"author":"insider@insider.com (Marguerite Ward)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5ee7c2893f737024027c1d77?format=jpeg":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn62@2020_4/2020/09/20/17-35-46-023_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=zYGmdy6q1gg:IfFKpZJ9q7c:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn22@2020_1/2020/09/20/17-35-40-880_978e33db6bf36c7f.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=zYGmdy6q1gg:IfFKpZJ9q7c:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn57@2020_2/2020/09/20/17-35-35-865_b1b3db3018064589.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=zYGmdy6q1gg:IfFKpZJ9q7c:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn4@2020_2/2020/09/20/17-35-37-087_fbb130fbfb162ed9.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/zYGmdy6q1gg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn74@2020_5/2020/09/20/17-35-40-473_3440723abe0a342b.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1600623333164},{"createdTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","updatedTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","title":"Millennials are flocking to Colorado because they see it as a quarantine haven — here's what they're saying about life in the Centennial state","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/millennials-flocking-to-colorado-pandemic-wears-on-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f63d31c323fc4001e0d701a?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Colorado\" height=\"1331\" width=\"1774\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Blaine Harrington III/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Colorado is emerging as a top <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/colorado-quarantine-location-rich-americans-millennials-urban-exodus-agents-2020-08\">destination</a> for millennials who are looking to relocate during the pandemic.</li>\n<li>Business Insider spoke to eight 20- and 30-somethings who have moved to Colorado since April to find out why they made the leap.</li>\n<li>They said they all fell for Colorado's charm for the same reasons: job opportunities, good weather, accessibility, and plenty of outdoor activities.</li>\n<li>Below are three of their stories.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><h2>The outdoors as mental healing</h2><p><strong>Name</strong>: Jessica Occean, 30</p><p><strong>Moved from</strong>: New York, New York</p><p><strong>Moved to</strong>: Denver, Colorado</p><p>Jessica Occean is a born and bred New Yorker. But, as she told Business Insider, she recently turned 30 and found that her city needs and wants had changed.&#160;</p><p>\"I wanted things that NYC just couldn't offer, even on a $90,000 salary for a single, fiscally responsible person,\" she said. \"I wanted a good quality of life, space in my home, a less crowded existence especially in my commute and general day-to-day, and access to the outdoors for some mental healing.\"&#160;</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f63cbe4323fc4001e0d6ff1?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Denver Colorado skyline\" height=\"1668\" width=\"2223\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Denver, Colorado.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Brad McGinley Photography / Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>When the pandemic struck, she lost her job as a sales account executive in tech and was paying $2,000 a month for a fourth-floor walk-up apartment with roach problems. \"There was nothing to stay in NYC for,\" she said.</p><p>But even as NYC no longer felt like the answer, she wasn't prepared to give up her career in the tech industry or city life altogether. Enter: Denver.&#160;</p><p>Occean said the mountain city \"ticked so many boxes I needed in this stage of my life.\" Despite never having visited, the practicality of the decision and the fact that her sister had just moved there was enough to prompt her to take the leap in June. Now, she's living in a North Capitol Hill apartment where she's paying nearly $600 less a month and living in 300 more square feet than her former NYC apartment.</p><h2>A practical place to weather the pandemic</h2><p><strong>Name</strong>: Naka Canlas Potts, 27</p><p><strong>Moved from</strong>: Denton, Texas</p><p><strong>Moved to</strong>: Fort Collins, Colorado</p><p>Nika Canlas Potts, 27, moved to Fort Collins with her spouse in August because of the pandemic. Before the move, the couple had been living in Denton, Texas, for 10 years. Potts told Business Insider she doesn't think the pandemic is anywhere near over.</p><p>\"It came down to the idea of, 'Where do we want to spend the next year of the pandemic,'\" she said, adding that the hobbies that had kept them sane during the beginning of the pandemic — walks, hikes, and camping — became impossible as Texas grew hot and humid. Moving to a foothills city in Colorado, she said, gave them the opportunity to be outside and partake in safe, socially distant activities.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f63cc74323fc4001e0d6ff5?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Fort Collins Colorado\" height=\"1668\" width=\"2223\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Footbridge over Cache la Poudre River at whitewater park in downtown Fort Collins, Colorado, with Powerhouse Energy Campus of Colorado State University in background.\n<p class=\"copyright\">marekuliasz / Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Potts said she found leaving Denton easy because many places had shut down to never reopen, and they were working remotely for the foreseeable future. Even though they've only been in Fort Collins for a week, she said they're already loving it because it allows for more physical activity, has public transportation, and has better weather.&#160;</p><p>Colorado doesn't offer Potts a more affordable lifestyle, but she thinks they're getting their money's worth. Even though they're paying $600 more a month in rent for a house similar to the one they had in Texas, they don't have to drive as much, run the air conditioning as frequently, or pay for a gym membership, which cuts down on other costs.</p><p>\"We definitely will need to be more thrifty here, but so far, it has felt worth it,\" she said.</p><h2>The promise of a better lifestyle</h2><p><strong>Name</strong>: Alissa Johnson, 23</p><p><strong>Moved from</strong>: Minneapolis, Minnesota</p><p><strong>Moved to</strong>: Aurora, Colorado</p><p>A better lifestyle is what drew 23-year-old Alissa Johnson to Aurora, Colorado, in May. She and her boyfriend had been living in a rocky part of northern Minneapolis, Minnesota. They visited a few friends in Colorado and \"fell in love,\" she said, describing the state as a mix between Washington and Minnesota.</p><p>Back in Minneapolis, Johnson found herself in some frightening situations as a bystander in both a robbery at a dollar store and police search that she said involved 25 cop cars and a helicopter. \"I had this gut feeling of, 'You need to leave,'\" she said.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f63cfdd323fc4001e0d7006?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Aurora Colorado shopping mall\" height=\"1664\" width=\"2218\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Pedestrians walk by a fire pit and the clock tower along South Main Street at Southlands Mall in Aurora, Colorado.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Anya Semenoff / Contributor</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>She found a place for herself and her boyfriend in about two days, she said. They're paying about $100 more a month in rent, but thinks it's worth the swimming pool and gym in the building.</p><p>She said she's thankful she listened to her gut. \"If we would have stayed, we would have been directly in the area of the riots and protests in Minneapolis,\" she said. \"We had gone back to visit family, and the gas station that I had gone to every morning was burnt down and people were flooding the streets at night.\"</p><p>Colorado, she said, has been good for her because she's a \"big outdoorsy person\" who likes a view and clean water — two things she said Minneapolis lacked.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/millennials-flocking-to-colorado-pandemic-wears-on-2020-9'>Business Insider</a></div><div 01:35:33","updatedTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","title":"Mohamed El-Erian warns that stocks could tank if the Fed's liquidity 'engine' stops running, cites disconnect between prices and fundamentals","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/stock-market-outlook-federal-reserve-liquidity-risk-mohamed-el-erian-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f64ec77323fc4001e0d725c?format=jpeg\" alt=\"mohammed el erian.JPG\" height=\"1654\" width=\"3309\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.reutersconnect.com/all?id=tag%3Areuters.com%2C2017%3Anewsml_RC1C3F2E0570%3A2101241852&#38;search=all%3Amohammed%20el-erian\" target=\"_blank\">Reuters/Lucy Nicholson</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul><li><strong>Economist Mohamed El-Erian says markets may falter as the Fed's liquidity \"engine\" becomes less and less powerful, and as investors begin to challenge elevated valuations.&#160;</strong></li><li><strong>\"If that engine disappears, we have a long way between where asset prices are right now and where fundamentals will validate them,\" he told Bloomberg TV.&#160;</strong></li><li><strong>In a separate op-ed for Bloomberg, El-Erian said economic and corporate fundamentals must improve for valuations to be sustained. </strong></li><li><strong style=\"color: #222222;\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/international?r=US&IR=T?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingest?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingest?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingest?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingestmp;utm_medium=ingest\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</strong></li></ul><hr><p>Renowned economist Mohamed El-Erian says the stock market faces downside risk as the Fed's liquidity \"engine\" becomes less and less powerful. He also sees the possibility of a dip if more investors start to question whether sky-high valuations can be validated by fundamentals.</p><p>\"Where we go from here is going to continue to be liquidity driven, if that engine disappears, we have a long way between where asset prices are right now and where fundamentals will validate them,\" he said <a href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/videos/2020-09-18/el-erian-investors-less-comfortable-with-effectiveness-of-fed-video\">in an interview with Bloomberg TV on Friday</a>.</p><p>El-Erian detailed how, since Wednesday's FOMC meeting, there have been signs that investors are \"less comfortable about the effectiveness of Fed liquidity,\" and as a result of that, \"more willing to challenge pretty elevated valuations.\"&#160;</p><p><em><strong>Read more:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/stock-market-crash-expert-shares-6-investing-risks-peter-cecchini-2020-9\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">An ex-Wall Street chief strategist says the market's comeback has made most investors 'blissfully unaware' of its real risks — and lays out 6 reasons why another free-fall is on the cards</a></em></p><p>In a separate <a href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/opinion/articles/2020-09-17/are-stocks-losing-some-of-their-liquidity-momentum\">Bloomberg op-ed published before the interview</a>, El-Erian warned that the Fed has injected liquidity into markets not only through policies, but by sparking a fear-of-missing-out mindset for investors.&#160;</p><p>\"The Fed's repeated support for financial markets has engendered a deep 'buy-the-dip' investor conditioning and a prominent FOMO mindset,\" he wrote.</p><p>Now that the Fed isn't meeting for the next two months, El-Erian expects \"more skeptical investors may now feel more comfortable to challenge valuations.\"</p><p><em><strong>Read more:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/stock-picks-to-buy-beat-market-growth-potential-faangs-goldman-2020-9\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">GOLDMAN SACHS: Buy these 21 stocks on track for years of market-beating growth that could make them future giants — even rivals to the FAANGs</a></em></p><p>For these valuations to be sustained, more economic improvement and stronger corporate fundamentals are necessary, wrote El-Erian.</p><p>Citing Thursday's mildly improving jobless claims, he said: \"The economic recovery continues but at a space that is too slow relative both to what's possible and what's needed.\"</p><p>\"Unless Congress steps up to the responsibility of taking timely action to support both the demand and supply side of the economy...the risk increases of a missed market hand-off from previously strong but fading liquidity to what's urgently needed also for economic and social well-being: A strong lasting and inclusive recovery,\" El-Erian wrote.&#160;</p><p><em><strong>Read more:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/stock-market-crash-risks-60-40-portfolio-record-low-leuthold-2020-9\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">A 'disturbing new all-time low' in the market just flew under the radar as stocks hit record highs — and one Wall Street expert warns it implies years of bleak returns for young investors</a><br></em></p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a 2020 11:52:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f64ec83323fc4001e0d725d?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"e5834abeff6cf28c6a1357f8a0483e40","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn39@2020_1/2020/09/20/17-35-50-730_6f9d3786e8539bea.webp","destWidth":2938,"destHeight":2204,"sourceBytes":168226,"destBytes":168226,"author":"egraffeo@businessinsider.com (Emily Graffeo)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f64ec77323fc4001e0d725c?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn34@2020_2/2020/09/20/17-35-45-916_e9f76b213fe75156.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn62@2020_4/2020/09/20/17-35-46-023_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=HClLcPhsxbU:1HoLL958KXA:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn45@2020_6/2020/09/20/17-35-42-025_ee15cbdf978d62fb.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=HClLcPhsxbU:1HoLL958KXA:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn12@2020_2/2020/09/20/17-35-42-565_60933ad01b02bc21.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=HClLcPhsxbU:1HoLL958KXA:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn74@2020_2/2020/09/20/17-35-39-096_93d8d68ac5606dc2.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/HClLcPhsxbU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn40@2020_4/2020/09/20/17-35-48-840_a9c18bab8445a552.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1600623333150},{"createdTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","updatedTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","title":"A group of retail industry insiders is taking a cue from Alibaba and creating a new shopping day to jumpstart the holiday season","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/deals-discounts-october-10-save-holiday-shopping-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f64d933323fc4001e0d71d7?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Alibaba Singles&#39; Day\" height=\"3335\" width=\"4447\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A journalist takes a picture of a screen showing real-time data of transactions at Alibaba Group&#39;s 11.11 global shopping festival in Beijing, China.\n<p class=\"copyright\">REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>A group led by Coresight Research and rewards app Shopkick is hoping to save the holiday shopping season with a new festival called \"10.10,\" taking place on October 10.&#160;</li>\n<li>10.10 takes a cue from Alibaba's massive Singles' Day shopping festival in China held on November 11, which generated about $38.3 billion in sales last year.&#160;</li>\n<li>By offering discounts on October 10, the group is hoping to elongate the holiday season and mitigate potential issues with shipping and fulfillment.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>A group of retail insiders are banding together in an effort to save the holiday shopping season — as the industry weathers a year unlike any before.</p><p>To do so, stakeholders are looking to create a brand-new shopping festival called \"10.10,\" taking place online on October 10.</p><p>The occasion is a nod to China's massive Singles' Day shopping event, which happens on November 11 (11/11) each year. In 2019, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/alibaba-singles-day-beats-amazons-estimated-prime-day-sales-2019-11\">Singles' Day generated about $38.3 billion in sales</a>, according to Alibaba, which hosts the 24-hour shopping extravaganza.&#160;</p><p>With 10.10, American retailers can look to \"create excitement\" and \"bring back the magic and the fun of shopping,\" according to Coresight Research's founder and CEO, Deborah Weinswig, who conceptualized the festival along with&#160; rewards app Shopkick.&#160;</p><p>As part of the festival, the group is encouraging retailers to run special promotions on October 10. There's also a charitable element, as customers shopping with participating retailers will be given the option to donate their earned rewards to a charity of their choice. Shopkick will create a website for the festival. The retailers participating in the event have not been disclosed.</p><p>The timing of 10.10 is no coincidence. As the holiday shopping season draws closer, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/holiday-shopping-could-bring-issues-for-retailers-execs-2020-8\">retailers are beginning to warn</a> that their systems could become overloaded and customers could face order delays close to the holidays. Shipping volumes <a href=\"https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-retail-shipping/fearing-shipping-crunch-retailers-set-earliest-ever-holiday-sale-plans-idUSKBN25H158\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"60\" data-uri=\"d5def91ff01fbce141d67c890dd74f91\">have been unusually high</a> as consumers opt to shop online and stay largely at home amid the ongoing coronavirus pandemic. If more people are shopping around the same time due to the holidays, the problem could get worse.&#160;</p><p>By hosting a festival at the beginning of October, Weinswig said, the group hopes to \"pull the shopping season forward\" so that demand can be spread out for a longer period of time.</p><p>The festival is a form of \"thinking about how to elongate the season, how to make sure that that product is delivered when the consumer wants to give it and to get it,\" Weinswig said.&#160;&#160;</p><p>Other <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/holiday-deals-target-kohls-nordstrom-begin-before-thanksgiving-2020-8\">retailers including Kohl's, Target, and Nordstrom</a> have said they'd begin holiday deals in October or November in order to allow for safe environments in stores and to avoid potential shipping bottlenecks. A number of major retailers are also opting to <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/retailers-closing-their-doors-on-thanksgiving-full-list-2020-7\">keep their stores closed on Thanksgiving</a>.&#160;</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/deals-discounts-october-10-save-holiday-shopping-2020-9'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=-NvZWn0Ebzw:B1iSsqKkQ4A:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img Stone)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f64d933323fc4001e0d71d7?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn90@2020_3/2020/09/20/17-35-33-630_d0437fd299391667.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn62@2020_4/2020/09/20/17-35-46-023_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=-NvZWn0Ebzw:B1iSsqKkQ4A:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn87@2020_4/2020/09/20/17-35-36-564_7896f38bae8e0d99.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=-NvZWn0Ebzw:B1iSsqKkQ4A:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn33@2020_3/2020/09/20/17-35-38-860_f426627d9fb69b3f.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=-NvZWn0Ebzw:B1iSsqKkQ4A:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn33@2020_6/2020/09/20/17-35-36-789_4a2acad00bae1768.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/-NvZWn0Ebzw":null},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1600623333132},{"createdTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","updatedTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","title":"Trump supporters staged a rally at a Virginia polling center during early voting, intimidating voters, election officials say","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/virginia-trump-supporters-intimidated-voters-disrupt-early-voting-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f6730cc57b7da001ee12a65?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Trump 2020\" height=\"1000\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>(File image) A supporter of President Trump waves flags outside of McKenzie Arena, where U.S. President Donald Trump is holding a rally in support of Republican Senate candidate Rep. Marsha Blackburn, November 4, 2018 in Chattanooga, Tennessee.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Drew Angerer/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Trump supporters waving flags and chanting slogans staged a rally near a polling center in Fairfax, Virginia, Saturday on the second day of early voting in the state, filmed footage shows.</li>\n<li>\"Some voters, and elections staff, did feel intimidated by the crowd and we did provide escorts past the group,\" said Gary Scott, the general registrar of Fairfax County.</li>\n<li>But a local Republican official, Steve Rastatter, denied that protesters had been seeking to intimidate voters and said they had complied with officials' requests to move away.&#160;</li>\n<li>President Trump has spread groundless accusations that Democrats are seeking to steal the election, and has called on supporters to act as poll monitors.&#160;</li>\n<li>Attempts at voter intimidation are illegal in Virginia and other US states.&#160;</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Supporters of President Donald Trump staged a rally during early voting at a polling station in Virginia on Saturday, in a stunt that an election official said had intimidated voters and disrupted voting.&#160;</p><p>According to footage of the incident posted online by filmmaker Anthony Tilghman, a group of supporters holding up pro-Trump banners staged the protest near the polling station entrance in Fairfax, on the second day of early voting in the state.&#160;</p><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" data-cards=\"\" data-conversation=\"\">&#8212;Anthony Tilghman  (@AnthonyTilghman) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/mims/statuses/1307360544559706113?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">September 19, 2020</a></blockquote><script async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script><p>&#160;</p><p>A county election official, Gary Scott, said that the protest was about 100 feet from the building entrance where voters cast their ballot early.</p><p>Contrary to some initial reports, the protesters had not blocked access to the polling station, he said.</p><p>\"Citizens coming into and leaving the building did have to go by them,\" Gary Scott, the general registrar of Fairfax County, said in a statement to <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/09/19/us/politics/trump-supporters-early-voting-virginia.html\">The New York Times.</a> \"Those voters who were in line outside of the building were moved inside and we continued operations. Some voters, and elections staff, did feel intimidated by the crowd and we did provide escorts past the group. One of the escorts was the county executive.\"</p><p>Fairfax County Democrats Chair Bryan Graham accused local Republicans of seeking to intimidate voters.</p><p>\"The Republicans are straight-up attempting to intimidate voters at the Government Center. Circling the parking lots with their Trump flags and horns blaring,\" he tweeted.&#160;</p><p>But Fairfax County Republican Committee Vice-Chair Sean Rastatter, who was at the protest, told the Times that they not been seeking to intimidate voters.&#160;</p><p>He said that he didn't think \"there was any way to need or feel intimidated in any form\" and that protesters had complied with a request from election officials to \"back away from the curb\" and voters waiting to cast their ballot.&#160;</p><p>The incident reflects the febrile climate around this year's election, with Trump having repeatedly spread disinformation that mail-in votes are exposed to fraud, and Democrats are plotting to steal the election.</p><p>The president at rallies has called on supporters to act as<a href=\"https://twitter.com/atrupar/status/1304988587532922880?s=20\">\"poll watchers\" to guard</a> against election fraud. Democrats say that the president seeks to delegitimize thousands of mail-in votes to cling to power illegally should he lose in November.</p><p>Thousands more Americans are expected to cast their ballot by mail this year amid the coronavirus pandemic, with polls showing Democratic nominee Joe Biden holding the lead over Trump.&#160;</p><p>Already some observers say that the escalating tensions could spill over into election day violence.</p><p>Russ Travers, who served as acting director of the National Counter-Terrorism Centre until March, <a href=\"https://www.abc.net.au/news/2020-09-04/former-us-counter-terrorism-head-warns-violence-around-election/12628490\">told ABC News</a> last week: \"I fear there are a lot of people out there with very warped views of reality and a lot of guns who could willingly take up their weapons in defense of what they believe is the President and the constitution.</p><p>\"That, I think, is a worrisome possibility that is growing as the political rhetoric gets more and more severe.\"</p><p>In a statement Saturday, Fairfax County Commonwealth's Attorney Steve Descano <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/FairfaxCountyCA/posts/197420411812487\">said that those </a>seeking to&#160;intimidate voters would be prosecuted.&#160;</p><p>\"I am instructing my office to pursue cases of voter intimidation that may occur,\" Descano tweeted.&#160;</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f67351a57b7da001ee12a67?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"2c4f71643093039d5766677ffe5a416f","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn78@2020_4/2020/09/20/17-35-49-971_c4a135d98a7d157f.webp","destWidth":1777,"destHeight":1333,"sourceBytes":85602,"destBytes":85602,"author":"tporter@businessinsider.com (Tom Porter)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f6730cc57b7da001ee12a65?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn18@2020_3/2020/09/20/17-35-43-548_1c64d2a0a901cc3c.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn62@2020_4/2020/09/20/17-35-46-023_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=uIj5O-JJUuY:Cp1v-jLP9iM:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn5@2020_2/2020/09/20/17-35-46-640_4bbb19faeaf37cff.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=uIj5O-JJUuY:Cp1v-jLP9iM:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn97@2020_6/2020/09/20/17-35-38-509_f50a9216eaf0b053.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=uIj5O-JJUuY:Cp1v-jLP9iM:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn24@2020_3/2020/09/20/17-35-38-819_9090b31dab569485.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/uIj5O-JJUuY":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn9@2020_3/2020/09/20/17-35-44-174_ecf4c32a2c5e1829.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1600623333156},{"createdTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","updatedTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","title":"One stock market signal suggests the US presidential race is tightening, Goldman Sachs says","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/stock-market-signal-us-presidential-election-race-goldman-sachs-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f43ea0389aff80028ab7823?format=jpeg\" alt=\"biden trump\" height=\"386\" width=\"773\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Doug Mills-Pool/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul><li><strong>The trading activity of certain stocks is sending a signal to investors that the upcoming Presidential election this November is going to be close — and is getting closer, Goldman Sachs said on Friday.</strong></li><li><strong>The relative outperformance of high-tax stocks relative to their low-tax counterparts signals a recent preference for stocks expected to benefit from a Republican victory.</strong></li><li><strong>It specifically suggests a 53% probability of corporate tax reform, according to Goldman. The firm says this is only likely happen if Democrats pull off a sweep in November.</strong></li><li><strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingest?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingestutm_source=msn.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_content=msn-slideshow&utm_campaign=bodyurl?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingest?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingest?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingestce=markets&#38;utm_medium=ingest\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Visit the Business Insider homepage for more stories</a>.</strong></li></ul><hr><p>Judging by the trading activity of certain stocks, the presidential election in November is getting tighter — although it still favors a Democratic sweep, Goldman Sachs said in a note on Friday.</p><p>Specifically, the recent outperformance of a basket of stocks with high corporate tax rates relative to its low-tax counterpart signals a recent preference for companies expected to benefit from a Republican victory. Further, the direct probability of Joe Biden's proposed tax hike has declined in recent weeks, although it remains the more likely outcome, Goldman data show.</p><p>Both dynamics are reflected in the charts below:</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f64fc7f57b7da001ee12851?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Goldman election onte.JPG\" height=\"694\" width=\"1595\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Goldman Sachs</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Specifically, the high-tax basket's outsized returns currently imply a 53% probability of corporate tax reform, the note said.&#160;Reversing President Donald Trump's signature 2017 tax legislation is a Biden policy initiative that could likely only be pulled off if Democrats controlled both Congress and the White House.</p><p>The 53% probability of corporate tax reform is in line with prediction market's 54% probability of a Democratic sweep this November, Goldman highlighted.&#160;</p><p><em><strong>Read more:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/stock-picks-to-buy-beat-market-growth-potential-faangs-goldman-2020-9\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">GOLDMAN SACHS: Buy these 21 stocks on track for years of market-beating growth that could make them future giants — even rivals to the FAANGs</a><br></em></p><p>Despite the declining implied probability of a Democratic victory, there are still signs that investors are preparing for a full sweep.</p><p>\"Education and clean energy stocks have moved in directions consistent with a rising probability of Democratic sweep,\" Goldman said.</p><p>Clean energy stocks have outperformed the S&#38;P 500 by 55 percentage points year-to-date, while for-profit education stocks have lagged the broader market in recent months.&#160;</p><p>If Democrats do pull off a sweep in November, Goldman says to expect a period of heightened market volatility as investors grapple assessing the impact of Biden policy initiatives amid a global pandemic and sharp economic decline.&#160;</p><p><em><strong>Read more:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/stock-market-crash-expert-shares-6-investing-risks-peter-cecchini-2020-9\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">An ex-Wall Street chief strategist says the market's comeback has made most investors 'blissfully unaware' of its real risks — and lays out 6 reasons why another free-fall is on the cards</a></em></p><p>While corporate and tax hikes from the Biden administration would reduce 2021 S&#38;P 500 earnings by 9% and likely hurt stocks, large fiscal expansion initiatives and less uncertainty with trade policy could be a tailwind for stocks, Goldman said.</p><p>Biden's plan includes $7 trillion in gross fiscal spending on infrastructure, education, clean energy, and healthcare, Goldman noted.</p><p>Finally, investors should brace for a period of extended and heightened volatility based on current implied moves in option pricing \"as investors assess the potential for it to take longer than usual to reach definitive election results,\" the note said.</p><p>\"The market now shows an extended period of high volatility well beyond Election Day. This likely reflects the potential for election results to be finalized with a delay,\" Goldman said.&#160;</p><p><em><strong>Read more:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/options-trading-strategy-market-wizards-schwager-tony-saliba-shares-advice-2020-9\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Legendary options trader Tony Saliba famously put together 70 straight months of profits greater than $100,000. Here's an inside look at the strategy that propelled him to millionaire status before age 25.</a></em></p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/5-GCKxMM2os\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sun, 20 Sep +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f64f29557b7da001ee1280a?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"95fb0d6f0e05d0a3cedfd500c8138943","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn60@2020_2/2020/09/20/17-35-50-893_43a391a06378959e.webp","destWidth":570,"destHeight":428,"sourceBytes":17756,"destBytes":17756,"author":"mfox@businessinsider.com
