Fox)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f43ea0389aff80028ab7823?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn8@2020_3/2020/09/20/17-35-48-797_409ff660391b7655.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f64fc7f57b7da001ee12851?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn31@2020_3/2020/09/20/17-35-41-603_b496b96372307c17.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn62@2020_4/2020/09/20/17-35-46-023_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=5-GCKxMM2os:hipO8EK9HNI:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn84@2020_1/2020/09/20/17-35-42-202_16fddc1b4a7ad922.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=5-GCKxMM2os:hipO8EK9HNI:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn89@2020_1/2020/09/20/17-35-43-982_c6be62effc3eaf72.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=5-GCKxMM2os:hipO8EK9HNI:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn39@2020_4/2020/09/20/17-35-45-265_4e1085dad619925e.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/5-GCKxMM2os":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn10@2020_6/2020/09/20/17-35-37-980_be92b4a482c2c25d.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1600623333150},{"createdTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","updatedTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","title":"This sleek futuristic off-grid smart home can cost up to $413,00 and only takes 90 minutes to install — take a look inside 'Space'","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/iohouse-space-smart-home-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f62748b57b7da001ee1210f?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IOHOUSE 27\" height=\"1262\" width=\"1682\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>iOHouse.\n<p class=\"copyright\">iOHouse</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>iOhouse designed Space, a totally off-grid tiny home.&#160;</li>\n<li>With all the highest end customizations, the home costs about $413,000 and can be installed in just 90 minutes.</li>\n<li>As a smart home, every feature is controlled through the owner's phone.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Swedish company iOhouse created a luxury, futuristic smart home with <a href=\"https://iohouse.se/#about\">Space.</a> The contemporary design comes completely move-in ready, with everything from furniture to sheets and wine glasses already set up. The house is transported by trailer anywhere in the EU, dropped in place by a crane, and residents can move in within 90 minutes.</p><p>The coronavirus pandemic, along with greater potential for remote work than ever, have driven many out of cities in search of privacy and more affordable living. iOhouse claims that Space can offer the best of both worlds for this type of customer, with all the luxuries of a modern urban home preinstalled, plus a high-end smart home that can be completely controlled through an app.</p><p>Smart homes are becoming more ubiquitous, although not usually in the fully connected way that Space is. They are common in the forms of Alexa, Amazon's virtual assistant, or LED connected bulbs that can be controlled from a smartphone.</p><p>A <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/iot-smart-home-automation\">January 2020</a> Insider Intelligence report predicted there will be 64 billion smart home devices by 2020, and <a href=\"https://time.com/5634791/smart-homes-future/\">ABI research</a> predicted $123 billion in Internet of Things spending by 2021. Smart devices remain more expensive than their non-smart counterparts, but the industry is growing regardless.</p><p>Take a look at Space.&#160;</p>\n<div id=\"slideshow\">\n\tiOhouse describes Space as an \"off the grid, modern-concept living space.\"\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f637502323fc4001e0d6d1d?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IOHOUSE 3\" height=\"1333\" width=\"1778\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>iOHouse.\n<p class=\"copyright\">iOHouse</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tThe company says that Space was designed as a second home or summer cottage. Water and sewage systems are set up for two people to live independently for two weeks under typical conditions.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f62673957b7da001ee120d6?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IOHOUSE 7\" height=\"1333\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>iOHouse.\n<p class=\"copyright\">iOHouse</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tThe home straddles the border of a tiny home, compared to just a small home, at about 645 square feet. It weighs 19 tons.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f62672e323fc4001e0d6af0?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IOHOUSE 10\" height=\"1333\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>iOHouse.\n<p class=\"copyright\">iOHouse</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tIt could also function as an office or professional studio.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f6385e857b7da001ee123a8?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IOHOUSE 31\" height=\"1333\" width=\"1778\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>iOHouse.\n<p class=\"copyright\">iOHouse</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tIt is powered by solar panels and a generator, with built in heating, cooling, water, sewage, and ventilation.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f63855d57b7da001ee123a2?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IOHOUSE 24\" height=\"1333\" width=\"1778\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>iOHouse.\n<p class=\"copyright\">iOHouse</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tAll of these built-in features mean that installation takes only 90 minutes, with no outside utility hookups.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f62748b57b7da001ee1210f?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IOHOUSE 27\" height=\"1262\" width=\"1682\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>iOHouse.\n<p class=\"copyright\">iOHouse</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tThe house can be pleased in nearly any location, chosen for natural beauty, even if it wouldn't be convenient for utilities in other cases.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f63866057b7da001ee123ab?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IOHOUSE 25\" height=\"1081\" width=\"1441\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>iOHouse.\n<p class=\"copyright\">iOHouse</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\t\"It can be dropped in a private location that would be inaccessible for a typical house.\"\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f64e6bb57b7da001ee127d6?format=jpeg\" alt=\"iOhouse delivery\" height=\"848\" width=\"1130\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>iOhouse.\n<p class=\"copyright\">iOhouse</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tThe house fits on the back of a truck for easy delivery.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f638c7b57b7da001ee123d3?format=jpeg\" alt=\"iOhouse delivery\" height=\"822\" width=\"1097\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>iOhouse.\n<p class=\"copyright\">iOhouse</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tThe house can be purchased completely furnished and move-in ready.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f638c9d323fc4001e0d6dfb?format=jpeg\" alt=\"iOhouse delivery\" height=\"850\" width=\"1133\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>iOhouse.\n<p class=\"copyright\">iOhouse</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tA crane drops the house into place, and it's good to go.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f638bbc323fc4001e0d6df4?format=jpeg\" alt=\"iOhouse delivery\" height=\"852\" width=\"1136\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>iOhouse.\n<p class=\"copyright\">iOhouse</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tInside, the house has a bedroom, living room, kitchen, and bathroom, plus two fold-out terraces.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f638f02323fc4001e0d6e21?format=jpeg\" alt=\"iOhouse\" height=\"1173\" width=\"1565\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>iOhouse.\n<p class=\"copyright\">iohouse</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tThe interior is decorated in neutrals, with glass, wool, metal, and wood.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f638f4057b7da001ee12407?format=jpeg\" alt=\"iOhouse\" height=\"1080\" width=\"1440\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>iOhouse.\n<p class=\"copyright\">iohouse</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tWith all the highest upgrades and furniture, the home costs about $413,000.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f638fb257b7da001ee1240c?format=jpeg\" alt=\"iOhouse\" height=\"1080\" width=\"1440\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>iOhouse.\n<p class=\"copyright\">iohouse</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tThis includes all appliances, like a dishwasher, gas stove, refrigerator, and even a washing machine.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f638ff0323fc4001e0d6e31?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IOHOUSE 18\" height=\"1332\" width=\"1776\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>iOHouse.\n<p class=\"copyright\">iOHouse</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tAs a smart home, all aspects of the house can be controlled from a phone.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f63901e323fc4001e0d6e34?format=jpeg\" alt=\"iOhouse\" height=\"1080\" width=\"1440\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>iOhouse.\n<p class=\"copyright\">iohouse</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tFrom a smartphone, control security cameras, a weather station, the stereo system, and more.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f63905d323fc4001e0d6e35?format=jpeg\" alt=\"iOhouse\" height=\"1080\" width=\"1440\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>iOhouse.\n<p class=\"copyright\">iohouse</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tSmart air ventilation even automatically corrects oxygen levels inside.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img 01:35:33","updatedTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","title":"Trump tells supporters 'you'll never see me again' if he loses to Biden","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-says-youll-never-see-me-again-loses-to-biden-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f2fd799988ee36ff65e14a6?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Trump\" height=\"798\" width=\"1200\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">JIM WATSON/AFP via Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>At a campaign rally in North Carolina Saturday, President Donald Trump told attendees they'll never see or hear from him again if he loses the election to Joe Biden.&#160;</li>\n<li>\"If I lose to him, I don't know what I'm going to do. I will never speak to you again,\" Trump told supporters at a rally in North Carolina.</li>\n<li>In a June interview, Trump refused to say whether he would accept the results of the 2020 election if he did not emerge the winner.&#160;</li>\n<li>Trump made similar remarks in 2016 when he rivaled Hillary Clinton for the presidency: \"I don't think I'm going to lose, but if I do, I don't think you're ever going to see me again, folks,\" Trump <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/donald-trump-if-i-lose-i-dont-think-you-will-ever-see-me-again-2016-4\">said</a>. \"I think I'll go to Turnberry and play golf or something.\"</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>President Donald Trump told supporters Saturday night that he will never speak to them again if he loses the election in November.&#160;</p><p>Speaking at a campaign rally in Fayetteville, North Carolina, Trump railed against rival Joe Biden, calling him \"the worst candidate in the history of presidential politics.\"</p><p>\"If I lose to him, I don't know what I'm going to do. I will never speak to you again,\" Trump told the attendees at the rally. \"You'll never see me again.\"</p><p>Neither the Trump nor Biden campaign immediately responded to a request for comment from Business Insider.&#160;</p><p>Biden, in yet <a href=\"https://www.insider.com/biden-trolls-trump-and-purchases-keep-america-great-web-domain-2020-8\">another move to troll the president</a>, released a 10-second ad shortly after Trump delivered his remarks, approving the message.&#160;</p><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" data-cards=\"\" data-conversation=\"\">&#8212;Joe Biden  (@JoeBiden) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/mims/statuses/1307491919384260609?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">September 20, 2020</a></blockquote><script async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script><p>Trump made similar remarks in 2016 when he rivaled Hillary Clinton for the presidency.</p><p>\"I don't think I'm going to lose, but if I do, I don't think you're ever going to see me again, folks,\" Trump <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/donald-trump-if-i-lose-i-dont-think-you-will-ever-see-me-again-2016-4\">said at a Maryland rally in April 2016</a>. \"I think I'll go to Turnberry and play golf or something.\"</p><p>Trump has signaled how he'll react if Biden wins the election. In a June interview, he refused to say whether he would <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-suggests-that-he-wont-accept-the-2020-election-results-if-he-loses-2020-7\">accept the results</a>.</p><p>\"I have to see, look, I have to see, I'm not just going to say yes, I'm not going to say no, and I didn't last time either,\" Trump said when asked for a clear answer on whether he'd accept this year's election results.</p><p>Biden is leading Trump by about 6 percentage points, according to a national polling average from Real Clear Politics.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-says-youll-never-see-me-again-loses-to-biden-2020-9'>Business Insider</a></div><div border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=26CEPprD8ec:7Qozt8D8kFQ:F7zBnMyn0Lo\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=26CEPprD8ec:7Qozt8D8kFQ:F7zBnMyn0Lo\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=26CEPprD8ec:7Qozt8D8kFQ:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=26CEPprD8ec:7Qozt8D8kFQ:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=26CEPprD8ec:7Qozt8D8kFQ:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=26CEPprD8ec:7Qozt8D8kFQ:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=26CEPprD8ec:7Qozt8D8kFQ:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/26CEPprD8ec\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sun, 20 Sep 2020 15:20:42 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f67666757b7da001ee12a78?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"5afcb6d5e473cc847e12baf55c515d1a","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn24@2020_5/2020/09/20/17-35-50-361_dd2be03fcb89758b.webp","destWidth":1064,"destHeight":798,"sourceBytes":32502,"destBytes":32502,"author":"ydzhanova@businessinsider.com (Yelena Dzhanova)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f2fd799988ee36ff65e14a6?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn82@2020_2/2020/09/20/17-35-35-706_402a8b0aa4097fad.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn62@2020_4/2020/09/20/17-35-46-023_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=26CEPprD8ec:7Qozt8D8kFQ:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn63@2020_3/2020/09/20/17-35-47-071_34432f6d405e1231.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=26CEPprD8ec:7Qozt8D8kFQ:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn60@2020_4/2020/09/20/17-35-40-556_c93b1ee92f6cfe48.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=26CEPprD8ec:7Qozt8D8kFQ:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn96@2020_6/2020/09/20/17-35-47-059_3d97d0b94cf45d73.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/26CEPprD8ec":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn12@2020_1/2020/09/20/17-35-48-901_76f38c167a02dc4e.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1600623333147},{"createdTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","updatedTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","title":"My life has been chaos since quarantine started. Here are 5 habits helping me sleep better and stay calm and centered during the day.","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/changes-ive-made-to-my-self-care-routine-during-quarantine-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f64ce5157b7da001ee1272c?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Katie Nave\" height=\"2078\" width=\"2771\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Katie Nave has incorporated things like meditation, reading, and tarot cards into her self-care routine during the pandemic.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Katie Nave</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Katie Nave is freelance writer, advocate, and nonprofit communications specialist based in Brooklyn, New York.</li>\n<li>&#160;At the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic in March, she moved in with her ex-husband so they could safely co-parent their 5-year-old daughter.</li>\n<li>In an aim to improve her mental health, she developed self-care morning and evening routines to carve out quiet time for meditation, journaling, and reading.</li>\n<li>Nave also says that burning incense and candles, reading tarot cards, and shutting off her phone an hour before bed have helped improve her headspace and sleep habits.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Like many people, my life in quarantine is chaos. Back in March, my daughter's school closed, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/quarantined-with-ex-husband-since-march-covid-pandemic-2020-7\">I moved back in with my ex-husband</a> to safely co-parent, and my freelance work began to dry up. Like most everyone, my daily routine and creature comforts were completely gone, and I felt like a mess.</p><p>I've never been the Gywneth Paltrow, glowy, goddess-of-perfection-and-wellness type, but in the past, self-care meant getting to an exercise class in the morning or meeting up with friends for dinner. Without access to these, at the start of quarantine, I became a person who was always reaching for my phone, obsessively reading the latest news alerts and living in a constant state of fear.&#160;</p><p>After completely losing my cool with my daughter one night, I knew that something had to give. I felt I'd lost myself, and it was taking a toll on those closest to me. I needed to find a way to feel grounded again. I thought of my former methods of self-care, considered my therapist's (often ignored) suggestions, and did a little research. Then, I came up with a ritual to better start and end my day.&#160;</p><h2><strong>I've started waking up earlier for alone time to prepare for the day.</strong><strong>&#160;</strong></h2><p>For someone coping with anxiety or depression, simply facing the day can be overwhelming, but <a href=\"https://www.psychologytoday.com/us/blog/the-gen-y-psy/201810/the-power-routines-in-your-mental-health\">studies show</a> that maintaining a consistent daily routine can greatly benefit your mental health. I have certainly seen the results firsthand.&#160;</p><p>I wake up around 6 a.m. to ensure that I'm up before my daughter has a chance to barge in with an array of nuanced questions about sea animals. Sure, sleeping in for a few extra hours can be rejuvenating, but if I wake up and am immediately thrown into the madness of the day, I feel perpetually behind. Instead, taking about 20 minutes total for myself has helped to increase my productivity, energy, and overall mood.</p><h2><strong>Before anyone needs my attention, I go to my dedicated space and get still.&#160;</strong></h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f64cefd57b7da001ee12731?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Katie Nave\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Nave starts her day at 6 a.m. for some quiet time before her daughter wakes up.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Katie Nave</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>I've found it helpful to sit in the same spot in the corner of my bedroom each morning, light incense or a candle, and say a quick prayer or simply listen to my breath. I bought my floor cushion from a woman I met in Mexico, but there are <a href=\"https://www.etsy.com/listing/716435574/meditation-cushion-seating-floor-pillow?ga_order=most_relevant&ga_search_type=all&ga_view_type=gallery&ga_search_query=floor+cushion&ref=sr_gallery-1-5&organic_search_click=1&pro=1&frs=1_click=1&#38;pro=1&#38;frs=1\">similar cushions</a> available online that can ship almost anywhere. For me, this isn't a religious practice or a formal meditation. It is simply a way to get still, get quiet, and get centered.</p><p>I've also started pulling<a href=\"https://hauswitchstore.com/collections/tarot-oracle-decks/products/55724\"> tarot cards</a>&#160;each morning to help inspire reflection and direction. While this is likely not for everyone, I got inspired to do so after spending a weekend with my wonderfully witchy friend who walked me through how to do a simple tarot spread. HausWitch hosts <a href=\"https://hauswitchstore.com/collections/virtual-workshops\">virtual workshops online</a> where you can learn all about it.&#160;</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f64cf7557b7da001ee12735?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Katie Nave tarot\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Nave was introduced to tarot by a friend that reads the cards.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Katie Nave.</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Opening the curtains and letting natural light in is energizing and I immediately feel lighter when the fresh air hits my face.&#160;</p><h2><strong>Writing in a journal helps me get out all of my feelings.&#160;&#160;</strong></h2><p>I've always been a person with big feelings. Ideally, before starting the day, I'll take a few minutes to jot down my thoughts, purge my fears, and create a gratitude list. Getting super granular about specific areas of gratitude is a great anecdote for stress. A list may simply include my healthy lungs, my daughter's soft snores, a thoughtful text from a friend, or my cup of coffee.&#160;</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f64cfc557b7da001ee12736?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Katie Nave\" height=\"2274\" width=\"3024\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Nave has tried to write a journal entry each day during quarantine.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Katie Nave</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>I keep a stack of <a href=\"https://www.papersource.com/desk/lively-floral-journals-10001293.html\">simple journals from Paper Source</a> next to my bed that I try to write in each day. Revisiting journal entries from days and weeks back has also proven helpful in gaining perspective, especially as I become more and more desensitized to the pandemic. No matter what happens, I see that my feelings are like weather, always coming and going.&#160;</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f64d34f57b7da001ee12746?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Katie Nave journal\" height=\"2274\" width=\"3024\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Nave is filling up a stack of journals during quarantine.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Katie Nave</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>After this quiet time and a few gentle stretches, I'm ready to start my day.</p><h2><strong>In the evening, I carve out time to unwind and unplug.</strong></h2><p>While living in quarantine, I've spent many nights going down social media rabbit holes, glass of wine in-hand. I'm not alone in this, as <a href=\"https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/us-study-finds-covid-19-pandemic-transforms-cell-phone-usage-301066502.html\">studies show</a> that the pandemic has led to a large increase in cell phone usage. We're all feeling bored, lonely, and seeking pleasure. However, each time we pick up our phones, the flood of alerts can cause stress hormones to go through the roof.</p><p>Putting my phone away about an hour before bed and taking space to decompress from the day has helped me to feel more calm and has drastically improved my sleep.</p><h2><strong>A simple meditation practice at night helps me to sleep better. </strong></h2><p>I've always been resistant to meditation. I get itchy, bored, or simply fall asleep while attempting a long, formal practice. It annoyed the shit out of me when my ex discovered transcendental meditation, so it's likely that I'm still holding a personal grudge. Still, <a href=\"https://www.nccih.nih.gov/health/meditation-in-depth\">studies show</a> that meditation is highly beneficial to one's mental and physical health, so I've stopped trying to fight it.</p><p>I've recently embraced the practice of sitting still, listening to my breath, and clearing my mind for a few minutes each night. If I'm feeling fancy, I'll rub calming <a href=\"https://www.theartistryofessentialoils.com/\">essential oils</a>, like lavender or chamomile, and light <a href=\"https://www.swansonvitamins.com/aloha-bay-healing-chakra-energy-jar-candle-1-11-oz-unit?SourceCode=INTL4071&DFA=1&UTM_Medium=Shopping&UTM_Source=GOOGLE&UTM_Campaign=SWAN_National_Gen_Shopping_Null_Null_All+Products_Medium+4055-01+Healthy+Home&UTM_Content=PRODUCT_GROUP&SourceCode=INTL4071&ds_rl=1262629&ds_rl=1263854&ds_rl=1262629&gclid=CjwKCAjwkoz7BRBPEiwAeKw3q0Xvos973p7STbeT-Np5m6Hg-vF7lGsqLfDB6VIpcVu2ZRxOGOV8pxoCcyYQAvD_BwE7lGsqLfDB6VIpcVu2ZRxOGOV8pxoCcyYQAvD_BwE\">a candle</a>. Before putting my phone away for the night, I'll sometimes use the <a href=\"https://www.calm.com/\">Calm</a> app. They have daily 10 minute guided meditations, and more in-depth options, that I love.&#160;</p><h2><strong>Reading also offers me a therapeutic escape.&#160;</strong></h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f64d20057b7da001ee12742?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Katie Nave books\" height=\"2268\" width=\"3023\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Reading has helped Nave focus and avoid worrying too much.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Katie Nave</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Since childhood, reading has always provided me with a much-needed escape from reality. Whether I'm absorbed in a fiction novel or diving into a nonfiction topic of fascination, books help me to get outside of myself. They force me to stop multitasking, be still, and focus on the page in front of me.</p><p>Sharing book recommendations with friends in quarantine has also been a small way to add human connection and stay in touch with those that I miss. While I had trouble focusing early in quarantine, I'm now back in the reading game and have enjoyed \"Women Talking\" by Miriam Toews, \"Big Friendship\" by Aminatou Sow and Ann Friedman, \"There There\" by Tommy Orange, and \"Little Weirds\" by Jenny Slate.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f64d27e57b7da001ee12744?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Katie Nave book\" height=\"2274\" width=\"3024\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Nave has enjoyed reading &#34;Big Friendship&#34; by Aminatou Sow.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Katie Nave</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><h2><strong>My self-care rituals are far from perfect, but they have made a big difference for my mental health during this time.&#160;</strong></h2><p>As normal routines have been completely rocked, establishing regular touchpoints each morning and night has become my anchor. I'm still scared, sad, and anxious quite often, but this has helped me to feel a little more at ease each day.&#160;</p><section data-track-content=\"\" data-post-type=\"post\"><p><em>Katie Nave is a freelance writer, advocate, and nonprofit communications specialist living in Brooklyn, New York. Learn more on her&#160;<a href=\"http://www.katienavefreeman.com/\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"100\" data-uri=\"fdd2e0fde125bbaf8c791fc9f1f44ee1\">website</a>.</em></p></section><section></section><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a 4_771c9291fc08a9a9.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1600623333158},{"createdTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","updatedTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","title":"A vaccine doesn't mean the pandemic is over","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/coronavirus-vaccine-pandemic-flu-season-supply-chain-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f60ae1557b7da001ee1196d?format=jpeg\" alt=\"china coronavirus vaccine\" height=\"3541\" width=\"5312\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A vaccine may not mean the end of the pandemic.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Getty</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>We haven't yet experienced an entire season with influenza and coronavirus circulating at full force.&#160;</li>\n<li>The United States needs an estimated 850 million more syringes to distribute both coronavirus and seasonal influenza vaccines.</li>\n<li>To wipe out the coronavirus, addressing shortfalls in the vaccine supply chain must be a top priority.</li>\n<li>Purushottam Meena, Ph.D., is an Associate Professor of Operations Management in the School of Management at New York Institute of Technology.&#160;<em><br ></em></li>\n<li>This is an opinion column. The thoughts expressed are those of the author.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Dr. Anthony Fauci, director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, thinks that drug companies may develop a <a href=\"https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/fauci-predicts-safe-effective-coronavirus-vaccine-end-year-n1239055\">COVID-19 vaccine before year's end</a>.&#160;&#160;</p><p>But that doesn't mean the pandemic will be over. Far from it.</p><p>Distributing hundreds of millions of vaccine doses will pose an enormous challenge, and our country's medical supply chain — responsible for producing, transporting, and delivering crucial equipment and treatments nationwide — is <a href=\"https://www.acpjournals.org/doi/10.7326/M20-1326\">already overwhelmed</a>.&#160;</p><p>From shortages of life-saving medical devices to logistical obstacles, the United States is woefully unprepared — especially since the upcoming flu season will complicate the rollout of any such vaccine. Dismantling these roadblocks in the supply chain is the only way to end this pandemic.</p><h2>With the oncoming flu season, essential medical materials will be in short supply</h2><p>COVID-19 cases started soaring in the United States in mid-March, as the 2019-2020 flu season was winding down. We haven't yet experienced an entire season with influenza and the coronavirus both circulating at full force.&#160;</p><p>A concurrent surge without adequate preparation would be a disaster — for patients, providers, and the supply chain. COVID-19 and the flu both cause similar respiratory symptoms. Hospitals and ICUs experienced severe shortages of critical supplies toward the beginning of the pandemic, forcing states to compete for life-saving resources like ventilators and respirators. Given that <a href=\"https://www.cdc.gov/flu/about/burden/2018-2019.html\">hundreds of thousands of Americans are hospitalized with the flu each year</a>, an influx of more patients with similar needs could create even larger demand for equipment that's already in short supply.&#160;</p><p>Stopping this impending surge will require an adequate number of flu vaccines, more supplies, closely monitored delivery, and more funding — all of which the vaccine supply chain already struggles with.&#160;</p><p>Even before COVID-19, there were <a href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/coronavirus-vaccine-makers-are-hunting-for-vital-equipment-glass-vials-11592317525\">limited reserves of the medical-grade glass</a> used to make vaccine vials. The glass contains a specific composition of chemicals, which makes it more resistant to temperature changes and helps keep vaccines stable. It takes days or weeks to melt and mold it into the necessary vials.&#160;&#160;</p><p>The syringes used to inject inoculations are also running low. The United States needs an <a href=\"https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/2020/07/02/covid-mask-shortage-left-us-unprotected-syringes-next/5359482002/\">estimated 850 million more syringes</a> to distribute both coronavirus and seasonal influenza vaccines. As of May, it only had 15 million syringes stockpiled, and the current efforts to close that gap are not very reassuring. Though the Department of Health and Human Services has contracted with several companies to manufacture 820 million more syringes, <a href=\"https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/2020/07/02/covid-mask-shortage-left-us-unprotected-syringes-next/5359482002/\">only 420 million will be available by the end of the year</a>, according to reporting from USA Today.</p><h2>Keeping vaccines cold enough during transportation poses another challenge</h2><p>Beyond the scarcity of materials, there are shortcomings within the \"cold chain\" for vaccines. The cold chain is a section of the supply chain that requires temperature control. It's a necessary component of the transportation process for a number of different goods — ranging from ice cream to insulin.&#160;</p><p>Vaccines have to be kept at a constant, cool temperature, typically between 35 and 46 degrees Fahrenheit, even when transported across the country. Outside of this range, they lose their potency and must be thrown away. Many of the COVID-19 vaccines in development may <a href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/covid-19-vaccine-race-turns-deep-freezers-into-a-hot-commodity-11599217201\">require even cooler temperatures</a> — dipping as low as negative 112 degrees Fahrenheit — making cold chain transportation even more challenging.&#160;</p><p>While there have been advances in technology used to refrigerate in-transit vaccines, mistakes can still happen far too easily. It only takes one trucking leg or storage facility that isn't temperature-controlled to spoil an entire batch.&#160;</p><p>If there's any hope in preventing vaccine shortages and the havoc that would wreak on our nation's health care system, these issues must be addressed.</p><h2>Fortunately, our political leaders can help — and already are</h2><p>The US government has entered into contracts with multiple private companies like <a href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/coronavirus-vaccine-makers-are-hunting-for-vital-equipment-glass-vials-11592317525\">SiO2</a> and <a href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/drugmakers-race-to-build-covid-19-vaccine-supply-chains-11596101586\">Corning</a>, allowing them to expand their manufacturing capacities and make more medical-grade vials. Fostering more of these longstanding partnerships between government and private commercial enterprises would help alleviate roadblocks in the vaccine supply chain by preventing shortages of crucial materials, long before those supplies are needed.&#160;</p><p>The government could also rethink how it allocates vaccines. Typically, flu vaccines are distributed based on cities' and states' populations. But this approach doesn't reflect the share of the population that is willing to actually get the vaccine. When the uptake rate in a population is low, unused vaccines accumulate. Health officials should take historical uptake rates into account to prevent surpluses in some regions and shortages in others.&#160;&#160;</p><p>Even still, these changes won't help without a more streamlined cold chain transportation process. New temperature-controlled delivery technologies can prove expensive. But making simple changes — like limiting handoff points, consolidating shipments, and monitoring the temperature of shipments in real-time — can mitigate damages to scarce vaccine supplies.&#160;</p><p>Developing an effective COVID-19 vaccine is merely the beginning of the end of this pandemic. To wipe out the virus, lawmakers need to address shortfalls in the vaccine supply chain.&#160;</p><p><em>Purushottam Meena, Ph.D., is an associate professor of operations management in the School of Management at New York Institute of Technology.&#160;</em></p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sun, 20 Sep 2020 13:15:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f6508ac57b7da001ee128b1?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"cf3aea1530910137967127fc9c454123","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn33@2020_1/2020/09/20/17-35-35-682_1dc7d7d66b9a99f5.webp","destWidth":1666,"destHeight":1249,"sourceBytes":126318,"destBytes":126318,"author":"tclark@businessinsider.com (Travis Clark)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f0cda5baee6a8103b469392?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn2@2020_1/2020/09/20/17-35-43-348_78659ed8523f72fc.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f650191323fc4001e0d731d?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn41@2020_6/2020/09/20/17-35-46-967_1a51171b60577b8a.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f650276323fc4001e0d7324?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn50@2020_4/2020/09/20/17-35-43-603_db9d0d8368632742.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f650356323fc4001e0d7328?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn86@2020_1/2020/09/20/17-35-40-787_58ddfd0bf07ca4f9.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f65041f323fc4001e0d732e?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn56@2020_6/2020/09/20/17-35-48-155_1fad644109d4a41d.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f65051257b7da001ee1289a?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn3@2020_5/2020/09/20/17-35-41-430_8c5c75475a1565b5.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f65059d323fc4001e0d7336?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn42@2020_3/2020/09/20/17-35-41-917_204230fa43ad4ce3.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f6506a657b7da001ee128a7?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn93@2020_6/2020/09/20/17-35-43-284_f0b726437a9def70.webp","https://i.insider.com/5ef0dd2e3ad861092c6269d7?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn14@2020_5/2020/09/20/17-35-38-052_98879e9e4fe1e9d1.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f0cda5c3f737046d07b4032?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn50@2020_6/2020/09/20/17-35-41-809_1eef26e4c344315c.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn62@2020_4/2020/09/20/17-35-46-023_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=BZvAloxH7LI:-CqRlLbasBU:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn82@2020_4/2020/09/20/17-35-40-625_16852680d72cfa87.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=BZvAloxH7LI:-CqRlLbasBU:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn3@2020_2/2020/09/20/17-35-44-769_17f62c971193fe1e.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=BZvAloxH7LI:-CqRlLbasBU:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn65@2020_5/2020/09/20/17-35-38-317_26a355fb6855c123.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/BZvAloxH7LI":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn4@2020_6/2020/09/20/17-35-36-793_3ca6d6d3b89369c0.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1600623333157},{"createdTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","updatedTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","title":"11 practical pieces of advice I wish someone had given me when I was younger","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/practical-pieces-of-advice-id-give-to-my-younger-self-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e7e3e430c2a6238181fb86b?format=jpeg\" alt=\"mother and daughter boomer millennial\" height=\"1414\" width=\"1885\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Author Polina Marinova says she&#39;s learned that life is about spending intentional time with the people you love.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.gettyimages.com/detail/photo/senior-woman-and-young-woman-examining-flower-in-royalty-free-image/1139688071?adppopup=true\" target=\"_blank\">Oliver Rossi/Getty Images</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Polina Marinova is the founder and author of&#160;<a href=\"https://theprofile.substack.com/\" target=\"_blank\" title=\"https://theprofile.substack.com/\" rel=\"noopener\" data-saferedirecturl=\"https://www.google.com/url?q=https://theprofile.substack.com/&source=gmail&ust=1593205833501000&usg=AFQjCNE9bjciSqIGeHGkAeAFX8Y9-Rga7AAFX8Y9-Rga7A\" data-analytics-module=\"summary_bullets\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"0\">The Profile</a>, a newsletter that features interesting longform profiles on successful people and companies.</li>\n<li>When she was younger, Marinova says she would often let one setback put a damper on her entire day, week, or even month. Now, at 28, she says she works to see the good even in difficult times.</li>\n<li>Marinova says she's learned it's important to not let your identity become stagnant, and that it's better to be interesting than perfect.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>These days, people love to make small talk starting with the following: \"Man, 2020 has been a really s----y year.\"&#160;</p><p>While I understand the sentiment, I can't bring myself to nod in full agreement. This year has been absolutely devastating for a myriad of reasons, but it has also had a few bright spots. I got married, left my job, started a business, and moved to a new apartment.&#160;</p><p>When I was younger, I would let one awful event ruin my day, week, or even month. Every time something good happened, the awful thing I worried about would loom over me like a perpetual dark cloud. One of the biggest lessons I've learned this year is that good and bad&#160;<em>can</em> coexist. When something's bad, it's not&#160;<em>all</em>&#160;bad, and vice versa.</p><p>My birthday is approaching, so I wanted to reflect on my 28th year of life and share some practical nuggets that I've found useful.</p><h2><strong>1. The quality of your work will eventually catch up to your ambition.</strong></h2><p>I've been working on The Profile for three years. It's come a long way since then. The reason it has gotten better is because I didn't give up on it — even when it was bad.</p><p><a href=\"https://theprofile.substack.com/p/ira-glass-the-king-of-storytelling\">Ira Glass said</a>&#160;that everybody who does interesting, creative work went through years where they had really good taste and could tell their product wasn't as good as they wanted it to be. It fell short. And that's exactly when most people quit.</p><p>It took Glass 10 years of podcasts for him to feel like his taste caught up to his ambition. The only way to close the gap between taste and skill? Doing the work week after week, day after day. \"It is only by going through a volume of work that you're going to catch up and close that gap,\" he said.</p><h2><strong>2. Find ways to fall into intellectual rabbit holes.</strong></h2><p>When I sit down to write, I typically draw on my experiences for ideas. But during quarantine, those real-life experiences have dwindled. So I've had to learn how to create an environment that facilitates falling into rabbit holes.</p><p>The first way I do that is by pestering interesting people to have conversations with me. The second is to go on a walk outside and&#160;<em>actively</em> observe my surroundings. And finally, I sometimes just take a book from my bookshelf, open it to a random page and start reading. Ideas are all around us… we just need to notice them.</p><h2><strong>3. Take mental breaks throughout the day.</strong></h2><p>After a long period of staring at the screen, my mind starts screaming. That's when I know I need to take a break. For me, there are several activities that soothe me, and I use them to break up my day in three chunks.</p><p>In the morning, I do 10 to 20 minutes of yoga. In the afternoon, I exercise for about 30 minutes. And in the evening, I take a walk with Anthony for about 45 minutes to an hour. All three things are physical because they get my blood flowing, allowing me to step away from technology and let my mind wander. This has been the single-best, most-rewarding change I've made in the last year.</p><h2><strong>4. Chase what you don't know.</strong></h2><p>It's so damn easy to label ourselves a certain type of person. For a long time, I was a \"journalist.\" Suddenly, I'm an entrepreneur! Who knows what I'll be five years from now? The point is not to let your identity become stagnant.</p><p>Actor Willem Dafoe, who has played a Spider-Man villain, Vincent van Gogh, and Jesus, <a href=\"https://time.com/5714746/willem-dafoe-the-lighthouse-interview/\">says</a> that so much of what we do is predicated on an idea of ourselves that we're trying to protect. It's part of the reason he enjoys playing such a range of characters. He's always chasing after what he doesn't know. \"Do things that don't let you decide definitively who you are and the way things are,\" he said.</p><h2><strong>5. Be interesting, not perfect.</strong></h2><p>I used to optimize for perfection. Now I optimize for being interesting. Think about the favorite people in your life. Do you care that their hair is perfectly combed? Or do you not even notice that because you're so captivated by their brain?</p><p>Whether it's art, movies, or books, people talk more about the flawed things that get stuck in their heads than they do the obvious, perfect things.&#160;<a href=\"https://theprofile.substack.com/p/the-profile-dossier-malcolm-gladwell\">Malcolm Gladwell</a> said, \"You want an aftertaste, and that comes from not everything being perfectly blended together. The question is: What is interesting? That's what has to drive any creative act.\"</p><h2><strong>6. Competence is the antidote to fear.</strong></h2><p>I used to be absolutely terrified of public speaking. At the thought of it, I'd start nervously sweating. But here's the thing: Things aren't scary. People get scared.</p><p>I learned this from&#160;<a href=\"https://theprofile.substack.com/p/the-profile-dossier-chris-hadfield\">astronaut Chris Hadfield</a>. He uses the following example: When you first learned how to ride a bike, you were fearful because you could crash and hurt yourself. Then, as you got better and more confident in your skills, it became silly to be afraid of a bike. Yet the bike itself didn't change — it remained just as dangerous as it always was. <em>You</em>&#160;are the one who changed. Competence breeds confidence.</p><h2><strong>7. Your choices belong only to you and no one else.</strong></h2><p>One of my biggest worries before I left my job at Fortune was: \"What if I disappoint someone?\" When I think about this question now, I am amazed at the self-centered assumption it implies. Who — aside from my incredibly supportive family — cares so much about my life choices that they would be ... disappointed?</p><p>The brutal truth is that we're all busy navigating our own lives to have enough time to be disappointed in other people's decisions. I've learned to normalize my life. Do whatever makes you happy, and stop letting other people's misinformed judgments dictate your day-to-day.&#160;</p><h2><strong>8. Love is not an emotion; it's a skill.</strong></h2><p>Everything in life —&#160;yes, even love —&#160;is a skill. When&#160;<a href=\"https://theprofile.substack.com/p/100-couples-share-their-secrets-to\">I asked couples for their best marriage advice</a>, the one thing that kept coming up is that they understood that a loving partnership is a constant work in progress, and there's always room for improvement.</p><p>One reader told me, \"It has to be worked on; sharpened regularly. Much like any other craft, the time that goes into keeping it fresh and vibrant must be respected. And like all important skills, it must be used.\"</p><h2><strong>9. Life is about good people and good stories.</strong></h2><p>Because we've all been in quarantine for months now, I've become much more intentional about the people I want to spend time with. Although my circle of friends has gotten even smaller, it's grown exponentially in terms of amazing conversations and unforgettable memories.</p><p><a href=\"https://theprofile.substack.com/p/the-profile-dossier-shonda-rhimes\">As Shonda Rhimes put it:</a>&#160;\"I now work to see people, not as I'd rewrite them, but as they have written themselves. I see them for who they are. And for who I am with them.\"</p><h2><strong>10. No matter what, always bet on yourself.</strong></h2><p>One of the more mind-blowing things I've realized in the last year is that no job, no person, no amount of money will ever fulfill me if my self-worth is tied to something external.</p><p><a href=\"https://theprofile.substack.com/p/i-quit-my-job-at-the-start-of-the\">I've written about this before</a>, but it's incredibly liberating to have your identity tied to your own name. The best thing I did is start The Profile in 2017 because it gave me another identity — one that allowed me to be 100% myself.</p><h2><strong>11. Get proximate to suffering.</strong></h2><p>After everything that's happened in 2020, it's become crystal clear that many of us live in a bubble. To better understand other perspectives, we've got to get curious and break out of our own narrow views of the world. Visit a shelter, volunteer at a food bank, or help someone going through a tough time.</p><p>Here's&#160;<a href=\"https://theprofile.substack.com/p/the-profile-dossier-bryan-stevenson\">what Bryan Stevenson taught me</a>: \"We must get proximate to suffering and understand the nuanced experiences of those who suffer from and experience inequality. If you are willing to get closer to people who are suffering, you will find the power to change the world.\"</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/qvV5cfDtlc4\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sun, 20 Sep 2020 13:15:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5e7e3e430c2a6238181fb86b?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"33766db9a859227e89532fddf7d1e696","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn2@2020_4/2020/09/20/17-35-33-432_3abe6716d0e57611.webp","destWidth":1885,"destHeight":1414,"sourceBytes":264506,"destBytes":264506,"author":"insider@insider.com (Polina Marinova)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5e7e3e430c2a6238181fb86b?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn2@2020_4/2020/09/20/17-35-33-432_3abe6716d0e57611.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn62@2020_4/2020/09/20/17-35-46-023_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=qvV5cfDtlc4:IBe_9WjbzCk:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn66@2020_3/2020/09/20/17-35-41-164_a9d3fe1326a31c4d.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=qvV5cfDtlc4:IBe_9WjbzCk:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn62@2020_5/2020/09/20/17-35-38-174_8f85c9ad1164d63b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=qvV5cfDtlc4:IBe_9WjbzCk:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn91@2020_3/2020/09/20/17-35-37-181_92626004ad562c91.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/qvV5cfDtlc4":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn25@2020_4/2020/09/20/17-35-37-152_b7e4e2de80cd6797.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1600623333135},{"createdTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","updatedTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","title":"REVIEW: The Ram 1500 Rebel proves that when it comes to pickup trucks, diesel is better","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/ram-1500-rebel-review-diesel-pickup-truck-dodge-specs-torque-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f64c3cb57b7da001ee126d9?format=jpeg\" alt=\"RAM 1500 Diesel\" height=\"1500\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>RAM 1500 Rebel sported a menacing, blacked-out exterior.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Matthew DeBord/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>I tested a very, very well equipped 2020 <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/category/ram\">Ram</a> 1500 Rebel <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/category/pickup-trucks\">pickup truck</a>, an off-road optimized version of the truck that <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ram-1500-pickup-truck-business-insider-car-year-winner-2019-11\">captured our Car of the Year award in 2019</a>.</li>\n<li>My Rebel had a potent 3.0-liter turbodiesel engine that serves up 260 horsepower but an earthshaking 480 pound-feet of torque.</li>\n<li>My tester also featured a menacing, blacked-out exterior package.</li>\n<li>The Ram 1500 is a great pickup, but the diesel Rebel is something special.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Here's how the sequence usually goes for me when it comes to reviewing full-size pickup trucks. First, I sample the regular gas-powered version, and because I like big pickups, I often end up a happy guy. But then I spend some time with the diesel-engined model, and I forget all about the gas-burner.</p><p>Diesel and pickups! Two great tastes that go great together! A beautiful friendship!</p><p>Choose your cliché, but the bottom line is that diesel power, for obvious reasons, makes sense for large trucks — especially if you intend to do any sort of serious work, haul heavy loads, or tow more than a modest camper or trailer.&#160;</p><p>Ram makes a dandy full-size pickup. The Ram 1500 was Business Insider's <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ram-1500-pickup-truck-business-insider-car-year-winner-2019-11#:~:text=The%20RAM%201500%20pickup%20truck,of%20the%20Year%20%2D%20Business%20Insider&text=The%20word%20%22Insider%22.%22.\">2019 Car of the Year</a>, and it was a vehicle that impressed us mightily when tested on both the East and West Coasts. But the diesel is even better if you can imagine improving on greatness, as I found out when I borrowed the 2020 edition of the pickup, in a handsome \"Diamond Black Crystal Pearl-Coat\" paint job, for a week over the summer.</p><h2>Rebel, Rebel ... I love you so!</h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f64c3e9323fc4001e0d7130?format=jpeg\" alt=\"RAM 1500 Diesel\" height=\"1385\" width=\"1847\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The pickup is optimized for off-roading.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Matthew DeBord/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>And what a pickup it was! The Base Crew Cab 4x4 was $47,990, but many options — including the \"Rebel Level 2\" equipment group ($3,000) and a $5,000 diesel motor — brought my as-tested price to $71,305. A tech package that added heated seats and a heated steering wheel also tacked $3,000 on the sticker, and assorted other goodies embellished the Ram by $200 to $500 here and there.</p><p>But that's the usual story full-size pickups, which are best thought of these days as nearly infinitely option-able, yielding some wide price ranges for the manufacturers that sell everything from bare-bones work trucks to luxurious half-tons.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f64c45b323fc4001e0d7131?format=jpeg\" alt=\"RAM 1500 Diesel\" height=\"1310\" width=\"1747\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>I out the RAM 1500 Rebel to use for a serious run to the garden center.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Matthew DeBord/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Allow me to explain why I was testing the Ram 1500 in the first place: gardening! We sort of amped- p our summertime gardening game this year and had to make a journey of modest distance to a center in New Jersey that we'd heard about from our gardening underground.&#160;</p><p>An SUV wasn't going to cut it; we needed a proper pickup with the proper bed. And as you can see from the photo above, we made good use of it.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f64c3cb57b7da001ee126da?format=jpeg\" alt=\"RAM 1500 Diesel\" height=\"1500\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The bed divider came in handy.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Matthew DeBord/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>The Ram 1500 I tested came with both a tonneau cover, which was easily folded back, and a bed-separator — a great feature that allowed me to divide the box into one area for heavy bags of soil and one for plants. Using the divider to create a spot for the plants close to the cab meant that I could return home at highway speed without worrying about the load shifting, and I didn't have to employ the Ram 1500's tie-down points.</p><p>The truck also had the useful RamBox \"saddlebags,\" a pair of lockable storage compartments at the bed's flanks. I didn't need them, but the feature does use the interior of the Ram 1500's body panels to create some additional capacity, where otherwise an owner might be looking at a third-party setup to tote tools or gear.</p><h2>Trading horsepower for torque, torque, and more torque</h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f64c3ca323fc4001e0d712c?format=jpeg\" alt=\"RAM 1500 Diesel\" height=\"1500\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The truck also features RamBox storage compartments.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Matthew DeBord/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>The 3.0-liter, turbodiesel V6 makes 260 horsepower but — get this — 480 pound-feet of torque.</p><p>That translates into monumental pulling power. The Rebel can tow more than 12,500 pounds, all while putting up some tasty fuel-economy numbers: 21 mpg in the city, 29 on the highway, and 24 combined. (Gas-engined trucks offer a 395-horsepower V8 and a 305-horsepower V6.)&#160;</p><p>The Ram's eight-speed automatic handles all of that torque rather gracefully, piping it to the capable four-wheel-drive system. But it doesn't alter the Rebel diesel's demeanor, which put me in the mind of a small freight train when I was tooling down the highway.</p><p>The truck can go from a standstill to 60 mph in about eight seconds, and when you sum all this up, you see what the Rebel is all about: bold off-roading, an answer to the Ford F-150 Raptor.</p><p>The knobby Goodyear tires were a giveaway, but the overall packaging of my Rebel test truck suggested that one could apply the vehicle to a greater variety of tasks than just trail-busting — crammed as it was with infotainment tech, connectivity, premium appointments, and that dashing black paint job.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f64c3ca323fc4001e0d712d?format=jpeg\" alt=\"RAM 1500 Diesel\" height=\"1500\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The diesel engine was a torque monster.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Matthew DeBord/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>The blacked-out treatment went further than the paint: the $525 exterior package brought a black grille with black framing, a black Ram badge, and black 18-inch wheels.</p><p>As far as off-roading goes, I could point out that black shows dirt, but the Rebel looks so dang cool that I doubt it would stay dirty for long, if ever. This is a pickup that wants to pay frequent visits to the car wash.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f64c3c957b7da001ee126d5?format=jpeg\" alt=\"RAM 1500 Diesel\" height=\"1500\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The styling is aggressive.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Matthew DeBord/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Note, however, that there are textured running boards, making getting in and out of the lifted pickup much easier, but also making it possible to scrape mud off your boots before soiling the primo cab.</p><h2>&#160;A high-end interior and a high-end verdict</h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f64c3cb323fc4001e0d712f?format=jpeg\" alt=\"RAM 1500 Diesel\" height=\"1503\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The RAM Rebel&#39;s interior was premium.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Matthew DeBord/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>The all-black exterior theme continues inside the Rebel, with plush front bucket seats and a comfy, capacious rear configuration. A dual-pane sunroof brightens the cabin considerably, but it's a $1,500 extra.&#160;</p><p>My test truck was chock full o' tech, starting with the 8.4-inch central touchscreen running Fiat Chrysler's underrated Uconnect infotainment system. This setup handles everything from Bluetooth and USB device connectivity to GPS navigation (with USB ports dedicated to charging). I enjoyed the dulcet tones of a 19-speaker Harman-Kardon premium audio system and had Apple CarPlay and Android Auto in reserve.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f64c3ca57b7da001ee126d8?format=jpeg\" alt=\"RAM 1500 Diesel\" height=\"1503\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>I fell for the Rebel.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Matthew DeBord/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>The Ram 1500 was the best full-size pick we drove, off all the half-tons on the market, in the period from about 2015 until last year, when the new Ram grabbed top prize in our Car of Year competition.&#160;</p><p>I had no complaints about the gas-engined V8 I tested in 2019, but the diesel V6 was something special. If you aren't driving fast all the time, you grow to love the succulent surge of torque that an awesome diesel produces, and the visual presentation of the Ram 1500 Rebel intensifies that impression.</p><p>Simply put, the Ram 1500 Rebel diesel is addictive to drive and addictive to look at, in a totally badass sort of way. I think it shook up the gardening center on that day I visited — Darth Vader unsettling the 'burbs.</p><p>It's worth pointing out that although the truck has attitude galore, it also gets the job done. This imitating pickup carried flowers and potting soil home, safely and it style. And that says more about the modern, full-size pickup truck world these days than just about anything else.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/ram-1500-rebel-review-diesel-pickup-truck-dodge-specs-torque-2020-9'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a 241_dc535d4dbb29e9af.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=jV_jaX2VaT4:hc-KlRfG5Dw:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn2@2020_5/2020/09/20/17-35-37-905_ae9c5c5c572e45e3.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/jV_jaX2VaT4":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn78@2020_1/2020/09/20/17-35-45-307_03e46a4e4552b958.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1600623333142},{"createdTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","updatedTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","title":"The ban on TikTok downloads has been postponed by one week after Trump gave his 'blessing' to a deal with Oracle and Walmart","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/tiktok-download-ban-officially-delayed-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f6703b357b7da001ee12a5b?format=jpeg\" alt=\"donald trump plane\" height=\"1882\" width=\"2510\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>US President Donald Trump said he&#39;s given the TikTok-Oracle deal his blessing.\n<p class=\"copyright\">NICHOLAS KAMM/AFP via Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>The US is officially postponing the ban on TikTok downloads it said would come into force on Sunday.</li>\n<li>Secretary of Commerce Wilbur Ross said in a statement Saturday that \"recent positive developments\" meant the deadline for the ban has now been moved to 11:59 p.m. on September 27.</li>\n<li>It came the same day Trump told reporters he had given his \"blessing\" to a deal between TikTok and Oracle.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>The ban on TikTok downloads is officially on hold for a week.</p><p>US Secretary of Commerce Wilbur Ross confirmed the postponement of the ban in a <a href=\"https://www.commerce.gov/news/press-releases/2020/09/statement-delayed-prohibitions-related-tiktok\">statement</a> on Saturday.&#160;</p><p>\"In light of recent positive developments, Secretary of Commerce Wilbur Ross, at the direction of President Trump, will delay the prohibition of identified transactions pursuant to Executive Order 13942, related to the TikTok mobile application that would have been effective on Sunday, September 20, 2020, until September 27, 2020 at 11:59 p.m.\"</p><p>It is a significant U-turn, as the US announced Friday it would&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-banning-all-tiktok-downloads-from-september-20-2020-9\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">ban all new downloads of TikTok and WeChat starting Sunday,</a>&#160;demanding that the app be booted off Apple and Google's app storefronts.</p><p>TikTok, on Friday,&#160;<a href=\"https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-china-tiktok-lawsuit/tiktok-files-complaint-against-trump-administration-to-try-to-block-u-s-ban-idUSKBN26A0DP\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">filed a complaint with a federal court</a>&#160;seeking to block the Trump administration from enforcing the ban.</p><p>The postponement came the same day&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-gives-blessing-to-proposed-tiktok-deal-with-oracle-2020-9\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Trump told reporters he had given his \"blessing\"</a>&#160;to a deal between TikTok and US tech giant Oracle.</p><p>On Saturday, Oracle announced it would become a&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/oracle-announces-125-stake-in-tiktok-global-after-trump-nod-2020-9\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">minority investor in TikTok's global business with a 12.5% stake</a>&#160;in the company, and that it would become the app's secure cloud technology provider. It was confirmed by TikTok, which added it was also working on a partnership with Walmart.</p><p>\"Both companies will take part in a TikTok Global pre-IPO financing round in which they can take up to a 20% cumulative stake in the company,\" TikTok said. It has also promised to set up a US-based headquarters and create 25,000 jobs.&#160;</p><p>The deal is not yet closed, and still needs to win approval from the Chinese government. On Saturday, China's Ministry of Commerce put out a statement accusing the US of bullying. \"If the US insists on going its own way, China will take necessary measures to resolutely safeguard the legitimate rights and interests of Chinese companies,\" the ministry said in a statement per <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2020/sep/19/stay-calm-us-tiktok-users-prepare-for-world-without-newly-banned-app\">The Guardian</a>.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/tiktok-download-ban-officially-delayed-2020-9'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=_v9HtJ_dxlE:uQHwWIV00S0:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a
