href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=_v9HtJ_dxlE:uQHwWIV00S0:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=_v9HtJ_dxlE:uQHwWIV00S0:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=_v9HtJ_dxlE:uQHwWIV00S0:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/_v9HtJ_dxlE\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sun, 20 Sep 2020 08:53:54 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f6703b357b7da001ee12a5b?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"51de9dbcf5fd5bdf0398eae340b5a8fa","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn9@2020_1/2020/09/20/17-35-33-395_1d00399a5216fbc4.webp","destWidth":2510,"destHeight":1882,"sourceBytes":79856,"destBytes":79856,"author":"insider@insider.com (Isobel Asher Hamilton)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f6703b357b7da001ee12a5b?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn9@2020_1/2020/09/20/17-35-33-395_1d00399a5216fbc4.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn62@2020_4/2020/09/20/17-35-46-023_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=_v9HtJ_dxlE:uQHwWIV00S0:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn4@2020_5/2020/09/20/17-35-42-395_735e0e654fcd5479.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=_v9HtJ_dxlE:uQHwWIV00S0:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn34@2020_1/2020/09/20/17-35-46-623_df405eb7d4277bc3.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=_v9HtJ_dxlE:uQHwWIV00S0:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn96@2020_1/2020/09/20/17-35-42-310_c59629738cc157bc.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/_v9HtJ_dxlE":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn80@2020_4/2020/09/20/17-35-37-766_ed6bfb8037c04e29.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1600623333159},{"createdTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","updatedTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","title":"Trump threw stimulus checks back into play and called for a large economic aid package — but Republicans still aren't backing more spending","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-stimulus-checks-coronavirus-economy-federal-spending-unemployment-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f35bd6fb4bb1c001df53365?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Donald Trump .JPG\" height=\"1000\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">REUTERS/Kevin Lamarque</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Trump called on Republicans to back more spending, but he's appeared to sway very few GOP senators.</li>\n<li>Many Republican senators staunchly oppose more federal spending, citing the debt.</li>\n<li>\"The core disagreement: Are we trying to get the economy back up and running or should we keep it shut down?\" conservative economist Oren Cass told Business Insider.</li>\n<li>The impasse threatens to prolong the downturn for millions of people still receiving unemployment benefits.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>President Donald Trump threw the prospect of another round of stimulus checks back into play earlier this week, calling for Republicans to get behind another big aid package.</p><p>But the Senate GOP hasn't been swayed so far — and they're doubling down on their reluctance to approve more federal spending after Democrats blocked a slimmed-down $300 billion package last week.</p><p>On Wednesday, Trump tweeted that Republicans should \"go for the much higher numbers\" on coronavirus aid. He later praised a <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/bipartisan-house-lawmakers-unveil-stimulus-plan-unemployment-economy-2020-9\">$1.5 trillion relief plan</a> that a bipartisan group of 50 House lawmakers put forward.</p><p>\"Some of the Republicans disagree, but I think I can convince them to go along with that because I like the larger number,\" Trump said at a press conference. \"I want to see people get money.\"</p><p>However, top Senate Republicans immediately threw cold water on the idea.</p><p>\"This used to be the White House versus Pelosi up until about now — now the president's coming in and saying we can maybe go to $1.5 trillion,\" Senate Finance Chairman Chuck Grassley <a href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-09-17/republicans-are-divided-again-on-stimulus-this-time-by-trump\">told Bloomberg on Thursday.</a> \"He better be careful of that because I don't think that will get through the United States Senate.\"</p><p>It indicates Trump may have limited influence prodding Republicans to support additional stimulus spending. Before negotiations collapsed last month, Trump largely sat them out, leaving it up to Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and White House chief of staff Mark Meadows — two of his top lieutenants — to engage with Democrats.</p><p><em><strong>Read more:</strong>&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/investing-advice-5-portfolio-moves-second-round-stimulus-andrew-sheets-2020-9\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"80\" data-uri=\"34eada2db0ca11066be5cd3d491c5dad\">Morgan Stanley says the stock market's future is 'unusually dependent' on another stimulus package — and recommends 5 portfolio moves to make if Congress passes another round</a></em></p><p>Democrats led by Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi are insisting on at least $2.2 trillion in federal spending. They lowered their demand from $3.4 trillion, the size of an aid package House Democrats passed in May. It included provisions for additional stimulus checks, $600 unemployment benefits, and state aid.</p><p>There are still areas of fierce disagreement between Republicans and Democrats. Talks fell through in early August after both sides failed to bridge divisions on federal unemployment aid and state aid, prompting Trump to implement several executive actions.</p><h2>\"Are we trying to get the economy back up and running or should we keep it shut down?\"</h2><p>Oren Cass, executive director of American Compass and a conservative economist in contact with several congressional GOP offices, says the standoff between both parties stems from conflicting views of what a package should achieve.</p><p>\"The core disagreement: Are we trying to get the economy back up and running or should we keep it shut down?\" Cass told Business Insider.</p><p>Complicating matters is that Republicans never coalesced around an aid package. They unveiled a $1 trillion plan in late July, but Senate Republicans never brought it to a vote since scores of lawmakers within their party opposed the price tag.</p><p>Cass favors another stimulus package to prop up the economy, saying its recovery can be accelerated by helping people return to work. He adds additional relief legislation would likely benefit the GOP politically ahead of November.</p><p>\"It seems odd for the controlling party in power in both the Senate and White House with an incredibly important, close and contentious election a few months away to be rejecting the idea of an economic policy that's much needed and very popular,\" Cass said.</p><p>Indeed, <a href=\"https://www.ipsos.com/en-us/americans-overwhelmingly-support-continuation-coronavirus-stimulus-and-relief-programs\">an Ipsos poll conducted in late July</a> found strong support across party lines for additional stimulus measures:</p><ul><li>Around 77% of Americans supported additional stimulus checks.</li><li>76% of Americans backed additional unemployment benefits, though no amount was specified.</li><li>Around 82% of Americans approved providing more loans to small businesses.</li></ul><p>Many economists are urging lawmakers to approve more spending to address the economic fallout from the pandemic, which threatens to deepen the pain for nearly 29 million Americans still receiving some form of unemployment benefits.</p><p>\"State and local governments are facing extreme budget distress; food insecurity is at its highest level in decades,\" Jay C. Shambaugh, a former Obama administration economist, <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/09/17/opinion/covid-relief-plan-congress.html\">recently wrote in a New York Times op-ed.</a> \"We've regained only about half the jobs lost in the spring. More money from Congress is both fiscally affordable and deeply needed.\"</p><p>With negotiations bogged down, the White House and congressional Democrats have turned their attention to a stop-gap bill to fund the government past October 1, the end of the fiscal year. Early on, Mnuchin and Pelosi agreed to keep that legislation separate from coronavirus relief.</p><p>Failure to reach an agreement there as well could cause a government shutdown just weeks ahead of the presidential election.</p><p><em><strong>Read more:</strong> <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/stock-market-investing-strategy-advice-election-vaccine-contrarian-ideas-ms-2020-9\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">2 senior PMs at Morgan Stanley's $665 billion investment-management business share their contrarian outlooks on the election, the stock market, and a vaccine — and break down how they are readying portfolios in advance</a></em></p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-stimulus-checks-coronavirus-economy-federal-spending-unemployment-2020-9'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=GwdeRqKHvCg:AgJJ2ozXsBg:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=GwdeRqKHvCg:AgJJ2ozXsBg:F7zBnMyn0Lo\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=GwdeRqKHvCg:AgJJ2ozXsBg:F7zBnMyn0Lo\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=GwdeRqKHvCg:AgJJ2ozXsBg:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=GwdeRqKHvCg:AgJJ2ozXsBg:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=GwdeRqKHvCg:AgJJ2ozXsBg:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=GwdeRqKHvCg:AgJJ2ozXsBg:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=GwdeRqKHvCg:AgJJ2ozXsBg:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/GwdeRqKHvCg\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sun, 20 Sep 2020 12:45:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f35bd91e89ebf001f04479c?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"27acd272140105371dc51e722f269a22","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn43@2020_3/2020/09/20/17-35-49-931_cc2cb8109573486d.webp","destWidth":1843,"destHeight":1382,"sourceBytes":111532,"destBytes":111532,"author":"jzeballos@businessinsider.com (Joseph Zeballos-Roig)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f35bd6fb4bb1c001df53365?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn84@2020_2/2020/09/20/17-35-46-929_50a73fd45e5529c6.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn62@2020_4/2020/09/20/17-35-46-023_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=GwdeRqKHvCg:AgJJ2ozXsBg:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn14@2020_4/2020/09/20/17-35-43-352_bbe4bacfe416b162.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=GwdeRqKHvCg:AgJJ2ozXsBg:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn98@2020_6/2020/09/20/17-35-37-866_8a357bcd76790733.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=GwdeRqKHvCg:AgJJ2ozXsBg:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn38@2020_5/2020/09/20/17-35-44-409_c9c70af64c4cce4f.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/GwdeRqKHvCg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn46@2020_4/2020/09/20/17-35-36-762_4f248bc785e5bc56.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1600623333141},{"createdTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","updatedTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","title":"Doing these 3 things will make you an expert on any topic, according to a Google mentor","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/steps-to-become-expert-in-anything-according-to-google-mentor-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e17747ab2e66a59b828e814?format=jpeg\" alt=\"woman presenting\" height=\"4000\" width=\"6000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The more you learn, the more you&#39;ll discover what you don&#39;t know.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Filadendron/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>It's easy to let imposter syndrome get in the way, but these three steps can help you gain the skills and knowledge to confidently call yourself an expert.&#160;</li>\n<li>David Mitroff, Google mentor and psychology PhD, says it's important to spend at least three years, at a minimum, learning about a topic in depth.&#160;</li>\n<li>Build up the confidence to declare yourself an expert, make sure you have the knowledge to back it up, and don't be afraid to show it.&#160;</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Do you think of yourself as an expert in your industry? You may be more of one than you realize. In an engaging&#160;<a href=\"https://www.ted.com/talks/david_mitroff_when_are_you_good_enough_to_become_an_indsutry_expert\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">TEDx Talk</a>, marketing consultant, Google mentor, and psychology PhD David Mitroff picks apart the question of what it takes to be an expert at something and when you should start saying that you are — because if you don't, no one else will.</p><p>Mitroff began thinking about this after he gave a talk and two old men came up to him and said, \"You're really funny. You should be a standup comic.\"&#160;</p><p>He wasn't so sure, but he looked up the definition of a standup comic, and read that it was someone who interacts with the audience and is dynamic and fun. \"I do that,\" he thought. So he decided to put \"standup comic\" in&#160;his LinkedIn profile. After all, he figured, people who eat ice cream and post about it call themselves food bloggers, so why not?</p><p>The town where he'd met the old men asked him to return and give a second talk. On the basis of&#160;his previous talk and his LinkedIn profile, they promoted this new event calling him a consultant and standup comic. The presentation&#160;went well and the audience laughed. But an old friend of Mitroff's called him up insisting that he couldn't call himself a standup comic because he hadn't performed at places like The Improv. Mitroff pointed out that if you Googled the name of the (small) town where he'd spoken and the term&#160;\"standup comic,\" results one through 10&#160;were about him, on account of the promotion for his talk.</p><p>\"So when are you an expert?\" Mitroff asked. \"Is it when others say you are? Is it when two old guys say you are or your friend says you're not? Is it when you say you are?\"</p><p>We all know the reasons for not calling ourselves an expert. There's imposter syndrome, the feeling&#160;that your accomplishments are the result of luck and that you're in constant danger of being exposed as a fraud. If you believe this, then claiming to be an expert only increases your danger of being called out as a fake.</p><p>More rationally, you may also be concerned about the&#160;<a href=\"https://www.inc.com/jessica-stillman/top-stupidity-researcher-do-these-5-things-to-be-instantly-smarter.html\">Dunning-Kruger effect</a>, a well-known and widespread phenomenon in which people believe themselves to be more expert than they are. \"As you start learning something more and more, you realize you know less and less and less,\" Mitroff said. \"You've got to learn more and more skills about it.\"&#160;</p><p>Mitroff is not suggesting that you should declare yourself an expert on fly-fishing, for instance, after one successful fishing trip. Instead, he says, if you want to become an expert at something, do these three&#160;things:</p><h2>1. Spend three years learning your topic</h2><p>\"After a lot of research, and a lot of time and pain, I believe it takes three years to become an expert,\" he said. (He's leaving aside fields where there's a set certification path, for instance the four years of medical school followed by a residency required to become a physician.)</p><p>\"Now does that mean you just wait three years and then say, 'OK, I'm an expert now'? No, you actually have to do stuff,\" he said. Begin by acquiring knowledge, and then keep on learning. \"The research shows that experts continue to learn and educate themselves more and more and more, and they surround themselves with other people to become even more expert,\" he said. \"You don't just become an expert and stop learning.\"</p><p>Think about the smartest people you know. I'm willing to bet most of them do just this. Or think about some of the smartest and most iconic entrepreneurs, such as&#160;<a href=\"http://www.inc.com/minda-zetlin/warren-buffett-birthday-90-bill-gates-cake-video-friendship.html\">Bill Gates and Warren Buffett</a>. They spend much of their time reading, studying, and talking to other experts to continue expanding their expertise. If, after decades of constant learning, these guys still don't know everything they need to, chances are you won't either.</p><h2>2. Build your confidence</h2><p>Being an expert won't do you much good if you never tell anyone about it. \"You have to believe in yourself,\" Mitroff said. \"You have to believe in your product, or believe in your service. You have to believe in your community, and you have to believe in what you're doing.\"</p><p>If you've followed the first step and put in the time to learn&#160;your topic and practice&#160;your skills, then you've already gone at least some of the way to becoming an expert. Being an expert doesn't mean that you're never wrong, it doesn't mean you know absolutely everything, and it doesn't mean that other experts will always agree with you. It means you've put in the time and work to learn as much about your topic as you can, and that you're continuing to learn more every day.&#160;</p><p>So if you've put in that time and you've learned a lot, own it! Declare yourself an expert. Don't let naysayers like Mitroff's friend get inside your head and shake that confidence.</p><h2>3. Take action</h2><p>Your expertise will be of no use to anyone if all you do is sit around saying what an expert you are. So put your expertise to practical use.</p><p>As a marketing consultant, Mitroff made an astute observation: Most people who are nominated for awards don't win them, but the mere fact of being nominated brings them visibility and prestige. Armed with that knowledge, he began nominating his clients and other people he knew for awards in their fields. \"Why not?\" he said. \"They might accidentally win sometimes, but if they don't win it doesn't matter.\"</p><p>Others began nominating Mitroff for awards in return, and he also began nominating himself. Along the way, he got nominated for an award as a changemaker in the city of Oakland, California, a nomination that made sense because, he says, he's given free presentations to aspiring entrepreneurs and small-business owners at Oakland City Hall more than 60 times.</p><p>Did he win the award? No. But, he says, that nomination may have led directly to his being chosen for the very TEDx Talk he was now giving.</p><p>What about you? What good things do you think might happen to you if you put in the work to become an expert, owned your expertise, and then took action?</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/steps-to-become-expert-in-anything-according-to-google-mentor-2020-9'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=L3MZRWE6aLg:OQfkkaKdH7U:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=L3MZRWE6aLg:OQfkkaKdH7U:F7zBnMyn0Lo\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=L3MZRWE6aLg:OQfkkaKdH7U:F7zBnMyn0Lo\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=L3MZRWE6aLg:OQfkkaKdH7U:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=L3MZRWE6aLg:OQfkkaKdH7U:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=L3MZRWE6aLg:OQfkkaKdH7U:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=L3MZRWE6aLg:OQfkkaKdH7U:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=L3MZRWE6aLg:OQfkkaKdH7U:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/L3MZRWE6aLg\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sun, 20 Sep 2020 13:05:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f650edb323fc4001e0d736f?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"595faeaadae83db93cff3a28d1aea3e2","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn44@2020_1/2020/09/20/17-35-50-592_4a30b4d49dd015e7.webp","destWidth":5333,"destHeight":4000,"sourceBytes":1140656,"destBytes":1140656,"author":"insider@insider.com (Minda Zetlin)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5e17747ab2e66a59b828e814?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn37@2020_2/2020/09/20/17-35-45-928_d46d5eb0472ab7b9.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn62@2020_4/2020/09/20/17-35-46-023_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=L3MZRWE6aLg:OQfkkaKdH7U:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn26@2020_4/2020/09/20/17-35-40-949_2e7f0161000e32ca.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=L3MZRWE6aLg:OQfkkaKdH7U:V_sGLiPBpWU":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=L3MZRWE6aLg:OQfkkaKdH7U:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn30@2020_5/2020/09/20/17-35-38-294_b7a81b6c0f3e7d64.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/L3MZRWE6aLg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn1@2020_1/2020/09/20/17-35-44-321_28999b2bbeea45f5.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1600623333152},{"createdTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","updatedTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","title":"Far-right conspiracy theorists say 94% of US COVID-19 deaths don't count because those Americans had underlying conditions. That's bogus.","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/cdc-coronavirus-death-count-underlying-conditions-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5ec93dc63ad86153866c9b93?format=jpeg\" alt=\"coronavirus patient elderly hospital covid-19\" height=\"1468\" width=\"2300\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Patient Doreen Mount is comforted by a radiologist in the X-ray department at the Royal Blackburn Teaching Hospital in Blackburn, Britain, May 14, 2020.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.reutersconnect.com/all?id=tag%3Areuters.com%2C2020%3Anewsml_RC28QG9YM8GL&#38;share=true\" target=\"_blank\">Hannah McKay/Reuters</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>The CDC's weekly report on US COVID-19 deaths breaks down fatalities by age, sex, race, and comorbidities &#8212; health conditions that increase a person's risk of a severe case.</li>\n<li>Because only 6% of Americans who died of COVID-19 had no preexisting conditions, some people think those are the only people who the virus has truly killed. That's false.</li>\n<li>Even President Trump retweeted, then deleted, once such erroneous statement.&#160;</li>\n<li>Health problems like diabetes and heart disease make COVID-19 more deadly. Those who die with comorbidities were still killed primarily by the virus, though.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Nearly 200,000 Americans have died of COVID-19.&#160;</p><p>The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is working to track and study those deaths in as much detail as possible. Each week, the agency updates a provisional report that compiles coronavirus mortality data based on patients' death certificates.</p><p>The report breaks down US coronavirus deaths by age, sex, race, and location based on information submitted to National Center for Health Statistics. It also includes patients' comorbidities: preexisting health conditions like diabetes or kidney disease that are known to raise a person's risk of a severe infection.</p><p>The August 29 update to <a href=\"https://www.cdc.gov/nchs/nvss/vsrr/covid_weekly/index.htm#Comorbidities\">that report</a> noted that in \"6% of the deaths, COVID-19 was the only cause mentioned,\" meaning no other health conditions were \"mentioned in conjunction with deaths.\"&#160;</p><p>That means only 6% of the 153,504 Americans who'd died by that date had no underlying health conditions.</p><p>But that line was widely misinterpreted — in fact, it set off a conspiracy-theory firestorm.</p><p><a href=\"https://archive.is/mPtBa\">Countless</a> <a href=\"https://archive.is/BifXf\">social media users</a> —&#160;including <a href=\"https://twitter.com/littllemel\">many</a> associated with the far-right, <a href=\"https://www.twitter.com/littllemel/status/1299791452105474057\">&#160;pro-Trump conspiracy-theory group QAnon</a> — suggested the report meant that only 6% of those counted in the US coronavirus death total actually died of the disease.</p><p>President Donald Trump even retweeted one such claim on August 30, <a href=\"https://projects.propublica.org/politwoops/tweet/1300018868669362178\">then deleted it</a> eight hours later. He also mentioned the 6% statistic <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YI_XUG5u3EE&feature=youtu.be&t=948mp;t=948\">in a September 1 interview</a> with Fox News.</p><p><a href=\"https://www.twitter.com/littllemel/status/1299791452105474057\">The tweet</a> Trump reshared, posted by a QAnon supporter, said: \"This week the CDC quietly updated the Covid number to admit that only 6% of all the 153,504 deaths recorded actually died from Covid. That's 9,210 deaths. The other 94% had 2 to 3 other serious illnesses and the overwhelming majority were of very advanced age.\"</p><p>But that's bogus.</p><p>Just because people had, say, heart disease or obesity doesn't mean the virus wasn't their cause of death. If they hadn't gotten COVID-19, those people would probably still be alive.</p><p>The CDC's report simply emphasizes how dangerous COVID-19 is for the many people who already have other health conditions.&#160;</p><p>In the weeks since the report with that line came out, <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/113662872001148/posts/3545342378833163\">Facebook</a>, <a href=\"https://twitter.com/littllemel/status/1299791452105474057\">Twitter</a>, and <a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/p/CEgwJqFhEfU/\">Instagram</a> have flagged posts promoting this 6% idea as false information.</p><h2>Underlying conditions increase the risk of severe coronavirus infections</h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f04cb5d1918245bd33242ec?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Texas coronavirus hospital patient covid 19 death \" height=\"2000\" width=\"3000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Medical staff wearing PPE push a stretcher with a deceased patient to a car outside the COVID-19 intensive-care unit at United Memorial Medical Center in Houston, Texas, on June 30, 2020.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Go Nakamura/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Many <a href=\"https://www.cdc.gov/media/releases/2020/p0625-update-expands-covid-19.html\">preexisting health conditions</a> put coronavirus patients at <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/coronavirus-can-cause-heart-infections-2020-3\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"80\" data-uri=\"a0aae5afe620eb490ca71213bd122a8e\">higher risk of developing severe cases</a>. Overall, patients with underlying conditions were 12 times more likely to die of COVID-19 compared to otherwise healthy patients, according to CDC data collected through May 30. Similarly, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/hypertension-diabetes-conditions-that-make-coronavirus-more-deadly-2020-3#one-third-of-covid-19-patients-who-died-in-italy-had-heart-disease-2\">a March report</a> from Italy's National Institute of Health showed that at the beginning of the pandemic, 99% of COVID-19 patients who died there had at least one preexisting condition.&#160;</p><p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/hypertension-diabetes-conditions-that-make-coronavirus-more-deadly-2020-3\">The CDC has found</a> heart disease, lung disease, and diabetes to be among the most common comorbidities when COVID-19 kills.&#160;</p><p>Indeed, <a href=\"https://academic.oup.com/eurheartj/article/41/22/2058/5851436\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"20\" data-uri=\"b55eb83b70f5e2e932fc669f2b5cb928\">a study from Wuhan, China,</a> showed that people with high blood pressure were twice as likely to die from COVID-19 as patients with normal blood pressure. Studies from <a href=\"https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/32726151/\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"80\" data-uri=\"a3d8f72803c466cfda4e42e74ef8698a\">Columbia University</a>&#160;and&#160;<a href=\"https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/907966/PHE_insight_Excess_weight_and_COVID-19__FINAL.pdf\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"80\" data-uri=\"f137e92820680d80f6317826252da4fd\">Public Health England</a>, meanwhile, found that obese people over 60 are more likely to require ventilation or die if they get COVID-19.</p><p>To think about how COVID-19 and underlying health conditions interact, think of a diabetic person's impaired immune system as a pot of water on a cold stove. If left alone, that pot won't overflow: The person is keeping the stove's flame off by managing their condition with insulin.</p><p>But now say the diabetic person gets the coronavirus — that turns the stove on, since high blood sugar <a href=\"https://www.uofmhealth.org/health-library/uq1148abc\">impairs the immune system's</a> ability to kill invading pathogens. A COVID-19 infection can also cause swelling in the body, which can lead to even higher blood-sugar levels. That in turn further compromises the body's immune response, allowing the infection to worsen.&#160;</p><p>Eventually, the pot might boil over.</p><p>But if this diabetic person hadn't gotten the coronavirus, they most likely would not have died.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f626a43323fc4001e0d6afb?format=jpeg\" alt=\"FILE PHOTO: A general view of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) headquarters in Atlanta, Georgia September 30, 2014.   REUTERS/Tami Chappell/File Photo\" height=\"2333\" width=\"3110\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The CDC headquarters in Atlanta, Georgia.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Tami Chappell/Reuters</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>That's what the CDC's recent COVID-19 mortality report showed. It was not in any way a revision of the agency's death count.</p><h2>Underlying conditions are one reason the coronavirus has hit Black Americans disproportionately hard&#160;</h2><p>The increased risk people with comorbidities face when they get COVID-19 in part explains why <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/black-americans-disproportionately-hospitalized-with-coronavirus-2020-4\">Black Americans</a> are being hospitalized with and dying of the coronavirus in disproportionately high numbers.&#160;</p><p><a href=\"https://www.brookings.edu/blog/up-front/2020/06/16/race-gaps-in-covid-19-deaths-are-even-bigger-than-they-appear/\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"20\" data-uri=\"e72ca7c7c63e455ab0d339b8aa09c9f8\">The CDC</a> estimates that Black Americans between the ages of 35-44 are <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/the-racial-gap-in-coronavirus-deaths-is-driven-by-racism-2020-6\">10 times more likely to die</a> of COVID-19 than their white counterparts. <a href=\"https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/69/wr/mm6915e3.htm?s_cid=mm6915e3_w\">According to data</a> the agency published in April, 33% of the US's hospitalized coronavirus patients were Black, though Black people make up 18% of the overall US population.</p><p>Dr. Anthony Fauci, director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/fauci-covid-19-shows-unacceptable-disparities-for-african-americans-2020-4\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"80\" data-uri=\"40b54f8dfeb04a68c529a19cd2312d60\">has said</a>&#160;the coronavirus has hit Black communities hardest because of the prevalence of \"underlying medical conditions — the diabetes, the hypertension, the obesity, the asthma.\"</p><p>Indeed, Black counties in the US have disproportionately high rates of underlying conditions like diabetes and heart disease, a <a href=\"https://ehe.amfar.org/Assessing%20Differential%20Impacts%20of%20COVID-19%205-3-20_final.pdf\">May report</a> showed. Those counties also experience more air pollution, which is <a href=\"https://www.aaaai.org/conditions-and-treatments/library/asthma-library/air-pollution-asthma\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"100\" data-uri=\"cb706c6ce3e88d26be4e5b7022f436df\">linked to asthma</a>.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f6118c257b7da001ee11cfe?format=jpeg\" alt=\"black lives matter coronavirus\" height=\"3333\" width=\"5000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A young boy wears a mask during a vigil for George Floyd in Pennsylvania on May 31, 2020.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Preston Ehrler/SOPA Images/LightRocket via Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>These higher-than-average rates of underlying health conditions in Black communities are the product of systemic inequality.</p><p><a href=\"https://ehe.amfar.org/inequity?_ga=2.51214761.1618924293.1588715818-1730120696.1588715818\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"eb4b5625f19cd4adf73607d9e7ecdf4f\">One recent study found that</a> \"structural factors including healthcare access, density of households, unemployment, pervasive discrimination, and others,\" are driving COVID-19 disparities — and certainly \"not intrinsic characteristics of Black communities or individual-level factors.\"&#160;</p><p>For instance, many Black, Latinx, and indigenous populations are at a higher risk of contracting COVID-19 simply because they're more likely to have to leave home for work: People of color make up about half of the US's 55.2 million <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/the-racial-gap-in-coronavirus-deaths-is-driven-by-racism-2020-6\">essential workers</a>.</p><p><em>Hilary Brueck and Canela López contributed reporting to this story.</em></p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/cdc-coronavirus-death-count-underlying-conditions-2020-9'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a 01:35:33","updatedTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","title":"Trump said 'there will be no God' if Biden is elected","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/donald-trump-campaign-rally-biden-god-religion-election-north-carolina-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f6750e4323fc4001e0d7507?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Trump-Fayetteville-1\" height=\"3200\" width=\"4800\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>President Trump speaks at a campaign rally in Fayetteville, N.C.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Melissa Sue Gerrits/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>At a campaign rally in Fayetteville, N.C., President Trump said that \"there will be be no God\" if Joe Biden is elected.</li>\n<li>Trump has increasingly used religion as a wedge issue to attack Biden, despite none of the claims being true.</li>\n<li>Biden, a lifelong Catholic, has spoken openly for years about the role faith has played in life, especially during times of enormous tragedy.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>President Trump on Saturday railed against Democratic presidential nominee Joe Biden in his latest series of faith-based attacks at a campaign rally in Fayetteville, North Carolina.</p><p>After reveling in the potential installment of another Supreme Court justice, Trump went on a diatribe against Biden on a range of issues, from energy production to gun rights, before pivoting to religion.</p><p>\"The sleepy campaign has joined forces with those trying to tear down America and our way of life,\" Trump said. \"He comes out with a platform...There will be no oil. There will be no God. There will be no guns.\"</p><iframe width=\"560\" height=\"315\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/u5iue1zOJu0\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen></iframe><p>While visiting Ohio in August, Trump leveled similar attacks against Biden as he sought to tout improving econonic conditions throughout the state.</p><p>\"He's following the radical left agenda, take away your guns, destroy your 2nd Amendment, no religion, no anything, hurt the Bible, hurt God,\" Trump said, <a href=\"https://apnews.com/a3c57cdcf8e44755d15930b29c660e36\">according to</a> the Associated Press. \"He's against God. He's against guns. He's against energy, our kind of energy.\"</p><p>Biden is a lifelong Catholic who has spoken openly for years about the role faith has played in life, most notably during times of enormous tragedy.</p><p>In December 1972, a month after he was elected to the US Senate representing Delaware, his first wife, Neilia, and their infant daughter, Naomi, were killed in a car accident. His sons, Beau and Hunter, were seriously injured in the accident but survived. In 2016, Beau, who rose to become Attorney General of Delaware, died at age 46 from brain cancer.</p><p>In August, the Biden campaign issued a statement in response to Trump's accusations.</p><p>\"Like the words of so many other insecure bullies, President Trump's comments reveal more about him than they do about anyone else,\" Biden said. \"They show us a man willing to stoop to any low for political gain, and someone whose actions are completely at odds with the values and teachings that he professes to believe in.\"</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original Welcome to this weekly roundup of Business Insider stories from executive editor Matt Turner.&#160;</em><strong><a href=\"http://newsletter.businessinsider.com/join/4np/insider-weekly\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"20\" data-uri=\"d9a82e56703288f84894c3fc96ee240e\"><em>Subscribe here to get this newsletter in your inbox every Sunday.</em></a></strong></p><p><em>Read on for news about <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/poll-senate-wait-2020-election-supreme-court-ruth-bader-ginsburg-2020-9\">the death of Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg</a>, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/whatsapp-tracking-apps-online-activity-sleep-interactions-2020-9\">WhatsApp-tracking apps that are letting people figure out when you're sleeping</a>, how home-listing site <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-zumper-weeded-out-people-getting-government-assistance-to-pay-for-apartments\">Zumper weeded out thousands of Section 8 renters</a>, and a <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/inside-yelp-phoneix-insiders-allegations-racism-sexism-drugs-2020-9\">toxic culture in Yelp's Phoenix office</a>.&#160;</em></p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5ede3fb52618b96bfa3f5997?format=jpeg\" alt=\"mark zuckerberg\" height=\"1365\" width=\"2048\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Drew Angerer/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Hello!</p><p>The death of Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg is likely to make intense political polarization in the US even more severe.</p><p>Ginsburg's death opened up a vacancy on the Supreme Court that President Trump said he will fill as quickly as possible. But a new national survey from Insider found <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/poll-senate-wait-2020-election-supreme-court-ruth-bader-ginsburg-2020-9\">that most respondents disagree with the plan to fill the seat as soon as possible</a>. You can get the latest on the response to Ginsburg's death right <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/\">here</a>.</p><hr><p>I started <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-facebook-became-haven-for-misinformation-2020-7\">last week's email</a> by recounting when I first heard about Facebook. My first experience with Whatsapp came later.</p><p>As many of my friends and relatives moved overseas in the 2010s, it became my primary method of communication with many. And now, while I barely ever open Facebook, I'm constantly turning to Whatsapp.&#160;</p><p>Part of the appeal has been its approach to privacy. But as we reported this week, that may not be everything it seems.&#160;</p><p>From Rob Price:</p><p style=\"padding-left: 40px;\"><em>WhatsApp prides itself on its approach to privacy.</em></p><p style=\"padding-left: 40px;\"><em>But the user data that the Facebook-owned messaging app shares publicly is allowing dozens of outside apps to track aspects of WhatsApp users' online activity — including whom they're likely talking to, when they're sleeping, and when they're using their devices.&#160;</em></p><p style=\"padding-left: 40px;\"><em>These apps and services use the \"online\" signaling feature within WhatsApp to enable their users to monitor the digital habits of anyone using WhatsApp without their knowledge or consent, Business Insider has found.</em></p><p style=\"padding-left: 40px;\"><em>These intrusive apps highlight how even services that strongly protect users' privacy in some ways — like WhatsApp's commitment to encryption — can still expose data that can be used to track their users.</em></p><p>Read the story in full here:</p><ul><li><strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/whatsapp-tracking-apps-online-activity-sleep-interactions-2020-9\">WhatsApp-tracking apps are letting people figure out when you're sleeping and who you're talking to on the Facebook-owned app</a></strong></li></ul><p>Related:</p><ul><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/instagram-building-messaging-api-brands-2020-9\">Instagram is building a messaging API to help brands manage their DMs with users</a></li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-instagram-reels-compares-to-tiktok-influencer-brand-deals-2020-9\">Influencers see big differences between Instagram's Reels and TikTok in audience, style, and money-making potential</a><br><section></section></li></ul><hr><h2>How home-listing site Zumper weeded out thousands of Section 8 renters</h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f5a7f61e6ff30001d4e826d?format=jpeg\" alt=\"zumper section 8 discrimination 2x1\" height=\"917\" width=\"1834\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Zumper; Jane Tyska/MediaNews Group/The Mercury News via Getty Images; Samantha Lee/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>From Dan Geiger:</p><p style=\"padding-left: 40px;\"><em>Sharon Whitley was searching for an apartment in Chicago last summer when she stumbled onto the listings site Zumper, a San Francisco startup that has raised $150 million from big-name backers to compete with listings giants such as Zillow and Trulia.</em></p><p style=\"padding-left: 40px;\"><em>A single mother of three, she said she had relied since the mid-1990s on the federal government's Section 8 voucher program, which provides her a $1,000-a-month subsidy toward the cost of her rent. Without the aid, she said, she wouldn't be able to afford an apartment.</em></p><p style=\"padding-left: 40px;\"><em>Whitley said she submitted her information to listings posted on Zumper's site. She said she also remembered filling out a Zumper profile and answering yes when asked whether she relied on a Section 8 voucher.</em></p><p style=\"padding-left: 40px;\"><em>\"I did expect someone to contact me,\" she said. \"I never heard anything.\"</em></p><p style=\"padding-left: 40px;\"><em>At the time, Whitely chalked up her experience to the lack of responsiveness any renter might encounter during a search for a new home.</em></p><p style=\"padding-left: 40px;\"><em>Instead, she may have been the victim of a subtle form of prejudice that has long plagued the real estate industry. For decades, many landlords and brokers alike have passed over Section 8 renters based on untrue stereotypes and stigmas attached to government-subsidized tenants, some experts say.</em></p><p>Read the story in full here:</p><ul><li><strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-zumper-weeded-out-people-getting-government-assistance-to-pay-for-apartments\">Zumper, a home-listing site that has raised $150 million from backers like Blackstone and Kleiner Perkins, weeded out thousands of Section 8 renters in a practice some experts say may amount to discrimination</a></strong></li></ul><p>Related:</p><ul><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/opendoor-net-income-revenue-going-public-spac-merger-chamath-palihapitiya-2020-9\">SoftBank-backed Opendoor lost $339 million in 2019. Here's how it's pitching a path to profits as it gears up to go public via a SPAC.</a></li></ul><section></section><hr><h2>A toxic culture in Yelp's Phoenix office</h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f47ecf0db1ed00029714519?format=jpeg\" alt=\"yelp company culture racism sexism clique 2x1\" height=\"1000\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Yelp; Samantha Lee/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>From Rob Price:</p><p style=\"padding-left: 40px;\"><em>Some people of color at Yelp's Phoenix office said they experienced racism from hostile customers, as well as their own colleagues. They witnessed racist language, including nicknames and the n-word, as well as memes that mocked non-white clients.</em></p><p style=\"padding-left: 40px;\"><em>Sexism, they say, occurred too, both from customers and colleagues. \"You can only be called a c--t so many times before it wears on your soul,\" one said.</em></p><p style=\"padding-left: 40px;\"><em>Business Insider spoke to nine current or former employees of the buzzy internet firm about the culture in its Phoenix office.</em></p><p style=\"padding-left: 40px;\"><em>These sources said they experienced a hard-partying and sometimes-exclusionary atmosphere, with some claiming there was drug use in the office and that employees engaged in a sexual act at a Christmas party.</em></p><p>You can read the full story here:</p><ul><li><strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/inside-yelp-phoneix-insiders-allegations-racism-sexism-drugs-2020-9\">At Yelp's Phoenix office, some insiders say a 'boy's club' atmosphere fueled racism, sexism, and a hard-partying culture — on top of regular verbal abuse from customers</a></strong></li></ul><hr><h2>ICYMI: Fauci says we'll likely be wearing masks for most of 2021</h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5ec65099f0f41913b1151bd5?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Fauci\" height=\"1500\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>President Donald Trump is flanked by Dr. Anthony Fauci, director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases while speaking about coronavirus vaccine development in the Rose Garden of the White House on May 15, 2020 in Washington, DC.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Drew Angerer/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Hillary Brueck talked to Dr. Anthony Fauci this week. One takeaway: Just getting vaccinated is not going to be enough to end this pandemic.&#160;</p><p>\"I said a combination of an effective vaccine&#160;<em>and</em>&#160;adherence to certain public-health principles will get us to the point where we want to be, by the end of 2021,\" Fauci said during a lunchtime call over pizza on Wednesday. \"I never said just the vaccine. You never should abandon the public-health measures.\"</p><p>You can read the full story here:</p><ul><li><strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/fauci-the-vaccine-will-not-be-enough-to-stop-coronavirus-2020-9\">Fauci: We'll likely be wearing masks for most of 2021, even after a vaccine rolls out</a></strong></li></ul><p>Here are some headlines from the past week you might have missed.&#160;</p><p>— Matt</p><hr><section><p><a service called 'AWS Thor' that can predict when machines will break down</a></p></section><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a Turner)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5ede3fb52618b96bfa3f5997?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn52@2020_2/2020/09/20/17-35-46-840_191a69ab8176f8a0.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f5a7f61e6ff30001d4e826d?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn83@2020_2/2020/09/20/17-35-36-965_aa3a8568f28e466f.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f47ecf0db1ed00029714519?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn40@2020_1/2020/09/20/17-35-40-358_c93d380308b2b2e9.webp","https://i.insider.com/5ec65099f0f41913b1151bd5?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn95@2020_3/2020/09/20/17-35-49-393_57bb217b0994a0f4.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn62@2020_4/2020/09/20/17-35-46-023_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=ox_8vnu6YWA:kTxMe79Asxw:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn58@2020_3/2020/09/20/17-35-38-171_5ed73fa643b852bb.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=ox_8vnu6YWA:kTxMe79Asxw:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn55@2020_1/2020/09/20/17-35-46-861_921e6bc12970c949.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=ox_8vnu6YWA:kTxMe79Asxw:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn92@2020_5/2020/09/20/17-35-41-318_228bddb4cd080ee3.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/ox_8vnu6YWA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn69@2020_1/2020/09/20/17-35-38-365_32eaf3a38a854717.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1600623333140},{"createdTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","updatedTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","title":"I've been using Apple's new iOS 14 for a few days and while there's useful updates to Messages, the App Library is disappointing","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/apple-ios-14-messages-and-app-library-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5ef4c0a5f0f41969522a28a2?format=jpeg\" alt=\"iOS 14 (homescreen)\" height=\"1597\" width=\"2129\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Apple</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Apple held its annual hardware event virtually on September 15 and released iOS 14 the next day.</li>\n<li>The update had added changes to the home screen, Messages, Siri, and more.</li>\n<li>Messages updates are already proving useful, but the App Library feels more like a band-aid than anything helpful or new.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Apple just released&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/apple-ios-14-features-tips-tricks-one-week-update-2020-7\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"075c27804df574378240cb49d83075f7\">iOS 14</a>, with some major updates like home screen widgets and Siri, along with <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ios-14-new-apple-iphone-features-2020-6\">dozens</a> of more minor adjustments. The <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/apple-ios-14-beta-release-date-arrives-how-to-get-2020-7\">beta version</a> was released back in July, so many have had a few months to get acquainted with the new software. Some updates, like changing the <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/apple-ios-14-bug-resets-default-browser-2020-9\">default browser</a> and email app, have been anticipated by iPhone owners for years.&#160;</p><p>Every year with the new version of iOS, some of the coolest features debuted at WWDC end up being mostly inconsequential, at least to me, while other minor ones make daily tasks easier. After only a few days, I'm already a fan of changes Messages, while the new App Library didn't seem like anything special.&#160;</p>\n<div id=\"slideshow\">\n\tThe many small new features in Messages add up to one of the most useful updates in iOS14 for me, because it's probably the app I use the most throughout the day.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f64d67b323fc4001e0d71c2?format=jpeg\" alt=\"iOS 14 Messages\" height=\"979\" width=\"1305\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Apple</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tPinning conversations is a minor change, but it's also super helpful to easily reach the people and group chats I return to the most.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f64d70657b7da001ee1275f?format=jpeg\" alt=\"iOS 14 Messages\" height=\"1858\" width=\"2478\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>iOS 14 Messages.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Mary Meisenzahl</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tPinning a conversation puts it at the top of the Messages app. For me, making the photo larger rather than the text makes it easy to quickly find my important conversations.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f64d75357b7da001ee12761?format=jpeg\" alt=\"iOS 14 Messages\" height=\"1478\" width=\"1971\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>iOS 14 Messages.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Mary Meisenzahl</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tMessages got some other common sense updates, like tagging people in a group message, and threading messages.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f64dd5c57b7da001ee12789?format=jpeg\" alt=\"iOS 14 Messages\" height=\"1857\" width=\"2476\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>iOS 14 Messages.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Mary Meisenzahl</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tTo start a thread, just hold down on a message and the \"reply\" option will pop up.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f64dd0557b7da001ee12784?format=jpeg\" alt=\"iOS 14 Messages\" height=\"1880\" width=\"2507\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>iOS 14 Messages.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Mary Meisenzahl</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tThen you can view just the thread, which can be helpful in a fast moving group chat.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f64dda257b7da001ee1278a?format=jpeg\" alt=\"iOS 14 Messages\" height=\"1842\" width=\"2457\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>iOS 14 Messages.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Mary Meisenzahl</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tThreading and tagging people seems so obvious, I have to wonder why Apple did not implement them earlier, like many other messaging apps have. Still, I'm glad they're here, and they make handling the multiple group chats I use to stay in touch with friends and family that much easier.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f64ddc0323fc4001e0d71f5?format=jpeg\" alt=\"iOS 14 Messages\" height=\"1837\" width=\"2450\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>iOS 14 Messages.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Mary Meisenzahl</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tThe ability to search the emoji library is, again, very simple, but it makes life just a little bit easier.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f64ec9f323fc4001e0d725e?format=jpeg\" alt=\"iOS 14 Messages\" height=\"1164\" width=\"1552\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>iOS 14 Messages.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Mary Meisenzahl</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tBetween emoji search and the QuickPath swipe keyboard introduced in iOS 13, I can finally stop using the custom Google keyboard and stick to the built-in Apple one.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f64ecaf57b7da001ee127e7?format=jpeg\" alt=\"iOS 14 Messages\" height=\"1278\" width=\"1704\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>iOS 14 Messages.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Mary Meisenzahl</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tOne tiny update I predict will be super useful is a notification about what was pasted into Messages or any other text field. Who among us hasn't accidentally sent the wrong link?\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f64e07957b7da001ee127a3?format=jpeg\" alt=\"iOS 14 Messages.\" height=\"1528\" width=\"2038\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>iOS 14 Messages.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Mary Meisenzahl</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tSo far I'm less impressed with the App Library, which automatically organizes apps into categories when you swipe left past all the other screens.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f64e31e323fc4001e0d722b?format=jpeg\" alt=\"appLibrary1\" height=\"1828\" width=\"2438\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>App Library.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Mary Meisenzahl</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tTo me, the categorizations don't make very much sense, and they aren't nearly as useful as the organizational system I've already created for myself where I can access, for example, all my social media or music and audio in one spot.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f64e381323fc4001e0d722f?format=jpeg\" alt=\"appLibrary3\" height=\"1585\" width=\"2114\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>App Library.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Mary Meisenzahl</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tThe \"other\" categorization also makes me wonder how well these apps are really categorized. Maybe it will prove to be useful later, but for now, the App Library just seems like a way to hide away the disorganized, non-customizable mess of apps.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f64e3bf323fc4001e0d7230?format=jpeg\" alt=\"appLibrary2\" height=\"1778\" width=\"2371\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>App Library.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Mary Meisenzahl</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n</div><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a /09/20/17-35-46-089_4ff181e83f19a4bd.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f64e3bf323fc4001e0d7230?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn31@2020_1/2020/09/20/17-35-40-151_275bf836eee618bc.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn62@2020_4/2020/09/20/17-35-46-023_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=aGYHJ125sXA:4oCM-T1hxsU:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn32@2020_5/2020/09/20/17-35-49-656_b8c7f58d729df1ed.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=aGYHJ125sXA:4oCM-T1hxsU:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn42@2020_5/2020/09/20/17-35-39-142_d1dc87897443e3c1.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=aGYHJ125sXA:4oCM-T1hxsU:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn78@2020_2/2020/09/20/17-35-35-904_c2c2c10db6fd813d.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/aGYHJ125sXA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn49@2020_4/2020/09/20/17-35-41-106_5ce22229c21b8af1.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1600623333156},{"createdTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","updatedTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","title":"White House bars FDA commissioner from testifying before House committee","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/white-house-bars-fda-commissioner-from-testifying-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f676f4357b7da001ee12a82?format=jpeg\" alt=\"AP20236798154000\" height=\"1665\" width=\"2221\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>President Donald Trump listens as Dr. Stephen Hahn, commissioner of the U.S. Food and Drug Administration, speaks during a media briefing in the James Brady Briefing Room of the White House, Sunday, Aug. 23, 2020, in Washington.\n<p class=\"copyright\">AP Photo/Alex Brandon</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>The White House blocked FDA Commissioner Dr. Stephen Hahn from testifying before the Energy and Commerce Committee, a <a href=\"https://www.politico.com/news/2020/09/18/white-house-blocked-fda-hahn-417831\">White House spokesperson confirmed to Politico.&#160;</a></li>\n<li>Democratic Rep. Frank Pallone, Jr. and Democratic Rep. Anna G. Eshoo <a href=\"https://energycommerce.house.gov/newsroom/press-releases/pallone-eshoo-statement-on-white-house-blocking-fda-from-testifying\">raised concerns</a> over the White House's decision to block Hahn from testifying \"despite bipartisan interest.\"&#160;</li>\n<li>The Trump administration's politicization of public health, including a reported delay of a CDC report because it <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-officials-sought-alter-cdc-reports-covid-leaked-emails-politico-2020-9\">conflicted with the president's political stance</a>.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>The White House blocked FDA Commissioner Dr. Stephen Hahn from testifying before the Energy and Commerce Committee, <a href=\"https://www.politico.com/news/2020/09/18/white-house-blocked-fda-hahn-417831\">Politico reported.</a></p><p>Energy and Commerce Committee Chairman Democratic Rep. Frank Pallone, Jr. and Health Subcommittee Chairwoman Democratic Rep. Anna G. Eshoo <a href=\"https://energycommerce.house.gov/newsroom/press-releases/pallone-eshoo-statement-on-white-house-blocking-fda-from-testifying\">said in a statement Friday </a>that \"despite bipartisan interest and our request for Commissioner Hahn to appear before the Energy and Commerce Committee this month, the White House has blocked Dr. Hahn from testifying.\"</p><p>The lawmakers noted the committee's \"concerns about the Trump Administration's ongoing political interference into the COVID-19 response efforts of our public health agencies,\" and stressed that \"the American people deserve to hear\" from Hahn to \"ensure that the agency's COVID-19 decisions remain science-based.\"</p><p>Meanwhile, the FDA has recently ousted two Trump appointees at the agency.</p><p>In early September, John Wagner, who was appointed by the Trump administration to lead the FDA's office of external affairs <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/second-trump-appointee-out-at-fda-over-credibility-concerns-2020-9\">was replaced</a> with Hedii Rebello, who <a href=\"https://www.fda.gov/about-fda/fda-organization/heidi-rebello\">spent over 14 years at the FDA.&#160;</a> This replacement came days after Hahn fired the Trump appointed FDA spokesperson Emily Miller days after she started the job. Miller was <a href=\"https://www.cnn.com/2020/08/28/politics/emily-miller-food-and-drug-administration/index.html\">reportedly involved</a> with preparing for the FDA's announcement to issue an emergency authorization for convalescent plasma, which was met with swift backlash from medical experts, for which <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/fda-commissioner-says-he-overstated-effects-of-virus-therapy-2020-8\">Hahn apologized.&#160;</a>&#160;</p><p>A White House spokesperson confirmed to Politico that Hahn was barred from testifying so that <br>\"health officials can keep their time and energy focused on responding to the coronavirus.\"</p><p>Earlier this month, it was reported that Michael Caputo, the head spokesperson for the Department of Health and Human Services, and his scientific advisor, Dr. Paul Alexadnder, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-officials-sought-alter-cdc-reports-covid-leaked-emails-politico-2020-9\">may have successfully delayed CDC reports</a> that conflicted with the president's political viewpoints, <a href=\"https://www.politico.com/news/2020/09/11/exclusive-trump-officials-interfered-with-cdc-reports-on-covid-19-412809\">according to Politico.</a> Caputo<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/michael-caputo-hhs-trump-loyalist-ukraine-roger-stone-2020-4\">, a longtime Republican political strategist</a> before being appointed as HHS spokesman in April, is <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/hhs-spokesperson-michael-caputo-medical-leave-facebook-conspiracy-rant-2020-9\">currently taking medical leave.&#160;</a></p><ul class=\"read-more-links\"><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-officials-sought-alter-cdc-reports-covid-leaked-emails-politico-2020-9\" data-read-more-link=\"\" Choi)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f676f4357b7da001ee12a82?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn25@2020_6/2020/09/20/17-35-47-348_b6a45877318c1c5a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn62@2020_4/2020/09/20/17-35-46-023_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=FfEaeP44_3w:LFQNhIS5O38:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn17@2020_5/2020/09/20/17-35-39-336_0f79c3644bc8fc34.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=FfEaeP44_3w:LFQNhIS5O38:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn12@2020_3/2020/09/20/17-35-49-468_208c35ba8097a53d.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=FfEaeP44_3w:LFQNhIS5O38:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn8@2020_1/2020/09/20/17-35-41-503_0c3b4ff16657b9c8.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/FfEaeP44_3w":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn62@2020_4/2020/09/20/17-35-39-187_4c3ebe7453fdc9de.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1600623333155},{"createdTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","updatedTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","title":"Engagement with anti-vaxx Facebook pages more than trebled from July to August, analysis shows","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/engagement-anti-vaxx-facebook-pages-triples-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5ec8dc665af6cc386612bf44?format=jpeg\" alt=\"anti vaccine protest coronavirus\" height=\"1000\" width=\"1333\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A protester holds an anti-vaccination sign as supporters of President Donald Trump rally to reopen California as the coronavirus pandemic continues to worsen, on May 16, 2020 in Woodland Hills, California.\n<p class=\"copyright\">David McNew/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Analysis done by The Guardian newspaper showed Facebook user engagement with anti-vaccination content more than trebled from July to August.</li>\n<li>The analysis was based on monitoring six popular pages which posted anti-vaccine messages.</li>\n<li>In response Facebook said The Guardian's analysis was not reflective of the platform as a whole, and said it took down 7 million pieces of misinformation related to COVID-19 between April and June.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Analysis done by <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/media/2020/sep/19/engagement-anti-vaccine-facebook-posts-trebles-one-month-coronavirus\">The Guardian</a> newspaper suggests interest in anti-vaccination content on Facebook is soaring.</p><p>The investigation, using analytics tool CrowdTangle, focused on six UK-based Facebook pages, which the paper identified as being popular promoters of anti-vaccine content.</p><p>From July to August, interactions with anti-vaccine posts from those six pages increased more than three-fold, from 12,000 to 42,000.</p><p>The pages in question included an alternative medicine site with 1.9 million likes, and a page protesting lockdown measures in the UK with 30,000 likes, and a fan page for British conspiracy theorist David Icke with 22,000 likes.</p><p>The UK is <a href=\"https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-54212654\">currently experiencing a second wave of coronavirus infections</a>. An August poll found <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/coronavirus-poll-says-third-of-brits-would-definitely-get-vaccine-2020-8\">just 30% of Britons said they would definitely get a coronavirus vaccine</a> once it became available, with some experts blaming anti-vaccine misinformation and a lack of trust in the government for this low figure.</p><p>When contacted by the Guardian, a Facebook spokesperson said its analysis did not reflect the platform.</p><p>\"This analysis only considers a small sample size and is not representative of our work in this space. Facebook does not allow harmful misinformation on our platforms and we have removed 7m pieces of Covid-19-related misinfo between April and June, as well as posts shared with us by the Guardian that violated our policies,\" they said.</p><p>Facebook has been struggling with how to deal with content associated with the so-called \"anti-vaxx\" movement for years. It announced it was <a href=\"https://www.wired.com./story/facebook-anti-vaccine-crack-down/\">cracking down on the content in March 2019</a>, banning any anti-vaccine ads and demoting it in search results.</p><p>During the coronavirus pandemic, Facebook has started placing fact-checking cards on anti-vaccine content. The move&#160;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/anti-vax-group-sues-facebook-over-fact-checking-labels-2020-8\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">prompted a lawsuit from an anti-vaccination group</a>&#160;led by Robert F. Kennedy Jr.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/engagement-anti-vaxx-facebook-pages-triples-2020-9'>Business Insider</a></div><div (Isobel Asher Hamilton)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5ec8dc665af6cc386612bf44?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn26@2020_2/2020/09/20/17-35-43-402_d8ec8825edd9fa61.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn62@2020_4/2020/09/20/17-35-46-023_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=4bFrvcypIAE:oHzQI-Cnjcg:F7zBnMyn0Lo":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=4bFrvcypIAE:oHzQI-Cnjcg:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn56@2020_5/2020/09/20/17-35-36-870_b787e9c957089f34.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=4bFrvcypIAE:oHzQI-Cnjcg:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn73@2020_5/2020/09/20/17-35-44-853_86fb1cac288166bf.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/4bFrvcypIAE":null},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1600623333137},{"createdTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","updatedTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","title":"Officials identify a woman suspect after letter laced with deadly ricin poison sent to President Trump","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/ricin-poison-letter-sent-to-trump-woman-is-the-suspect-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f670993323fc4001e0d74fc?format=jpeg\" alt=\"white house exterior\" height=\"1350\" width=\"1800\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The White House is pictured in 2018.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.gettyimages.com/detail/news-photo/north-facade-of-the-white-house-by-james-hoban-washington-news-photo/1096028272?adppopup=true\" target=\"_blank\">DEA/M. BORCHI/Getty</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>An envelope addressed to the White House that contained the deadly poison ricin was intercepted by US authorities on Saturday, according to a report by the New York Times.</li>\n<li>The letter was addressed to President Donald Trump and appears to have been sent from Canada.</li>\n<li>Officials have identified a woman as a suspect, but have given no further details about the incident.&#160;</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>An envelope posted to the White House containing the lethal substance ricin was intercepted by US authorities on Saturday.</p><p>The letter addressed to President Donald Trump appears to have been sent from Canada, and officials have identified a woman as a suspect, according to a report by the <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/09/19/us/politics/ricin-white-house-postal-service.html\">New York Times.</a></p><p>It was stopped at the final off-site government mail center before it arrived at the White House.</p><p>\"The FBI and our US Secret Service and US Postal Inspection Service partners are investigating a suspicious letter received at a US government mail facility,\" the FBI said in a statement, according to Times. \"At this time, there is no known threat to public safety.\"</p><p>Similar envelopes were sent to law enforcement agencies in Texas, including a detention facility and a sheriff's office.</p><p>The Joint Terrorism Task Force in Washington is taking charge of the investigation with help from New York and the Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP).</p><p>No links have been found between the poisonous letter and any international terrorist organizations, investigators&#160; said. They declined to elaborate on what evidence they had that pointed them to the female suspect.</p><p>However, officials have said that the investigation is still in its early stages, and nothing has yet been ruled out.&#160;</p><p>Ricin is a powerful toxin produced in the seeds of the castor oil plant. The seed is so potent that a dose of purified ricin powder the size of a few grains of table salt can kill a human within three to five days.</p><p>This is not the first time there have been such attacks.</p><p>A Navy veteran was charged for attempting to send envelopes with ricin to multiple US officials in 2018. William Clyde Allen's case is still pending because officials found he had sent castor beans instead of ricin powder.</p><p>Former President Barack Obama was also the target of a ricin attack.</p><p>In 2013, actor Shannon Richardson was sentenced to 18 years in federal prison for mailing letter laced with ricin to Obama and Michael Bloomberg, then the mayor of New York.</p><p>Read more:</p><ul class=\"read-more-links\"><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/white-house-facts-rooms-2018-2?r=US&IR=TIR=T\" data-read-more-link=\"\" data-e2e-name=\"read-more-link\">15 rooms in the White House you probably never knew existed, from a chocolate shop to a private bowling alley</a></li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/coronavirus-adviser-is-pushing-white-house-to-adopt-herd-immunity-2020-8?r=US&IR=TIR=T\" data-read-more-link=\"\" data-e2e-name=\"read-more-link\">A top White House coronavirus adviser is reportedly pushing the Trump administration to adopt a controversial 'herd immunity' strategy</a></li><li><a voters say that 'it really matters' who wins the election — but half expect difficulties to vote, according to new survey</a></li><li><a 3 years after Trump tossed paper towels to survivors of Hurricane Maria</a><br><section></section></li></ul><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a
