border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/p2rs3Y0UVh8\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sun, 20 Sep 2020 09:40:31 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f6709bd57b7da001ee12a5e?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"8178f58ba82f46ce8a09a3819dce7bc7","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn63@2020_3/2020/09/20/17-35-50-719_d9d6423a3fe370bb.webp","destWidth":1800,"destHeight":1350,"sourceBytes":120882,"destBytes":120882,"author":"sankel@businessinsider.com (Sophia Ankel)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f670993323fc4001e0d74fc?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn37@2020_2/2020/09/20/17-35-47-413_ab5baa5f9f8d1fbb.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn62@2020_4/2020/09/20/17-35-46-023_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=p2rs3Y0UVh8:70BODBZ6jzo:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn12@2020_5/2020/09/20/17-35-47-305_b89e0e31eba9a294.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=p2rs3Y0UVh8:70BODBZ6jzo:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn42@2020_2/2020/09/20/17-35-44-440_575857cb7f875ed4.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=p2rs3Y0UVh8:70BODBZ6jzo:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn27@2020_2/2020/09/20/17-35-40-171_3eaa37c90aca827b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/p2rs3Y0UVh8":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn26@2020_6/2020/09/20/17-35-36-830_89bb7c477c1b779f.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1600623333155},{"createdTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","updatedTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","title":"Some unemployed Americans will soon receive an extra $300 per week as states roll out bonus relief benefits from FEMA","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/300-weekly-unemployment-benefits-bonus-fema-payments-state-status-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5ea31d604bca637d213b0a9a?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Stimulus Checks\" height=\"717\" width=\"1024\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Economic stimulus checks are prepared for printing at the Philadelphia Financial Center May 8, 2008 in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Jeff Fusco/Stringer</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>After the weekly federal supplemental unemployment benefits lapsed in July, President Trump allotted $44 billion in additional funds for FEMA to provide to states for unemployment relief.</li>\n<li>Every state besides South Dakota received funds, and at least 21 have at least begun processing the payments, according to CNBC.</li>\n<li>Some states have not sent out checks to qualifying individuals, while some states that were approved earlier have already finished distributing payments.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>&#160;</p><p>In order to help those who were laid off due to the pandemic, Congress earlier this year sent out weekly $600 bonus unemployment checks. At the end of July, those benefits lapsed, and a month and a half later, Congress has yet to pass another package.</p><p>But on August 8, President Trump allocated $44 billion to FEMA to provide grants to states in order to bridge the gap between the original stimulus package and the next one— whenever that may be, if it happens at all.</p><p>The Lost Wages Supplemental Payment Assistance Grant allowed states to decide on their own if they needed the money and apply it accordingly. The deadline for the grant was September 10, and now states are figuring out how to distribute the money, and in many cases have already sent it out.</p><p>The $300 weekly unemployment bonus payments you may have heard about recently are a part of this rollout, but their distribution status at a state level varies.</p><p>Every state except South Dakota applied for the FEMA grant. Guam and the US Virgin Islands will also be receiving funds as well.&#160;</p><p>CNBC reports <a href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2020/09/10/-19-states-start-paying-the-extra-300-weekly-unemployment-benefit.html\">21 states have either finished paying out the $300 payments or have begun sending them out.</a> Those include, in alphabetical order, according to CNBC: Alabama, Arizona, Arkansas, California, Florida, Idaho, Iowa, Louisiana, Maryland, Massachusetts, Michigan, Minnesota, Missouri, Montana, New Hampshire, New Mexico, North Carolina, Rhode Island, Tennessee, Texas and Utah.</p><p>It is also worth noting that the FEMA grants differ from the <a href=\"https://www.dol.gov/newsroom/releases/eta/eta20200405\">Pandemic Unemployment Assistance (PUA)</a> program, which covers those who are not covered by unemployment benefits, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/personal-finance/pandemic-assistance-unemployment-benefits-overpayment-multiple-states-2020-6\">including independent contractors and part-time workers.</a></p><p>The $300 per week benefit payments supplement a state's current unemployment payouts — meaning they'll be applied in addition to whatever unemployment benefit the state is already paying those who lost their job. In order to be eligible for the FEMA grant funds, a household must already be receiving $100 in unemployment benefits. This means about 6% of households will be ineligible for this new plan, <a href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2020/09/15/these-people-wont-get-trumps-300-unemployment-benefit.html\">according to CNBC</a>.</p><p>John Pallasch, assistant secretary for the US Department of Labor, said this barrier was enacted so the funds would go to those who had lost their primary source of income, according to CNBC.</p><p>Some states are still processing the payments. For the states that have not yet processed them, the benefits will be applied retroactively for the weeks of August 1, 8, and 15.&#160;</p><p>Kentucky is the only state giving out a minimum of $400 a week, ($300 from FEMA and $100 in state funds.) Montana did as well, but recently ran out of funds, <a href=\"http://dli.mt.gov/news/218\">according to the Montana Department of Labor and Industry.</a></p><p><a href=\"https://des.az.gov/sites/default/files/media/newsrelease-9-11-2020-Arizona-Distributes-Nearly-800-Million-in-Lost-Wages-Assistance.pdf\">According to the Arizona Department of Economic Security</a>, Arizona has already paid out all the grant money, which lasted for a total of six weeks.&#160;Louisiana has also concluded payments as well, <a href=\"http://www.laworks.net/PublicRelations/PR_PressReleaseDetails.asp?SeqNo=2534&Year=2020&Month=9;Month=9\">as reported by Louisiana Workforce Commission.</a></p><p>Like the $600 weekly federal unemployment bonus payments, the states' weekly $300 supplemental payments aren't indefinite, either — the maximum number of weekly payments is six, and that includes any retroactive August payments.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/300-weekly-unemployment-benefits-bonus-fema-payments-state-status-2020-9'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=IoKO1pS-Jg4:OAnAxUYPkiQ:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=IoKO1pS-Jg4:OAnAxUYPkiQ:F7zBnMyn0Lo\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=IoKO1pS-Jg4:OAnAxUYPkiQ:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=IoKO1pS-Jg4:OAnAxUYPkiQ:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=IoKO1pS-Jg4:OAnAxUYPkiQ:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=IoKO1pS-Jg4:OAnAxUYPkiQ:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/IoKO1pS-Jg4\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sun, 20 Sep 2020 13:30:45 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f60e93b323fc4001e0d6488?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"efd3f382f5679f393aa7a3f7acb3f369","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn84@2020_6/2020/09/20/17-35-49-991_0c597e5d7ee8602b.webp","destWidth":956,"destHeight":717,"sourceBytes":31962,"destBytes":31962,"author":"bsmith@businessinsider.com (Barbara Smith)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5ea31d604bca637d213b0a9a?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn81@2020_4/2020/09/20/17-35-41-182_fed7299f783eeb84.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn62@2020_4/2020/09/20/17-35-46-023_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=IoKO1pS-Jg4:OAnAxUYPkiQ:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn90@2020_5/2020/09/20/17-35-35-830_5d8db08e5069479e.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=IoKO1pS-Jg4:OAnAxUYPkiQ:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn88@2020_6/2020/09/20/17-35-46-160_8670d64809067c93.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=IoKO1pS-Jg4:OAnAxUYPkiQ:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn65@2020_1/2020/09/20/17-35-42-259_41a771dfb8fba6cf.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/IoKO1pS-Jg4":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn64@2020_1/2020/09/20/17-35-35-648_d3870dbdfca38a13.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1600623333161},{"createdTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","updatedTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","title":"The Marine Corps' changes to its rifle qualification course will likely mean fewer expert shooters","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/marine-corps-rifle-course-changes-likely-mean-fewer-expert-shooters-2020-9","description":"<figure> \n <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f651aa1323fc4001e0d73d5?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Marine Corps rifle rifleman marksman\" height=\"1249\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\"> \n  <figcaption>\n   Marines shoot targets during a new experimental annual rifle qualification (ARQ) at Marine Corps Base Camp Lejeune in North Carolina, September 2, 2020. \n   <p class=\"copyright\">US Marine Corps/Lance Cpl. Christian Ayers</p> \n  </figcaption> </img>\n</figure>\n<ul class=\"summary-list\"> \n <li>The Marine Corps'&nbsp;new Annual Rifle Qualification will replace Annual Rifle Training with a more challenging course of fire that presents Marines with a more dynamic environment.</li> \n <li>The Corps expects to see fewer Marines shoot expert next year when the service fully transitions to the more realistic, combat-focused rifle qualification course.</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li> \n</ul>\n<p>The <a href=\"http://www.military.com/marine-corps\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Marine Corps</a> expects to see fewer Marines shoot expert next year when the service fully transitions to a more realistic, combat-focused rifle qualification course.</p>\n<p>The new <a href=\"https://www.military.com/daily-news/2019/12/13/marines-overhaul-rifle-qualification-feature-moving-targets-night-fire.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Annual Rifle Qualification (ARQ)</a> will replace Annual Rifle Training (ART) with a challenging new course of fire that forces Marines to apply basic marksmanship skills in a more dynamic environment, which will include moving targets and night shooting scenarios.</p>\n<p>The Marine Corps marksmanship community, recognizing the need to focus on lethality instead of standard marksmanship, drafted the new ARQ course of fire in October 2018 at the annual Combat Marksmanship Symposium.</p>\n<p>\"It's more combat-style and combat-situation shooting,\" Chief Warrant Officer 4 Eric Brown, Weapons Training Battalion gunner at Marine Corps Installations East-Marine Corps Base <a href=\"http://www.military.com/base-guide/marine-corps-base-camp-lejeune\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Camp Lejeune</a>, North Carolina, said in a news release.</p>\n<p>\"There was an assessment done, and we realized that the current method of rifle training and rifle qualification was not adequate to meet what the needs were on the battlefield for lethality from the Marine,\" he added.</p>\n<figure> \n <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f651ab5323fc4001e0d73d7?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Marine Corps rifle rifleman marksman\" height=\"1666\" width=\"2222\" charset=\"\"> \n  <figcaption>\n   Marines use artificial support during a new experimental annual rifle qualification (ARQ) at Marine Corps Base Camp Lejeune in North Carolina, Sept. 2, 2020. \n   <p class=\"copyright\">US Marine Corps/Lance Cpl. Christian Ayers</p> \n  </figcaption> </img>\n</figure>\n<p>The current ART qualification course, which was created in 1907, has Marines engage targets at ranges of 200, 300 and 500 yards from the sitting, kneeling, standing and prone positions. There is also a portion that focuses on short-range engagements within 25 yards.</p>\n<p>Marines at Lejeune recently got the chance to test the ARQ course of fire, which is expected to be in use across the Corps by 2021.</p>\n<p>During the new course of fire, shooters will wear combat gear, including ballistic helmet and body armor, while shooting their assigned weapon, whether it be an <a href=\"http://www.military.com/equipment/m4-carbine\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">M4</a> carbine, M16 rifle or the M27 infantry automatic rifle. Starting at the 500-yard line, Marines work their way forward to the 15-yard line, shooting at the same target the entire course of fire.</p>\n<p>Marines will now shoot an exposed enemy target marked with lethal zones for the head and chest, instead of the standard \"able\" or \"dog\" targets.</p>\n<p>\"There have been quite a few significant … changes. The sitting position is no longer used in the rifle qualification course of fire,\" Brown said in the release. \"The prohibition of artificial supported positions has been removed, and the shooter can use artificial support throughout. They can use barricades, bipods, magazines or even a backpack.\"</p>\n<p>During firing, Marines will no longer mark the target after each shot; instead, the shooter will fire all rounds in the time allotted. The longest firing period is 45 seconds at the 500-yard line for five shots; the shortest is three seconds to perform a headshot from the 25-yard line.</p>\n<figure> \n <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f651ac157b7da001ee12932?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Marine Corps rifle rifleman marksman\" height=\"1666\" width=\"2222\" charset=\"\"> \n  <figcaption>\n   A Marine uses artificial support in the kneeling position during a new experimental annual rifle qualification (ARQ) at Marine Corps Base Camp Lejeune in North Carolina, September 2, 2020. \n   <p class=\"copyright\">US Marine Corps/Lance Cpl. Christian Ayers</p> \n  </figcaption> </img>\n</figure>\n<p>Qualification badges will remain the same, but Marine Corps officials are <a href=\"https://www.military.com/daily-news/2019/12/15/new-scoring-standards-coming-marine-rifle-marksmanship-badges.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">still determining the new scoring system</a>, according to the release.</p>\n<p>Under the current qualification standards, Marines fire 50 rounds, worth five points each, depending on shot placement on targets. They must earn at least 190 points for the marksman badge; at least 210 for sharpshooter; and a minimum of 220 to earn expert.</p>\n<p>For the new ARC system, each shot will be scored as \"destroy,\" \"neutralize,\" \"suppress\" or \"miss,\" with \"destroy\" being the only shot counting for points, the release states.</p>\n<p>Brown expects that the changes under ARQ will result in a significant decrease in the number of Marines who qualify as expert, compared to <a href=\"https://www.military.com/daily-news/2019/12/15/new-scoring-standards-coming-marine-rifle-marksmanship-badges.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">2019, when 65% of Marines scored expert</a> under the ART system.</p>\n<p>\"I think they have made the range harder,\" Brown said. \"We have seen the effect that the environment, with the heat and the length of time they are exposed in the elements, has had on the Marines.\"</p>\n<p><em>— Matthew Cox can be reached at </em><em><a href=\"mailto:matthew.cox@military.com\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">matthew.cox@military.com</a></em><em>.</em></p>\n<div class=\"read-original\">\n Read the original article on \n <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/marine-corps-rifle-course-changes-likely-mean-fewer-expert-shooters-2020-9\">Business Insider</a>\n</div>\n<div class=\"feedflare\"> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=JqFZolda8Fg:M9Ssw5skExM:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=JqFZolda8Fg:M9Ssw5skExM:F7zBnMyn0Lo\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=JqFZolda8Fg:M9Ssw5skExM:F7zBnMyn0Lo\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=JqFZolda8Fg:M9Ssw5skExM:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=JqFZolda8Fg:M9Ssw5skExM:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=JqFZolda8Fg:M9Ssw5skExM:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=JqFZolda8Fg:M9Ssw5skExM:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=JqFZolda8Fg:M9Ssw5skExM:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\" /></a> \n</div>\n<img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/JqFZolda8Fg\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\" />","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sun, 20 Sep 2020 14:00:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f651ac157b7da001ee12932?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"770639d7f84c793cb3059171e93d6b6f","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn12@2020_1/2020/09/20/17-35-33-503_2e2b00d31550c040.webp","destWidth":2222,"destHeight":1666,"sourceBytes":481354,"destBytes":481354,"author":"insider@insider.com (Matthew Cox)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f651aa1323fc4001e0d73d5?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn14@2020_3/2020/09/20/17-35-35-727_415218b29933cdbc.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f651ab5323fc4001e0d73d7?format=jpeg":null,"https://i.insider.com/5f651ac157b7da001ee12932?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn12@2020_1/2020/09/20/17-35-33-503_2e2b00d31550c040.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn62@2020_4/2020/09/20/17-35-46-023_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=JqFZolda8Fg:M9Ssw5skExM:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn66@2020_5/2020/09/20/17-35-44-586_f85db817c6ac477d.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=JqFZolda8Fg:M9Ssw5skExM:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn44@2020_2/2020/09/20/17-35-48-906_b7fc843b7273c880.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=JqFZolda8Fg:M9Ssw5skExM:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn51@2020_2/2020/09/20/17-35-40-254_0a88d70aaf66ad49.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/JqFZolda8Fg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn75@2020_1/2020/09/20/17-35-46-877_0d498f89988ebe14.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1600623333158},{"createdTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","updatedTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","title":"New types of polar lights are upending what we know about the aurora. Amateur scientists and interns made the latest discoveries.","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/new-types-of-aurora-upending-understanding-of-polar-lights-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f61263557b7da001ee11d67?format=jpeg\" alt=\"reuters environmental photos of the year 2019\" height=\"2000\" width=\"2666\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The Aurora Borealis (Northern Lights) in the sky in Ivalo, Lapland, Finland September 27, 2019.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Alexander Kuznetsov/Reuters</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Scientists, amateur aurora-hunters, and a NASA intern have discovered fascinating new types of <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/photo-shows-comet-neowise-steve-aurora-and-meteor-2020-7\">aurora</a> in recent years.</li>\n<li>One new type of <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/aurora-chasers-filmed-new-aurora-the-dunes-2020-1\">aurora</a> revealed curls in Earth's upper atmosphere, and another pointed to a strange <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/new-aurora-borealis-crunch-earth-magnetic-field-2019-12\">magnetic crunch</a> in space.</li>\n<li>New observations of Jupiter's aurorae have also raised questions about the nature of these lights.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>The colorful lights that dance across polar skies create beautiful displays, but they also reveal mysteries about how planets, space, and the sun interact.</p><p>Though humans have been observing the aurora for centuries, scientists are still learning about how it works. Just this year, amateur aurora-hunters discovered a new type of aurora that could come from space particles heating Earth's upper atmosphere. A NASA intern also revealed a new type of twisting aurora, which led scientists to a mysterious crunch in Earth's magnetic field.&#160;</p><p>The lights at Earth's poles continue to surprise researchers, and other planets' aurorae offer hints at how their atmospheres and magnetic fields behave, too.</p><p>Here's what researchers have learned about the aurora over the last few years.</p>\n<div id=\"slideshow\">\n\tIn January, amateur aurora chasers revealed a new type of aurora that stretches across the sky like fingers. They called it \"the dunes.\"\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e33142524306a4a4e479454?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Aurora dunes discovery skitch\" height=\"1365\" width=\"1820\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Auroral dunes photographed on October 7, 2018 near Ruovesi, Finland.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://news.agu.org/press-release/citizen-scientists-discover-new-type-of-aurora-named-the-dunes-video-available/\" target=\"_blank\">Rami Valonen</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>Unlike regular aurorae, which spread down vertically from main ribbons of light, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/aurora-chasers-filmed-new-aurora-the-dunes-2020-1\">the dunes</a>' patterns stretch horizontally.</p>\n\tScientists think the dunes could be a visible manifestation of atmospheric waves: undulations of air responding to regions of different temperatures or densities in the atmosphere.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e331dbb62fa8165e62c3f08?format=jpeg\" alt=\"auroral dunes discovery\" height=\"1075\" width=\"1077\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Auroral dunes photographed on October 7, 2018 near Laitila, Finland (top) and Ruovesi, Finland (bottom). The two photographs were taken simultaneously. The dunes are marked by magenta circles and numbers.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://news.agu.org/press-release/citizen-scientists-discover-new-type-of-aurora-named-the-dunes-video-available/\" target=\"_blank\">AGU Advances/Palmroth et al.</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>\"For the first time, we can actually observe atmospheric waves through the aurora &#8211; this is something that hasn't been done before,\" Minna Palmroth, a physicist and lead author of a <a href=\"https://agupubs.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/journal/2576604x\">study</a> on auroral dunes, said in a <a href=\"https://news.agu.org/press-release/citizen-scientists-discover-new-type-of-aurora-named-the-dunes-video-available/\">press release</a>.</p>\n\tBased on video that the amateurs recorded, Palmroth thinks the dunes happen when electrical currents from space heat Earth's upper atmosphere.\n\t\n\t<iframe width=\"560\" height=\"315\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/OMgsOyIuebc\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen></iframe><p>That's because the dunes seemed to appear when charged particles from space transferred energy into the upper atmosphere. That heat could create a type of atmospheric wave that makes horizontal curls and folds in the air, which then spread across the sky.</p>\n\t\"Different auroral forms are like fingerprints,\" Palmroth said.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5ed7098d988ee353a8208169?format=jpeg\" alt=\"aurora southern lights earth atmosphere international space station iss\" height=\"518\" width=\"800\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The Aurora Australis, or southern lights, as seen from the International Space Station, on June 25, 2017.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ArHwh3xkEa8\" target=\"_blank\">NASA</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>\"If you see a certain auroral form, you know basically from that form what's happening further out in space.\"</p>\n\tA few other discoveries in recent years have also upended how scientists understand the northern and southern lights.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5c191d82404f4d64640753e4?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Aurora Borealis\" height=\"1500\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The Aurora Borealis (Northern Lights) in the sky near Rovaniemi in Lapland, Finland, October 7, 2018.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Alexander Kuznetsov/Reuters</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>Near the North Pole, the atmospheric phenomenon that produces those lights is called the aurora borealis. Near the South Pole, it's called the aurora australis.</p>\n\tMembers of a group called the Alberta Aurora Chasers made one such discovery in 2016, when they spotted a strange purple arc in the sky.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5aaa917f3be59f01148b462d?format=jpeg\" alt=\"aurora steve\" height=\"0\" width=\"0\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>STEVE (Strong Thermal Emission Velocity Enhancement) and the Milky Way at Childs Lake, Manitoba, Canada\n<p class=\"copyright\">Krista Trinder/ NASA Goddard Space Flight Center</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>They dubbed the mysterious new streak of light \"Steve,\" which later came to stand for the Strong Thermal Emission Velocity Enhancement (STEVE).</p>\n\tTo figure out what this new phenomenon was, aurora researcher Eric Donovan tracked a satellite as it flew through a STEVE.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f611d56323fc4001e0d66da?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Swarm satellite aurora\" height=\"1500\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>An artist&#39;s rendition of the European Space Agency&#39;s Swarm satellites.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.esa.int/Applications/Observing_the_Earth/Swarm/Getting_to_know_Steve\" target=\"_blank\">ESA/AOES Medialab</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>\"In 1997 we had just one all-sky imager in North America to observe the aurora borealis from the ground,\" Donovan said in a <a href=\"http://www.esa.int/Applications/Observing_the_Earth/Swarm/When_Swarm_met_Steve\">press release</a> from the European Space Agency, which built the satellite he used. \"Back then we would be lucky if we got one photograph a night of the aurora taken from the ground that coincides with an observation from a satellite.\"</p>\n\tThe processes that create an aurora on Earth start at the sun, thanks to a constant stream of electrically charged particles called solar wind.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e0276d1855cc269bf783863?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Solar Wind\" height=\"360\" width=\"640\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>An animation of the solar wind shows particles streaming from the sun towards Earth.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://svs.gsfc.nasa.gov/13502\" target=\"_blank\">NASA</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>Events on the sun send out floods of the ions and electrons that make up solar wind. These charged particles travel almost at the speed of light.</p>\n\tWhen these particles reach Earth, our planet's magnetic field funnels some of them to the poles, where they interact with our atmosphere to make the aurora.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f611c3d323fc4001e0d66d1?format=jpeg\" alt=\"earth magnetic field solar wind aurora poles charged particles\" height=\"337\" width=\"600\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Earth&#39;s magnetic field channels charged particles from the sun towards the poles.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.esa.int/ESA_Multimedia/Images/2018/03/Carrying_particles\" target=\"_blank\">NASA Goddard&#39;s Conceptual Image Lab/K. Kim</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>Solar particles interacting with oxygen produce green and red light, while nitrogen glows blue and purple.</p>\n\tSteve does not appear to come from these charged particles, however, which means it's technically not an aurora.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e0286f2e94e867790013ced?format=jpeg\" alt=\"aurora borealis iss\" height=\"1536\" width=\"2048\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The aurora borealis over Canada is sighted from the space station, September 15, 2017.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://eol.jsc.nasa.gov/SearchPhotos/photo.pl?mission=ISS053&#38;roll=E&#38;frame=23915\" target=\"_blank\">NASA/JSC</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>Rather, Donovan's satellite data suggested that STEVE came from a high-altitude ribbon of very hot gases burning at almost 5,500 degrees Fahrenheit (3,000 degrees Celsius).</p><p>\"It turns out that STEVE is actually remarkably common, but we hadn't noticed it before,\" Donovan said.</p>\n\tMost true aurorae come at times of heightened solar activity, when big events like explosions on the sun flood Earth with charged particles.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/563b9a4f9dd7cc16008c797a?format=jpeg\" alt=\"solar flare\" height=\"626\" width=\"1089\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>An artist&#39;s concept shows a solar flare exploding on the sun and sending plasma into space.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GSVv40M2aks\" target=\"_blank\">NASA Goddard</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>Big explosions and electric storms on the sun can also cut off electronic communications, confuse GPS, push satellites out of orbit, endanger astronauts, or even wipe out power grids.&#160;</p><p>Two such solar storms cut off emergency radio communications for a total of 11 hours following Hurricane Irma in 2017.</p>\n\tBut last year, NASA intern Jennifer Briggs discovered an aurora that didn't coincide with any extra activity from the sun.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e0132fb855cc21915084db4?format=jpeg\" alt=\"aurora borealis\" height=\"720\" width=\"722\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>All-sky cameras in Longyearbyen, Norway, near the Arctic Circle captured these images of an unusual, spiraling aurora.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.nasa.gov/feature/goddard/2019/postcards-from-the-edge-of-space-scientists-present-new-ionosphere-images-and-science\" target=\"_blank\">Fred Sigernes/Kjell Henriksen Observatory, Longyearbyen, Norway/Joy Ng</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>Briggs <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/new-aurora-borealis-crunch-earth-magnetic-field-2019-12\">spotted the twisting aurora</a> in the above footage from an island in Norway. Her team checked the records and found no unusual solar activity at that time.</p><p>\"This eastward and then westward and then spiraling motion is not something that we've ever seen, not something we currently understand,\" she said in a <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UzoZHxT5k5A&#38;t=4s\">press conference</a> in December.</p>\n\tScientists connected the twisting northern lights to a huge compression in Earth's magnetic field, making it the first aurora of its kind.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e026fda855cc263d9596f69?format=jpeg\" alt=\"magnetosphere compression\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>This animation shows the compression in the magnetosphere that rushed past a NASA satellite (pictured in blue) and caused the twisting aurora.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://svs.gsfc.nasa.gov/13502\" target=\"_blank\">Jennifer Briggs</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>\"You can imagine someone punching Earth's magnetic field,\" Briggs said. \"There was a massive but localized compression.\"</p><p>Scientists think the mysterious compression may have come from a storm at the edges of the magnetic field. They don't know exactly what that might look like or where it could have come from.</p>\n\tOther planets have their own aurora, often through the same processes as Earth's.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e506713fee23d160a681c83?format=jpeg\" alt=\"aurora planets\" height=\"732\" width=\"662\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Ultraviolet footage shows aurorae on Earth, Jupiter, and Saturn. Stars appear in the background of Earth&#39;s footage.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://twitter.com/physicsj/status/1230466890297794560?s=12\" target=\"_blank\">NASA/ESA/John Clarke/Jonny Nichols/James O&#39;Donoghue</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>Unlike Earth, planets Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, and Neptune have atmospheres mostly composed of hydrogen. So their aurorae are visible in ultraviolet light.</p>\n\tSome of Jupiter's aurora comes from its moon, Io, which has large volcanoes that spew sulfur dioxide into space.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e5468d1fee23d106f5a57c3?format=jpeg\" alt=\"jupiter aurora\" height=\"1668\" width=\"2224\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A composite of two observations from NASA&#39;s Hubble Space Telescope show Jupiter&#39;s aurora.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.nasa.gov/feature/goddard/2016/hubble-captures-vivid-auroras-in-jupiter-s-atmosphere\" target=\"_blank\">NASA/ESA/J. Nichols (University of Leicester)</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>Jupiter's magnetic field also rips material off of Io regularly and funnels it towards the planet's poles, where the particles make the aurora.</p><p>The charged particles that make Jupiters' aurora interact with its atmosphere to produce powerful X-rays.</p>\n\tIn 2017, researchers revealed a mystery in Jupiter's' aurorae: Its northern and southern lights aren't fluctuating together.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f612f2657b7da001ee11dab?format=jpeg\" alt=\"jupiter aurora mystery\" height=\"1374\" width=\"3000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>X-ray aurorae behave differently on Jupiter&#39;s north and south poles.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/chandra/solar-storms-ignite-xray-northern-lights-on-jupiter.html\" target=\"_blank\">X-ray: NASA/CXC/UCL/W.Dunn et al, Optical: NASA/STScI</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>On Earth, the aurora borealis and aurora australis generally brighten and dim together, since Earth's magnetic field is distributing solar particles to both of them.</p><p>But observations of Jupiter during solar storms show the aurorae on its northern and southern poles acting independently of each other. Nobody knows why.</p>\n</div><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a 01:35:33","updatedTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","title":"Trump gloated over an MSNBC anchor being shot by a rubber bullet at an anti-racism protest, calling it a 'beautiful sight'","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-mocks-msnbc-anchor-shot-rubber-bullet-a-beautiful-sight-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f671733323fc4001e0d74fe?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Trump Minnesota\" height=\"1000\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>President Donald J. Trump speaks during a campaign event at Bemidji Aviation on Friday, Sept 18, 2020 in Bemidji, MN.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Jabin Botsford/The Washington Post via Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>President Donald Trump at a Minnesota rally mocked MSNBC's Ali Velshi for being shot by police with a rubber bullet at anti-racism protests in May.&#160;</li>\n<li>\"Wasn't it really a beautiful sight? It's called law and order,\" Trump told cheering supporters.</li>\n<li>In a statement, MSNBC said the president \"endangers thousands of other journalists and undermines our freedoms.\"</li>\n<li>During his presidency, Trump has repeatedly attacked the press and encouraged violent tactics used by police against anti-racism demonstrators and rioters.&#160;</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>President Donald Trump at a campaign rally in Minnesota Saturday gloated over MSNBC anchor Ali Velshi being hit by a rubber bullet fired by police at a recent anti-racism protest.</p><p>The president spoke to supporters about the anti-racism protests that swept America over the summer, and the occasionally violent and indiscriminate police tactics used to suppress them that Trump has endorsed.&#160;</p><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" data-cards=\"\" data-conversation=\"\">&#8212;David Gura  (@davidgura) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/mims/statuses/1307318498205425665?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">September 19, 2020</a></blockquote><script async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script><p>&#160;</p><p>During the speech, Trump recalled an incident during anti-racism protests in Minneapolis in May in which police fired at MSNBC's Velshi and his camera crew were fired on by law enforcement.&#160;</p><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" data-cards=\"\" data-conversation=\"\">&#8212;Ali Velshi  (@AliVelshi) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/mims/statuses/1307352860246540288?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">September 19, 2020</a></blockquote><script async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script><p>&#160;</p><p>\"I remember this guy Velshi,\" Trump said. \"He got hit in the knee with a canister of tear gas, and he went down. He was down. 'My knee, my knee.' Nobody cared, these guys didn't care, they moved him aside.\"</p><p>And they just walked right through. It was the most beautiful thing,\" Trump said. \"No, because after we take all that crap for weeks and weeks, and you finally see men get up there and go right through them, wasn't it really a beautiful sight? It's called law and order.\"</p><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" data-cards=\"\" data-conversation=\"\">&#8212;MSNBC Public Relations  (@MSNBCPR) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/mims/statuses/1307416224675115020?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">September 19, 2020</a></blockquote><script async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script><p>&#160;</p><p>In a statement, MSNBC responded to Trump's taunt, accusing him of encouraging violence towards the press.&#160;</p><p>\"Freedom of the press is a pillar of our democracy. When the President mocks a journalist for the injury he sustained while putting himself in harm's way to inform the public, he endangers thousands of other journalists and undermines our freedoms.\"</p><p>In a tweet, Velshi corrected the president. He noted that he was hit by a rubber bullet and not a gas canister, and that police had used unprovoked violence against a peaceful demonstration.</p><p>\"So, <a href=\"https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump\" data-focusable=\"true\">@realDonaldTrump</a>, you call my getting hit by authorities in Minneapolis on 5/30/20 (by a rubber bullet, btw, not a tear gas cannister) a \"beautiful thing\" called \"law and order\". What law did I break while covering an entirely peaceful (yes, entirely peaceful) march?\" he tweeted.&#160;</p><p>A Trump campaign spokesperson said the president had been not been referring to Velshi in that section of the speech, and went on to attack the press.&#160;</p><p>\"Anybody who was watching knows the President was calling the restoration of peace 'a beautiful thing.' This was first distorted by CNN, which described arson-plagued riots as 'fiery but mostly peaceful,' so misrepresenting what people can see for themselves is par for the course,\" said the spokesperson.&#160;</p><p>Velshi's injury was one of a series of incidents over the summer where reporters covering the anti-racism protests were targetted by police. <a href=\"https://www.niemanlab.org/2020/06/well-try-to-help-you-follow-the-police-attacks-on-journalists-across-the-country/\">The Neiman Lab</a>recording 140 attacks by police on journalists in the initial weeks of the demonstrations.</p><p>Trump has repeatedly insulted and attacked the press during his term as president. A top UN official said in July that the president's \"onslaught\" on the media had damaged press freedom globally, <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/media/2020/jul/13/press-freedom-trump-effect-un-special-rapporteur\">reported Reuters.</a></p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a 01:35:33","updatedTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","title":"If you're a new grad with minimal work experience, here's how to get references for job interviews","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-new-grads-can-get-references-for-job-interviews-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e174495b2e66a32473dd5b5?format=jpeg\" alt=\"man interivewing\" height=\"4000\" width=\"6000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>As a new grad, you&#39;ll need to find references who can vouch for your work ethic, teamwork, and other transferable skills.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Pawita Warasiri/EyeEm/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>For many new grads, it's extremely difficult to find references for a job interview when you've had little to no past work experience.</li>\n<li>Luckily, most recruiters aren't looking for entry-level candidates with extensive industry experience. Find anyone who's interacted with you professionally and can vouch for your work ethic and other transferable skills.</li>\n<li>When you ask them to be a reference, be upfront and include a job description or a few bullets of accomplishments you'd like to highlight. Send thank-you notes at every step to show your appreciation.&#160;</li>\n<li>Additionally, it's good to have a few written references you can pull up when necessary.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>New college graduates, picture this: You're going on job interviews for the first time, which you pass with flying colors, only to get tripped up at the end when the interviewer&#160;<a href=\"https://www.monster.com/career-advice/article/professional-references-without-experience-0717\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">asks for a few references</a>. Where are you — a student who might not have ever had a \"real\" job before — supposed to get references from? Will a prospective employer really want to hear from the manager at the sandwich shop you worked at during the summers, your biology professor, or your swim coach? The answer may surprise you.&#160;</p><h2><strong>What do employers really want to know?</strong></h2><p>Most hiring managers and recruiters know from your resume (and from common sense) that their college grad applicants aren't going to come to the table with extensive industry experience. However, professional references are still a useful tool for them because it can shed light on who you are as a person and responsible job seeker.</p><p>\"From the professional evaluation stance of a recruiter, it's more about whether you have references and can get them quickly,\" said Mike Ruggiero, senior recruiter at Lionbridge Technologies. \"They're really looking for people who can offer insight beyond, 'I gave Molly a task and Molly completed it,'\" he said. In other words, think about who in your life can vouch for your <a href=\"https://www.monster.com/career-advice/article/work-ethic\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">work ethic</a>, your&#160;<a href=\"https://www.monster.com/career-advice/article/problem-solving\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">problem-solving skills</a>, and your team mentality — not just that you can do a job, but that you are a standout in all that you do.</p><p>\"Employers want to know that someone coming off their degree isn't just about skills,\" Ruggiero added.</p><p>Hiring managers will be most impressed if you have a&#160;<a href=\"https://www.monster.com/career-advice/article/prepare-your-references\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">list of references</a>&#160;ready to go as it will show that you came prepared.&#160;</p><h2><strong>Who should you ask to act as your reference?</strong></h2><p>A reference can really be anyone that can&#160;<a href=\"http://www.monster.com/career-advice/article/what-employers-want-from-job-references-hot-jobs\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">speak about your abilities and performance</a>. \"It can be a boss during your summer job, a coach, a professor. But it should be someone that has a professional type of experience with you,\" said Wes Perry, SVP and chief talent officer at Leader Bank, N.A.</p><p>In other words,&#160;<a href=\"https://www.monster.com/career-advice/article/Whats-Wrong-with-Personal-Reference\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">you don't want to ask Uncle Dave</a> or your next door neighbor to give you a reference. \"I've seen that happen a lot, and it shows that you don't get it,\" said Perry.</p><p>To figure out who the best references are for a particular position, simply ask your recruiter what types of references they want, suggests Ruggiero. \"Ask your recruiting team, how can I get you the best information?\" For example, if they want someone who can discuss your ability to be a work on a team, who better than a team coach or activity adviser?</p><p>\"Recruiters love sports players because they have to be&#160;<a href=\"https://www.monster.com/career-advice/article/5-ways-to-be-a-good-team-player-hot-jobs\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">part of a team</a>, be dedicated, and stay focused on training,\" said Ruggiero. If you're not an athlete, that's fine — you could be the chair of your math club, or the director of your drama group. \"Those types of references can be valuable if they can speak to how you have shown teamwork, professionalism, and the ability to meet deadlines,\" he said.</p><p>Again, it's expected that the entry-level grad might not have that many professional references, said Perry, but do the best you can to explain why you chose the references that you did. Something like: \"I'm giving you this professor because they can talk about a research project that we worked on and how I contributed.\"</p><p>Most important is making sure that the references you provide will speak highly of you. \"Sometimes a reference might say, 'I'm surprised this person picked me,'\" said Perry, and that can be a kiss of death. That's why you want to make sure to vet your potential references beforehand. \"They're going to either say they would or wouldn't be a good reference with you — most will be upfront,\" said Perry.</p><h2><strong>How should you ask for a reference?</strong></h2><p>If you're&#160;<a href=\"https://www.monster.com/career-advice/article/ask-letter-recommendation\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">asking someone to take the time to say something good about you</a>, you want to make sure that they first of all remember you, and that they know a little something about the position you're seeking. You might ask via email, phone, or in person, depending on your current relationship with the person. An old professor would work best over email, whereas a current boss at your part-time job would be just fine in person.</p><p>Be upfront about what you need from your reference, and be humble. You can say something like: \"I'm applying to a very exciting position, and was hoping you had five minutes to chat about potentially being a reference for me since you're highly respected in the industry.\" This approach offers them a compliment and is respectful of their time, said Ruggiero.</p><p>Speaking of time, don't get frustrated and give up if you don't hear back from someone immediately, said Perry. \"People are busy, so it's OK to give a little nudge,\" he said. Once you do hear back, provide them with the job description, and share a few bullet points reminding them about your accomplishments, especially if it's been a while since you worked with the person.</p><p>And don't forget: Send along thank-you notes every step of the process, said Ruggiero. \"You want to show that you always appreciate people so they'll know they're not just being used,\" he said.</p><h2><strong>What about written references?</strong></h2><p>The majority of employers will want to speak to references so they can ask specific questions, but it doesn't hurt to have a couple of letters in your back pocket, said Ruggiero.</p><p>This is especially helpful if you have a great experience with a professor who&#160;you know is retiring, or you can ask your supervisor at the end of an internship just in case they move on before you start your job search.</p><p>\"I've done that where I had a VP who I knew was retiring, so I asked if they would mind writing a letter of reference for me,\" said Perry. Students can do the same. Say:&#160;<em>\"I'm going to graduate next year, but I was wondering if you wouldn't mind writing a letter of reference on university letterhead.\"</em></p><p>\"It's always good to be able to say, 'I do have several written letters that I can provide immediately, and I can provide you contact information as well,'\" said Ruggiero. It shows that you had the foresight to be prepared, and are handling your job search in a very professional way.</p><p>Could you use more information on how to have a successful first-time job search?&#160;<a href=\"https://member.monster.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Join Monster for free today</a>. As a member, you can upload up to five versions of your resume — each tailored to the types of jobs that interest you. Recruiters search Monster every day looking to fill top jobs with qualified candidates, just like you. Additionally, you can get job alerts sent directly to your inbox to cut down on time spent looking through ads. Those are just two quick and easy ways Monster can help you start off on a career path to success.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a 01:35:33","updatedTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","title":"Volkswagen has unveiled its Caddy California camper van with a bed and kitchen — see inside","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/volkswagen-caddy-california-camper-van-that-can-sleep-4-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f58ea35e6ff30001d4e7b7e?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Volkswagen Caddy California\" height=\"1666\" width=\"2222\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The Volkswagen Caddy California on a camping trip.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://vwpress.co.uk/en-gb/releases/4313\" target=\"_blank\">Volkswagen</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Volkswagen has unveiled the Caddy California, a daily driver camper van that can sleep up to four people.</li>\n<li>This new release is the fifth iteration in the Caddy family and third camper in the California camper line.</li>\n<li>The Caddy California has a modular set up with an interior folding bed, pull-out rear kitchen box, and tent.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/category/volkswagen\">Volkswagen</a> has unveiled the new <a href=\"https://vwpress.co.uk/en-gb/releases/4313\">Caddy California</a>, a modular camper van with a a bed, kitchen, and tent.</p><p>The German automaker has long been a player in the camper van industry. The new Caddy California is the fifth iteration in the Caddy family and the third California camper model in the line that already includes the <a href=\"https://vwpress.co.uk/en-gb/releases/4072\">Grand California</a> and <a href=\"https://vwpress.co.uk/en-gb/releases/3894\">T6.1 California</a>.</p><p>But unlike the other two California models, the Caddy-based motor home was built to be a \"compact camper,\" according to its maker.</p><p>Volkswagen isn't the only mainstream automaker to have a stake in the <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/camper-van-conversion-companies-resilience-in-sales-despite-the-coronavirus-2020-5\">increasingly popular tiny homes on wheels business</a>. For example, Ford has its own <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/meet-nugget-tiny-home-built-inside-of-fords-transit-van-2019-10\">Nugget</a> and <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ford-transit-big-nugget-tiny-home-campervan-2019-10\">Big Nugget</a>: two campers built inside of a <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/leisure-travel-vans-wonder-rear-lounge-rv-2020-ford-transit-2020-6\">Ford Transit cargo van</a>. And most recently, Jeep reiterated its role in the tiny homes on wheels segment by <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/jeep-farout-overlander-camper-on-the-2021-gladiator-ecodiesel-2020-8\">unveiling a concept 2021 Gladiator pickup truck</a> with a rooftop tent and overlanding RV amenities.</p><p>Despite carrying the name of a US state, the California will only be available in the EU.</p><p>Keep scrolling to see inside the Caddy California:</p>\n<div id=\"slideshow\">\n\tThe 14.77-foot long iteration of the Caddy California will be officially launched in Europe by the end of 2020, although a long-wheelbase version at 15.92 is set to be unveiled next year.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f59421f7ed0ee001e25e5c7?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Volkswagen Caddy California\" height=\"1666\" width=\"2222\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The Volkswagen Caddy California.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://vwpress.co.uk/en-gb/releases/4313\" target=\"_blank\">Volkswagen</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tAccording to Volkswagen, the new Caddy California uses a modular setup to fit the bed, storage units, and kitchen.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f594227e6ff30001d4e7e2f?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Volkswagen Caddy California\" height=\"1666\" width=\"2222\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The Volkswagen Caddy California on a camping trip.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a to the beds found in the Grand California and T6.1 California, according to Volkswagen.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f59423b7ed0ee001e25e5c9?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Volkswagen Caddy California\" height=\"1666\" width=\"2223\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The Volkswagen Caddy California&#39;s interior.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://vwpress.co.uk/en-gb/releases/4313\" interior.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://vwpress.co.uk/en-gb/releases/4313\" target=\"_blank\">Volkswagen</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tWhen the bed — which can sleep two people — isn't in use, it can be folded into a third of its size and stored above the trunk space.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f5942477ed0ee001e25e5ca?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Volkswagen Caddy California\" height=\"1666\" width=\"2222\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The Volkswagen Caddy California&#39;s interior.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://vwpress.co.uk/en-gb/releases/4313\" target=\"_blank\">Volkswagen</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tBecause the sleeping space folds out and stands on its own legs, the passenger row of seats can be removed for more cargo storage space.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f594251e6ff30001d4e7e32?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Volkswagen Caddy California\" height=\"1875\" or at a campsite, the Caddy California comes equipped with an optional two-part kitchen that extends out the back of the vehicle.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img kitchen.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://vwpress.co.uk/en-gb/releases/4313\" target=\"_blank\">Volkswagen</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tThe top half of the kitchen unit has a gas cooktop with a shelf and wind block, while the bottom has storage for cutlery and utensils.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f59425de6ff30001d4e7e33?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Volkswagen Caddy California\" height=\"1666\" width=\"2222\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The Volkswagen Caddy California&#39;s kitchen.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a that supplies the cooktop.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f5942637ed0ee001e25e5cc?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Volkswagen Caddy California\" height=\"1666\" width=\"2222\" cooking.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f594271e6ff30001d4e7e35?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Volkswagen Caddy California\" height=\"1775\" width=\"2367\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The camper.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f58e9c7e6ff30001d4e7b73?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Volkswagen Caddy California\" height=\"1667\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The Volkswagen Caddy California&#39;s interior.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://vwpress.co.uk/en-gb/releases/4313\" target=\"_blank\">Volkswagen</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tThe camper's rear side windows come with storage bags — which doubles as curtains — that can hold up to 11.02 pounds.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f594282e6ff30001d4e7e36?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Volkswagen Caddy California\" height=\"1220\" width=\"1626\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The Volkswagen Caddy California on a camping trip.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a be blocked by using magnetic curtains.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f5942887ed0ee001e25e5d0?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Volkswagen Caddy California\" height=\"1249\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The Volkswagen Caddy California on a camping trip.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://vwpress.co.uk/en-gb/releases/4313\" LED lights.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f59428e7ed0ee001e25e5d1?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Volkswagen Caddy California\" height=\"1665\" width=\"2220\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The Volkswagen Caddy California.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://vwpress.co.uk/en-gb/releases/4313\" target=\"_blank\">Volkswagen</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tMoving on from the windows, the driver and passenger doors have fly screens to help ventilate the interior without letting bugs in.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f5942967ed0ee001e25e5d2?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Volkswagen Caddy California\" height=\"1877\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The Volkswagen Caddy California.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://vwpress.co.uk/en-gb/releases/4313\" target=\"_blank\">Volkswagen</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tThe camper also comes with two chairs and a table, all of which can be tucked away in its designated bag and stored underneath the bed.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f5942a0e6ff30001d4e7e38?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Volkswagen Caddy California\" height=\"1249\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The Volkswagen Caddy California on a camping trip.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://vwpress.co.uk/en-gb/releases/4313\" target=\"_blank\">Volkswagen</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tFor the true camping experience, the Caddy California also comes with a tent that can be used separately from the vehicle or used as an extra sleeping space for two additional people.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f5942b3e6ff30001d4e7e3b?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Volkswagen Caddy California\" height=\"1666\" width=\"2222\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The Volkswagen Caddy California on a camping trip.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://vwpress.co.uk/en-gb/releases/4313\" target=\"_blank\">Volkswagen</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tThe front of the Caddy California has a \"digital cockpit\" and a navigation system that accompanies the infotainment systems.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f5942bb7ed0ee001e25e5d5?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Volkswagen Caddy California\" height=\"1666\" width=\"2222\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The Volkswagen Caddy California.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://vwpress.co.uk/en-gb/releases/4313\" target=\"_blank\">Volkswagen</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tThe optionally all-wheel-drive vehicle also comes with Volkswagen's Travel Assist, which allows for semi-automated assisted driving.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f5942c8e6ff30001d4e7e3c?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Volkswagen Caddy California\" height=\"1666\" width=\"2222\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The Volkswagen Caddy California on a camping trip.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://vwpress.co.uk/en-gb/releases/4313\" target=\"_blank\">Volkswagen</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tThe camper can be used in conjunction with the \"California on Tour\" smartphone app, which lists campsites, camping companies, and places to dispose of water and waste.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f5942db7ed0ee001e25e5d6?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Volkswagen Caddy California\" height=\"1249\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The Volkswagen Caddy California on a camping trip.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://vwpress.co.uk/en-gb/releases/4313\" target=\"_blank\">Volkswagen</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tHowever, the app can be used by all other Volkswagen camper van owners and isn't exclusive to just the new Caddy California.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f5942787ed0ee001e25e5cf?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Volkswagen Caddy California\" height=\"1666\" width=\"2222\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The Volkswagen Caddy California on a camping trip.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://vwpress.co.uk/en-gb/releases/4313\" target=\"_blank\">Volkswagen</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n</div><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a f30001d4e7e36?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn32@2020_5/2020/09/20/17-35-39-629_8b02109cb1a2671d.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f5942887ed0ee001e25e5d0?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn88@2020_5/2020/09/20/17-35-36-990_4b57eb5dda18021b.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f59428e7ed0ee001e25e5d1?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn64@2020_6/2020/09/20/17-35-39-867_2137169793b15ed7.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f5942967ed0ee001e25e5d2?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn54@2020_6/2020/09/20/17-35-43-605_6302b9dbaf0c28c2.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f5942a0e6ff30001d4e7e38?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn21@2020_4/2020/09/20/17-35-36-116_8566288701452555.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f5942b3e6ff30001d4e7e3b?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn43@2020_6/2020/09/20/17-35-42-749_5b1272759236aa66.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f5942bb7ed0ee001e25e5d5?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn27@2020_3/2020/09/20/17-35-41-606_0c9c35fb9aebad61.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f5942c8e6ff30001d4e7e3c?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn28@2020_6/2020/09/20/17-35-49-725_8862fcfd1475bfe2.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f5942db7ed0ee001e25e5d6?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn100@2020_6/2020/09/20/17-35-37-043_e7ee35dae380aa82.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f5942787ed0ee001e25e5cf?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn92@2020_1/2020/09/20/17-35-42-553_7b16bc2bbd2cda77.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn62@2020_4/2020/09/20/17-35-46-023_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=Zw-Kw-olMPI:A7I-RhXYE4o:F7zBnMyn0Lo":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=Zw-Kw-olMPI:A7I-RhXYE4o:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn47@2020_1/2020/09/20/17-35-42-742_fac77af1d9ea3304.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=Zw-Kw-olMPI:A7I-RhXYE4o:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn57@2020_3/2020/09/20/17-35-38-994_516ed8671bd37460.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/Zw-Kw-olMPI":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn19@2020_1/2020/09/20/17-35-38-840_e60ed1a9d98b68e9.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1600623333145},{"createdTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","updatedTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","title":"Kids in the UK are now spending more money on 'Fortnite' and 'Roblox' than candy and books","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/kids-splashing-cash-fortnite-roblox-online-games-not-sweets-books-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5ec3f2fd5af6cc51cd4abfd9?format=jpeg\" alt=\"piggy bank\" height=\"1838\" width=\"1631\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">LPETTET/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Childrens&#8217; spending habits in the UK have shifted to online games such as \"Roblox\" and \"Fortnite\" since lockdown began, away from sweets and books, a pocket money app has reported.</li>\n<li>Kids are also saving 14% more money than they did in 2019 &#8212; that&#8217;s &#163;104 ($135) a year, RoosterMoney.</li>\n<li>Lego, Roblox, and Apple are the top three brands that children save up for, the study found.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Online video games \"Fortnite\" and \"Roblox\" have overtaken sweets and books as the main target of kids' pocket money spending in the UK, according to a pocket money app.</p><p>A study by RoosterMoney of 24,000 kids in the UK aged between four and 14 had Roblox, a virtual gaming platform, in top spot, followed by Epic Games' \"Fortnite,\" a battle-royale video game.</p><p>Within these games, users can buy outfits and accessories to personalize virtual characters.&#160;</p><p>Epic Games has been <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/fortnite-epic-games-apple-lawsuit-explained-2020-8\">fighting with Apple since \"Fortnite\"</a> launched its own in-game payment system in August, breaking the rules of the App Store.&#160;</p><p>Lego came in third in the pocket money league table, which assessed children's spending during the pandemic, while traditional purchases of books, magazines, and sweets slipped down to fourth place, from the top spots in the list.</p><h3>Kids saving more money than last year</h3><p>Their teeth aren't the only thing kids are saving this year: The Roostermoney study — which surveyed children that use the app, designed to help children save and manage money — revealed that kids are stashing away 43.5% of their pocket money on average, compared to 38% in 2019, a 14% rise.</p><p>Lego, Roblox and Apple are the top three brands that children save up for, the study found.</p><p>The average pocket money rate for children in the UK stands at £4.60 ($5.96) a week, amounting to £239 ($309) a year — kids are saving on average £104 ($135) annually for a rainy day.&#160;</p><p>The average UK adult savings rate is 5.5%, according to <a href=\"https://themoneycharity.org.uk/media/March-2020-Money-Statistics.pdf\">The Money Charity</a>.&#160;</p><p>A spokesperson from Roostermoney told Business Insider that the premise of the pocket money app is to help kids be better with cash, and to educate them on how to save. Children can use the app to log what they spend their money on, allocating it into different pots to save for the next trend, whilst parents monitor their spending.&#160;</p><p>The CEO of Roostermoney, Will Carmichael, said in a statement that he hopes parents have used the last few months to have more conversations with their kids about money.</p><p>\"With the last few months accelerating our move to becoming a cashless society, we can see that reflected not only in our own spending habits, but in that of our children too,\" he said, adding that it's encouraging that saving rates are high.</p><p>Further research from Roostermoney sent to Business Insider revealed that the most common chore for children receiving pocket money is cleaning their bedroom — while the most lucrative chore is washing the car. Parents are likely to give their child an extra few pennies for being good, as well as brave, the research said.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/kids-splashing-cash-fortnite-roblox-online-games-not-sweets-books-2020-9'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a
