f044997?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn7@2020_3/2020/09/20/17-35-49-469_df235812202af396.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f64c098323fc4001e0d7119?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn1@2020_2/2020/09/20/17-35-38-623_b511f37be309f05e.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f4e9aeae6ff30001d4e66d5?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn62@2020_6/2020/09/20/17-35-37-853_299ef0b9015854cd.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f36bb27e89ebf001f044a4b?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn76@2020_1/2020/09/20/17-35-42-140_8092331d3edaf8d4.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f64c7c657b7da001ee12707?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn50@2020_2/2020/09/20/17-35-47-547_81c2f110809b3046.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f64b631323fc4001e0d70e7?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn30@2020_3/2020/09/20/17-35-47-457_f01a48cf2d5f305f.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f64c02c323fc4001e0d7118?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn38@2020_3/2020/09/20/17-35-37-569_57c34f09b3493441.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f64b659323fc4001e0d70e8?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn80@2020_3/2020/09/20/17-35-36-098_dc1d7f0a0a20c7f5.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn62@2020_4/2020/09/20/17-35-46-023_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=8DGXOqViXN4:Wa5UsnZZWOo:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn68@2020_3/2020/09/20/17-35-39-757_c8bfd7ed77f4049e.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=8DGXOqViXN4:Wa5UsnZZWOo:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn36@2020_4/2020/09/20/17-35-45-051_37c4e5d85462b804.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=8DGXOqViXN4:Wa5UsnZZWOo:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn99@2020_3/2020/09/20/17-35-47-060_5c628abef5ea8f08.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/8DGXOqViXN4":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn47@2020_1/2020/09/20/17-35-46-863_da965bbe31cbd26d.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1600623333168},{"createdTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","updatedTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","title":"A 'patriotic' bipartisan presidential ticket determined by a coin flip demands to be taken seriously","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/unity-2020-idw-patriotic-bipartisan-presidential-tulsi-gabbard-crenshaw-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f64e11d323fc4001e0d721b?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Dan Crenshaw Bret Weinstein Unity 2020\" height=\"815\" width=\"1630\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Rep. Dan Crenshaw and Bret Weinstein.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCqhLut6QIaszwQjimemmdEw\" target=\"_blank\">Bret Weinstein</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>The \"intellectual dark web\" star Bret Weinstein sees certain disaster for the US if Trump or Biden wins in 2020.</li>\n<li>Weinstein launched \"Unity 2020\" &#8212; a \"patriotic\" bipartisan ticket with the president and vice president determined by coin flip &#8212; in the hopes of uniting the country.</li>\n<li>Unity 2020 has chosen Democratic Rep. Tulsi Gabbard and Republican Rep. Dan Crenshaw for its ticket. But both have already endorsed their respective parties' nominees.</li>\n<li>Weinstein wants the Libertarian and Green parties to give Unity 2020 their ballot access as a demonstration of their patriotism.</li>\n<li>The Libertarian Party's executive director told Business Insider that Unity 2020 \"feels like snake oil\" sold by \"people who should know better.\"</li>\n<li>\"Instead of as spoilers, [third parties] would be understood as heroes,\" Weinstein told Business Insider.</li>\n<li>This is an opinion column. The thoughts expressed are those of the author.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>It's hard out here for a third-party presidential ticket.&#160;</p><p>To gain ballot access in all 50 states, third parties struggle for years. These lesser-known parties launch nationwide grassroots efforts to collect signatures, file paperwork, and clear innumerable bureaucratic roadblocks. In many cases, a bid also requires reaching a vote-percentage threshold in down-ballot elections for the national party's presidential candidate to stand a chance of making it onto the ballot.</p><p>Even then, candidates are hampered by minuscule name recognition, left out of most national polling, and <a href=\"https://reason.com/2016/06/03/gary-johnson-polls-debates-libertarian/\">locked out of the</a> presidential debates.</p><p>It's a rigged game.&#160;</p><p>As of now, the Libertarian and Green parties are the only third parties that regularly gain widespread ballot access (Libertarians are on ballots in all 50 states; the Greens are in 45 states). But both parties are routinely dismissed as a \"<a href=\"https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/america-isnt-really-set-up-for-third-party-presidential-bids/\">waste of a vote</a>.\"&#160;</p><p>All in all, it's a massive undertaking to make a difference as a third party in the US. So it's intriguing when a new alternative to the Democratic and Republican stranglehold tries to make some noise.</p><p>The latest attempt to enter the fray, <a href=\"https://articlesofunity.org/\">Unity 2020</a>, wants to be taken seriously as a \"patriotic\" movement that stands as the last hope \"to save the Republic from the disaster that looms on our current path.\"</p><p>It's making some noise thanks to a prominent internet presence. But the massive holes in its plan — to say nothing of its logic that seems unmoored from political reality — have led at least one critic from a third party to call it \"snake oil.\"&#160;</p><h2>A 'patriotic' presidential ticket with no party</h2><p>Unity 2020 is the brainchild of former Evergreen State College professor Bret Weinstein, a charter member of the \"<a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2018/05/08/opinion/intellectual-dark-web.html\">intellectual dark web</a>\" (IDW) who is probably best-known for being the target of <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2cMYfxOFBBM\">a student-led mob on campus</a> in 2017. Unity 2020 isn't a party; it's \"a grassroots presidential campaign to restore patriotic, courageous &#38; capable leadership to the United States,\" according to its website.&#160;</p><p>Fundamental to the Unity 2020 ethos is the belief that the country faces certain doom if either President Donald Trump or Democratic presidential nominee Joe Biden wins the election in November. The idea, then, is that a \"patriotic\" bipartisan ticket can save the day.</p><p>Weinstein told me Unity 2020 has about <a href=\"https://articlesofunity.org/support/\">1,000 volunteers and has eschewed fundraising</a> to preemptively cut off any accusations of financial grifting. Such a small and impoverished operation stands little chance of even making as much electoral impact as the perennial third-party candidate <a href=\"https://rocky101.com/en_us/en/\">Rocky De La Fuente</a>. But the movement is generating noise because of IDW's broad audience reach online.</p><p>Weinstein in June unveiled the \"Articles of Unity\" on <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=b4H-0S89pxU\">Tucker Carlson's Fox News show</a> — which this summer <a href=\"https://deadline.com/2020/06/tucker-carlson-tonight-draws-record-4-3-million-viewers-in-2q-amid-all-time-highs-for-fox-news-channel-1202974105/\">broke the record</a> for being the highest-rated cable-news show in history.</p><p>In addition to his YouTube channel with over 220,000 subscribers, Weinstein also recently made his latest of several appearances on the \"<a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pRCzZp1J0v0\">Joe Rogan Experience</a>,\" one of the most popular YouTube shows and podcasts. The interview with Rogan — a fellow IDWer — has been viewed more than 6.5 million times. And that's just on YouTube, which doesn't account for the millions of audio-only downloads and streams Rogan gets with every episode.</p><p>Carlson's and Rogan's audiences are massive — and loyal. While it may not have reached \"the mainstream,\" it's clear that Weinstein is leveraging his network to spread Unity 2020's message to a large audience.</p><p>So what is that message? The \"Articles of Unity\" published on Unity 2020's website show a passion for shaking up the establishment, uprooting the staid two-party system, and moving toward democratic initiatives like ranked voting as a way of juicing more ideological diversity into politics, while chiseling away at two-party tribal hackery.</p><p>Hey, no one ever changed the world by thinking pragmatically. And judging by the many vagaries in the nitty-gritty of its plan, neither has Unity 2020.&#160;</p><p>While Unity 2020 has grand ideas, the organizers have a few practical problems. They have no ballot access less than 50 days before the general election, which is constitutionally required to take place on November 3. They have volunteers but very little organizational infrastructure. And the two candidates they've picked haven't agreed to run on their ticket and have already endorsed their respective parties' standard-bearers.</p><p>Oh also, a coin flip will determine whether the Democrat or the Republican serves as president or vice president, and the order of the ticket will be reversed every four years.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f64e16557b7da001ee127aa?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Tulsi Gabbard\" height=\"2543\" width=\"5086\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Rep. Tulsi Gabbard at a campaign event in February.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Brendan McDermid/REUTERS</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><h2>A hardcore Trump supporter and a renegade Democrat to unify us all</h2><p>Supporters submitted over 2,000 candidate nominations, according to Weinstein, and the top six were then voted on via ranked online ballots.&#160;</p><p><a href=\"https://articlesofunity.org/news/\">Eight rounds of online voting</a> — with 7,919 votes in all — ultimately yielded two sitting members of Congress (as well as military veterans) as Unity 2020's presidential ticket: Republican Rep. Dan Crenshaw and Democratic Rep. Tulsi Gabbard.&#160;</p><p>(I made numerous attempts to reach Crenshaw's and Gabbard's spokespeople to see if they were at all interested in running for president under the Unity 2020 banner but never got a response.)</p><p>Crenshaw was a featured speaker at last month's Republican National Convention, where he endorsed Trump. Gabbard ran for the Democratic nomination this year, finishing with a grand total of two delegates and the dubious honor of being the candidate <a href=\"https://morningconsult.com/2019/12/23/lesser-known-democrats-seize-spotlight-raise-profile-with-los-angeles-debate/\">most disliked by Democratic primary voters</a>. Upon dropping out of the race, she endorsed Biden.</p><p>I asked Weinstein in a phone interview last week how a dyed-in-the-wool Trump-supporting conservative and a renegade Democrat would appeal to moderates, centrists, or independents.&#160;</p><p>\"The ticket isn't moderate. The ticket is patriotic. And what makes the ticket viable is that both of these people are intelligent. They are clearly willing to make sacrifices on behalf of the nation. And they clearly both have courage,\" Weinstein said.</p><p>Unity 2020 was designed to draw voters \"equally from the two major parties,\" Weinstein said. But the two candidates selected may have some problems bridging that gap.</p><p>Gabbard's unpopularity within her own party, Weinstein said, comes in no small part from \"an absolutely bizarre attack from the DNC, with Hillary Clinton accusing her, of all things, of being a Russian asset.\"</p><p>Weinstein added, \"As somebody who grew up during the Cold War, seeing that kind of rhetoric deployed domestically in a political context against an obvious patriot is jaw-dropping.\"</p><p>Regarding Crenshaw, Weinstein said, \"He is a loyal Republican, but I have also spent a fair amount of time talking to Dan, and I find him interpersonally very reasonable. Dan, I would argue, is a person I have long hypothesized exists, which is to say someone who functions well within the current system but would prefer that the system did not have this partisan feature.\"</p><p>Weinstein sees no evidence of patriotism in Trump or Biden, calling the president \"an entirely cynical actor who does what is necessary to advance his own cause\" and describing Biden as a \"lifelong machine politician\" who has run his campaign in \"a decrepit condition.\"</p><p>A self-described \"radical progressive,\" Weinstein said: \"Economic inequality, growing past a certain point, tends to trigger revolts.\" But he added, \"The focus on race on the BLM left is going to drive the entire nation to a place that it has been in the past, where race was a primary feature of how we viewed each other. And anybody who understands the United States knows that moving in that direction will be negative and not positive.\"</p><p>It's not just the forces of the political duopoly that Weinstein is fighting, it's what he sees as political bias in Big Tech.</p><p>Twitter permanently suspended Unity 2020's \"@ArticlesOfUnity\" account for violating its \"platform manipulation and spam policy,\" a company spokesman told me. Weinstein said an <a href=\"https://twitter.com/BretWeinstein/status/1302456933132062720\">internal investigation</a> of Unity 2020's volunteers found no evidence of such violations and that Twitter <a href=\"https://twitter.com/EricRWeinstein/status/1303816088870776833\">has ignored</a> appeals. A <a href=\"https://twitter.com/AoUHistory\">new account</a> has been set up by Unity 2020 volunteers to document Twitter's alleged suppression of Unity-related hashtags and links.</p><p>None of this is an accident, according to Weinstein.&#160;</p><p>\"It is noteworthy that in the Twitter communications division, Kamala Harris' former press secretary is now highly placed,\" Weinstein said, referring to Joe Pacilio, who worked for Harris in that capacity when she was California's attorney general.</p><p>According to Twitter, Pacilio is a spokesperson and has nothing to do with policy enforcement. But he's <a href=\"https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/harris-twitter-trump/\">been accused without evidence by conservative websites</a> of policing Trump's tweets anyway.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f64e54257b7da001ee127c9?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Unity 2020\" height=\"768\" width=\"1536\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Unity 2020.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCi5N_uAqApEUIlg32QzkPlg\" target=\"_blank\">Bret Weinstein</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><h2>Brother, can you spare your national ballot access?&#160;</h2><p>Needless to say, the odds are stacked against Unity 2020. Among its many disadvantages, it has no ballot access to an election that's less than two months from now.</p><p>But Weinstein has a plan for that, too: Third parties — particularly the Libertarian and Green parties — should hand over their ballot access to Unity 2020 out of a sense of patriotism.</p><p>\"Libertarians and the Greens have achieved something very difficult: They have gained national ballot access. However, their role in American politics is effectively as a footnote,\" Weinstein said. \"But with the intent of making the point now at this moment in history, neither one is positioned to win … It is almost impossible to imagine Howie Hawkins or Jo Jorgensen ascending to the presidency.\"</p><p>Hawkins and Jorgensen are the respective nominees for the Green Party and the Libertarian Party.</p><p>Weinstein added: \"I have put my ideology aside, and all of the other volunteers inside of Unity have put their ideologies aside, in order to advance a plan for the good of the nation; the Libertarians and/or the Greens could do the same thing at this moment.\"&#160;</p><p>The Libertarians and Greens have other ideas about Unity 2020's ambitions.&#160;</p><p>\"They're absolute f---ing morons,\" Nicholas Sarwark, the Libertarian Party chair from 2014 to 2020, said. \"They don't have any plan for ballot access other than pretending it's not a thing.\"</p><p>Sarwark said Unity 2020's plan is to \"transcend laws\" by using a kind of magical thinking that he likened to Marianne Williamson's <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2019/09/03/magazine/marianne-williamson-2020.html\">big-on-love and short-on-policy campaign</a>.</p><p>\"Who's your ticket? Dan Crenshaw and Tulsi Gabbard? And the runners-up were William McRaven and Andrew Yang. It's like the start of '<a href=\"https://streetfighter.fandom.com/wiki/Character_Select\">Street Fighter</a>': Randomize your fighter and let's see how it goes,\" Sarwark added.</p><p>Sarwark said the potential Unity 2020 candidates were \"popular with a lot of people\" whose second choice would be Trump and that the project itself \"is an attempt to dismiss all of the work that's been done over decades by somebody who's done no work, and it should be treated with all due respect.\"</p><p>The Libertarian Party's executive director, Dan Fishman, said Unity 2020 \"feels like snake oil\" sold by \"people who should know better.\"</p><p>Fishman noted ballot-access deadlines have already passed and said getting the Libertarians on all 50 states' ballots (plus DC) was particularly difficult this year.</p><p>\"Without question this was the most difficult year ever to get 50-state ballot access. Because in the COVID era, nobody wants to take a pen and a piece of paper from you and sign their name to a petition,\" Fishman said.&#160;</p><p>Fishman said the idea that the Libertarian Party would just hand over its ballot access after successfully completing all the \"arduous\" required work was risible. He added that Weinstein appeared to be \"a person who hasn't done any due diligence at all.\"</p><p>As for the argument that the Libertarians have a patriotic duty to dump their ticket in favor of Unity 2020's, Fishman called that notion \"fearmongering\" and the opposite of patriotism.</p><p>\"We're not looking to elect somebody other than a Republican or Democrat,\" Fishman said. \"We're looking to elect a Libertarian.\"</p><p>The Greens agree.&#160;</p><p>\"Greens want to run Greens for office,\" Michael O'Neil, the Green Party's communications manager, said. \"They want to run candidates who will advocate for our platform and for the policies that we believe in. That's what political parties are supposed to do.\"</p><p>O'Neil is more sympathetic to the Unity 2020 cause than the Libertarians I spoke with.&#160;</p><p>He said the Greens were \"in 100% agreement with the motivation for the Unity 2020 project\" to bring about structural reform and \"democratize our elections.\" But O'Neil added, \"This change is not going to come in one election. It's certainly not going to come in the last two or three months of a presidential election.\"</p><p>However, the Greens have no intention of partnering with Unity 2020 to get Crenshaw and Gabbard on their ticket.</p><p>\"The Green Party nomination is not for anyone to hand out or to trade,\" O'Neil said.&#160;</p><p>\"What people need to understand about creating actual democratic political parties is that they have to be accountable to their membership, they need to be transparent, and, you know, they aren't built in a day,\" O'Neil added.</p><p>Weinstein doesn't buy these arguments and says it's defeatist to believe it's too late in the process to run the Crenshaw-Gabbard (or Gabbard-Crenshaw) ticket — and win.&#160;</p><p>\"Instead of as spoilers, [third parties] would be understood as heroes putting aside their interests for the moment to save a republic that many people seem to understand is in jeopardy,\" Weinstein said. \"It is the right thing to do, the honorable thing to do. And it is also the strategically savvy thing to do.\"</p><p>Weinstein has <a href=\"https://youtu.be/19g95qtDc0Y?t=321\">alluded to elements of his plan</a> that he has not yet made public, and he insists that ballot-access deadlines, running candidates who've already endorsed Trump or Biden, and <a href=\"https://reason.com/2020/09/09/the-incredible-shrinking-3rd-party-voter/\">a cyclical downturn in third-party interest</a> are not immovable barriers.</p><p>\"We discovered that nobody was going to enter the race that could possibly save us from this disastrous outcome, and somebody needed to do something,\" Weinstein said.&#160;</p><p>But he conceded, \"If I had it to do over again, if I knew the future, if I knew where we were going to end up where we did, would I have started much earlier? You better believe it.\"</p><p>In reality, there's little chance a freshman congressman and a lame-duck congresswoman on a random party line would make a dent in the polls against a sitting president and a former vice president. But prospective third-party voters who caught Weinstein on Rogan's show could be swayed, which given enough volume, might chip away at the already modest expected returns for third parties.</p><p>As for the notion that the Libertarians and Greens would team up with Unity 2020, representatives from both parties said they have not been asked.</p><ul class=\"read-more-links\"><li>Read more:</li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/stop-making-excuses-protesters-act-like-bad-cops-portland-seattle-2020-9\" data-analytics-position=\"4\" data-analytics-module=\"\">Stop making excuses for the 'protesters' that act like bad cops</a><br><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/depression-doesnt-take-time-off-coronavirus-pandemic-quarantine-lockdown-2020-5\" data-analytics-position=\"5\" data-analytics-module=\"\"></a></li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/depression-doesnt-take-time-off-coronavirus-pandemic-quarantine-lockdown-2020-5\" parasite, it bleeds you to live</a></li><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/donald-trump-dangerously-gullible-uncle-facebook-antifa-conspiracy-theory-2020-9\" data-analytics-position=\"7\" data-analytics-module=\"\">Trump is your dangerously gullible uncle on Facebook</a></li></ul><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/w476fOXwOtA\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sun, 20 Sep 2020 12:10:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f64e4c3323fc4001e0d7236?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"b3e35532309b80b6aa61a9f40d647fa0","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn61@2020_2/2020/09/20/17-35-35-711_bc852207517b55aa.webp","destWidth":1610,"destHeight":1208,"sourceBytes":68352,"destBytes":68352,"author":"afisher@businessinsider.com (Anthony L. Fisher)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f64e11d323fc4001e0d721b?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn19@2020_1/2020/09/20/17-35-49-704_2bbaae698a85e9ea.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f64e16557b7da001ee127aa?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn14@2020_3/2020/09/20/17-35-37-125_c460b6a38be409d0.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f64e54257b7da001ee127c9?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn4@2020_3/2020/09/20/17-35-47-748_56ae1d9b74f9016b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn62@2020_4/2020/09/20/17-35-46-023_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=w476fOXwOtA:BE5JYHMQEc0:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn75@2020_2/2020/09/20/17-35-43-300_e58bd0e0a444fc8f.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=w476fOXwOtA:BE5JYHMQEc0:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn56@2020_2/2020/09/20/17-35-40-256_5253d5d0a21ad8be.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=w476fOXwOtA:BE5JYHMQEc0:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn88@2020_1/2020/09/20/17-35-43-241_c16e057048555a9b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/w476fOXwOtA":null},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1600623333169},{"createdTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","updatedTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","title":"A striking new photo of Jupiter shows the Great Red Spot is shrinking – and other storms are growing","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/new-hubble-photo-of-jupiter-showcases-new-shifting-storms-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f652b9057b7da001ee12984?format=jpeg\" alt=\"jupiter.hubble\" height=\"1663\" width=\"1663\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>This photo of Jupiter, captured by NASA&#39;s Hubble Space Telescope on August 25, 2020, provides astronomers with new information about the planet&#39;s turbulent weather patterns.\n<p class=\"copyright\">NASA, ESA, STScI, A. Simon (Goddard Space Flight Center), and M.H. Wong (University of California, Berkeley) and the OPAL team</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>The Hubble Space Telescope took a striking new photo of Jupiter that shows how the planet's weather patterns have evolved.</li>\n<li>The gas giant's most famous storm &#8211; its Great Red Spot &#8211; has been shrinking. Another storm nearby may be turning from white to red.</li>\n<li>Meanwhile, clouds in Jupiter's northern hemisphere may indicate a new storm is brewing.&#160;</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Majestic Jupiter, our solar system's belligerent big brother, is putting its best side forward. <a href=\"https://www.spacetelescope.org/news/heic2017/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">A sharp new image from the Hubble Space Telescope</a> shows the giant planet's wild, ever-evolving weather – revealing both short- and long-term changes.</p><p>In the northern hemisphere, turbulent clouds could indicate the formation of a new swirling storm, while down south, a long-lived storm just below and about half the size of the Great Red Spot seems to be slowly changing colour from white to red.</p><p>If that's not enough, off to the left we also have a photobomb from ice moon Europa,&#160;<a href=\"https://www.sciencealert.com/europa-might-actually-be-the-best-place-in-the-solar-system-to-look-for-alien-life\">one of the targets of our search for extraterrestrial life</a>.</p><p>The Great Red Spot is the most famous of Jupiter's storms, and it's the most eye-catching feature in this new image. It's a truly enormous storm, rotating anticlockwise, and we think it's been around for at least 350 years.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f652e1957b7da001ee1298a?format=jpeg\" alt=\"jupiter great red spot\" height=\"536\" width=\"1310\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Jupiter&#39;s Great Red Spot is its most famous storm – it&#39;s been around for hundreds of years.\n<p class=\"copyright\">NASA, ESA, A. Simon/Goddard Space Flight Center, M. H. Wong/University of California, Berkeley, and the OPAL team</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>In the last few decades, the Great Red Spot&#160;<a href=\"https://www.sciencealert.com/jupiter-s-giant-red-storm-is-shrinking-after-raging-large-for-300-years\">appears to have been shrinking</a>, a mystery that has been puzzling scientists, but it's still huge; currently, it measures 15,800 km (9,818 miles) across. That's down from 16,350 km (10,159 miles) <a href=\"https://www.nasa.gov/feature/jpl/nasa-s-juno-spacecraft-spots-jupiter-s-great-red-spot\">in 2017</a>, but still significantly larger than Earth's&#160;<a href=\"https://www.universetoday.com/15055/diameter-of-earth/\">12,742-km</a>&#160;(7917.5-mile) diameter.</p><p>Recently, the Great Red Spot's shrinkage has slowed, but not entirely halted.</p><p>Just below it is a storm called Oval BA. It's much younger than the Great Red Spot, but absolutely fascinating in its own right. It&#160;<a href=\"https://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0019103500965485\">formed in the late 1990s</a>&#160;from three smaller storms that had been raging for 60 years, and has been intensifying ever since.</p><p>Interestingly, it started its newly merged life as a white storm. Then, in 2006, scientists noticed that it was changing colour – turning <a href=\"https://web.archive.org/web/20081019024917/https://science.nasa.gov/headlines/y2006/02mar_redjr.htm\">red like its larger cousin</a>. It didn't stay that way, as you can see. It faded back to white over the course of a few years. But Hubble's new image reveals that the white coloration wasn't permanent either. Oval BA seems to be turning red again.</p><p>This will be a fascinating thing to watch in the future, to determine if there's any rhyme or reason behind these colour changes, but it would likely be many years before a pattern can be discerned.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f652d8757b7da001ee12986?format=jpeg\" alt=\"jupiter storm\" height=\"652\" width=\"1314\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A bright white storm has appeared in Jupiter&#39;s northern hemisphere.\n<p class=\"copyright\">(NASA, ESA, A. Simon/Goddard Space Flight Center, M. H. Wong/University of California, Berkeley, and the OPAL team)</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>In the northern hemisphere, at mid-latitudes, a very bright white storm has appeared, travelling at around 560 km per hour (350 mph), trailed by a plume. As you can probably figure out, storms on Jupiter come and go all the time, but this one appears different.</p><p>Small, dark cyclonic clumps – rotating anticlockwise – are following behind it, embedded in the plume. We've not seen these before, and scientists think that it might be a nascent long-lived storm, similar to the Great Red Spot and Oval BA in the south.</p><p>There's certainly a lot there for planetary scientists to sink their teeth into as they try to understand Jupiter's wild and unpredictable atmosphere. But it's also an awe-inspiring reminder of the beauty and wonder of our little corner of the cosmos.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/new-hubble-photo-of-jupiter-showcases-new-shifting-storms-2020-9'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=AeMd00xZKoM:BCJ4UX92GSQ:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=AeMd00xZKoM:BCJ4UX92GSQ:F7zBnMyn0Lo\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=AeMd00xZKoM:BCJ4UX92GSQ:F7zBnMyn0Lo\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=AeMd00xZKoM:BCJ4UX92GSQ:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=AeMd00xZKoM:BCJ4UX92GSQ:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=AeMd00xZKoM:BCJ4UX92GSQ:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=AeMd00xZKoM:BCJ4UX92GSQ:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=AeMd00xZKoM:BCJ4UX92GSQ:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/AeMd00xZKoM\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sun, 20 Sep 2020 14:16:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f653038323fc4001e0d743e?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"d42733c039344cc04ec859277087d757","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn62@2020_3/2020/09/20/17-35-49-953_50f79092b4e47cd3.webp","destWidth":1663,"destHeight":1247,"sourceBytes":44048,"destBytes":44048,"author":"insider@insider.com (Michelle Star)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f652b9057b7da001ee12984?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn26@2020_4/2020/09/20/17-35-38-087_8c250ee20f4545da.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f652e1957b7da001ee1298a?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn97@2020_1/2020/09/20/17-35-40-147_4e838031e04b4353.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f652d8757b7da001ee12986?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn94@2020_4/2020/09/20/17-35-39-163_bc9178d940fe2b2b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn62@2020_4/2020/09/20/17-35-46-023_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=AeMd00xZKoM:BCJ4UX92GSQ:F7zBnMyn0Lo":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=AeMd00xZKoM:BCJ4UX92GSQ:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn62@2020_5/2020/09/20/17-35-45-416_f332102106bdfdac.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=AeMd00xZKoM:BCJ4UX92GSQ:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn50@2020_1/2020/09/20/17-35-45-179_d4f924b6732f37f5.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/AeMd00xZKoM":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn46@2020_4/2020/09/20/17-35-43-553_9471172e228d6249.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1600623333135},{"createdTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","updatedTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","title":"The fall equinox comes on Tuesday. A planetary scientist's simple animation explains what equinoxes are and how they work.","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-equinox-and-solstice-work-in-simple-animation-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5d079cfe6fc92046153c4b73?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Earth equinoxes and solstices graphic\" height=\"1251\" width=\"1667\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>How Earth, its axial tilt, and the sun work to create solstices, equinoxes, and seasons.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Shayanne Gal/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>The autumnal equinox happens Tuesday at 9:30 a.m. ET.</li>\n<li>During the March and September equinoxes, both halves of the Earth see almost exactly 12 hours of sunlight and 12 hours of nighttime.</li>\n<li>That's because of the way Earth is angled toward the sun on those days.</li>\n<li>A planetary scientist created an animation that shows how Earth's angle and orbit creates equinoxes and solstices.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>The fall equinox comes this <a href=\"https://www.timeanddate.com/calendar/autumnal-equinox.html\">Tuesday at 9:30 a.m. ET</a>.</p><p>Although not the best time to <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/when-spring-equinox-happens-march-2018-03#:~:text=The%20vernal%20or%20spring%20equinox,sun%20appears%20almost%20directly%20overhead.\">balance an egg</a> (that's an old wives' tale), the equinox heralds the coming of autumn, cooler temperatures, and shorter days for the northern hemisphere, which houses about <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/when-is-first-day-of-fall-september-equinox-2019-9#:~:text=This%20year's%20fall%20or%20autumnal,perpendicular%20to%20Earth's%20axial%20tilt.\">90% of Earth's population</a>. For the southern hemisphere, it signifies the opposite: warmer weather and the dawning of spring.&#160;</p><p>To illustrate what's going on with the equinox, <a href=\"https://twitter.com/physicsJ/status/1274224011287785472?s=20\">Dr. James O'Donoghue</a>, a planetary scientist at the Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency, created an animation that neatly summarizes how these events work, along with their relationship to the solstices.&#160;</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f64e8fa323fc4001e0d7252?format=jpeg\" alt=\"equinoxall\" height=\"338\" width=\"600\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>An animation of Earth as it orbits, with points marking both equinoxes and solstices along with relevant information.\n<p class=\"copyright\">James O&#39;Donoghue</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Solstices and equinoxes are the products of Earth's axial tilt: the degree to which the planet is tilted relative to the sun. The axis around which the Earth spins isn't straight up and down — it's about 23.5 degrees off. Because of that, different parts of the Earth get exposed to more or less sunlight as the planet rotates around the sun. That's why we have seasons.</p><p>It's also why the northern and southern hemisphere experience seasons <a href=\"https://www.e-education.psu.edu/emsc100tsb/node/227\">at opposite times</a>: During winter in the northern hemisphere, the southern hemisphere is tilted more towards the sun, and vice versa.</p><p>Meanwhile, Earth is also constantly rotating, which keeps its heating even – kind of like a planet-sized rotisserie chicken <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/when-spring-equinox-happens-march-2018-03#:~:text=The%20vernal%20or%20spring%20equinox,sun%20appears%20almost%20directly%20overhead.\">twisting over a spit</a>.&#160;</p><p>The axial tilt's most dramatic effect comes during the solstices, since those are the two days when one side of the planet is tilted the farthest away from the sun and the other is the closest. On December 21, the northern hemisphere receives less than nine hours of daylight, while the southern hemisphere receives more than 15.</p><p>During the summer solstice, <a href=\"https://twitter.com/physicsJ/status/1274224011287785472?s=20\">O'Donoghue explained</a> on Twitter, \"sunlight is most intense as it only has to pass through a short column of atmosphere.\" That's why it gets hot during summertime in general.&#160;</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5d88cea52e22af0ad94fd20c?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Earth during equinox\" height=\"1213\" width=\"1667\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Shayanne Gal/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>The two times of the year when Earth's axis isn't tilted towards or away from the sun – leading sunlight to hit the northern and southern hemispheres equally — are the equinoxes. On those days, both sides of the planet experience an equal 12 hours of sunlight and darkness.</p><p>So if you were to stand directly on the equator at 9:30 a.m. ET on Tuesday, your shadow would be at <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/when-spring-equinox-happens-march-2018-03#:~:text=The%20vernal%20or%20spring%20equinox,sun%20appears%20almost%20directly%20overhead.\">its absolute minimum</a>. The sun would also appear almost directly overhead.&#160;</p><p>But the shadowless moment would be fleeting, since Earth moves around the sun at about 66,600 mph.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/how-equinox-and-solstice-work-in-simple-animation-2020-9'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a 01:35:33","updatedTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","title":"These custom sleeper cabs are like luxurious tiny homes for long-haul truckers — see inside","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/ari-legacy-sleepers-custom-sleeper-cabs-long-haul-truck-drivers-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f64e0e057b7da001ee127a6?format=jpeg\" alt=\"ARI Legacy Sleepers\" height=\"1884\" width=\"3877\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">ARI Legacy Sleepers</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>ARI Legacy Sleepers builds custom sleeper cabs for long-haul truckers.&#160;</li>\n<li>The sleepers offer amenities truckers don't always have access to, like toilets, showers, kitchens, and full-sized beds.&#160;</li>\n<li>ARI can build in cool features like motorcycle garages, pull-out grills, upscale kitchens, and gaming stations.&#160;</li>\n<li>While a basic sleeper might run you $55,000, a large, customized build could cost upward of $150,000.&#160;</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Life on the road can be challenging for long-haul truckers; they generally work for weeks at a time, sleep in a small area in the cab, and depend on truck stops for the restroom, meals, and showers. But for a price, some companies will make their trucks a little more like home.&#160;</p><p>One such company, <a href=\"https://www.legacysleepers.com/\">ARI Legacy Sleepers</a>, builds spacious, feature-packed sleeper cabs complete with toilets, showers, kitchens, TVs, and other amenities to make truckers' off-duty hours more comfortable. Although high-end tiny homes and camper vans are a relatively new trend, ARI Legacy Sleepers has been packing that kind of functionality into small spaces since 2001.&#160;</p><p>Customers can choose from a variety of sizes and floor plans, or they can work with ARI to design a fully custom sleeper from the ground up. Depending on how much they want to spend, truckers can opt for interesting add-ons like custom tile work, full-size appliances, ceiling fans, gaming stations, and pull-out grills.</p><p>Keep scrolling to take a closer look at some of ARI Legacy Sleepers' creations.&#160;&#160;</p>\n<div id=\"slideshow\">\n\tARI Legacy Sleepers has been building custom sleeper cabs for long-haul truckers since +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f64e099323fc4001e0d7214?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"b0fe6c3021a57f32ec2767e676bc8103","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn18@2020_1/2020/09/20/17-35-35-679_0c6fae61695447c7.webp","destWidth":629,"destHeight":472,"sourceBytes":30108,"destBytes":30108,"author":"tlevin@businessinsider.com (Tim Levin)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f64e0e057b7da001ee127a6?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn22@2020_5/2020/09/20/17-35-37-272_5e3af9724980f879.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f62978b57b7da001ee121c0?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn23@2020_1/2020/09/20/17-35-45-759_7a4b3a9d1925641a.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f62978157b7da001ee121be?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn32@2020_6/2020/09/20/17-35-48-934_1774a3e2e2083ec2.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f62976657b7da001ee121bc?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn79@2020_4/2020/09/20/17-35-38-436_edad26525321387b.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f629783323fc4001e0d6bef?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn88@2020_6/2020/09/20/17-35-47-746_991515f9048d639d.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f629783323fc4001e0d6bee?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn58@2020_3/2020/09/20/17-35-41-995_06f059a88648b000.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f62978d57b7da001ee121c1?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn62@2020_3/2020/09/20/17-35-35-810_737e8b5a85b0e5d0.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f629766323fc4001e0d6bec?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn71@2020_1/2020/09/20/17-35-39-915_fb17eebb6e8bca6d.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f6297bc57b7da001ee121c6?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn58@2020_3/2020/09/20/17-35-37-635_d2269aa291c6ffa7.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f62978557b7da001ee121bf?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn16@2020_4/2020/09/20/17-35-41-600_3e3393e6b2b7dccb.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f62978e323fc4001e0d6bf0?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn84@2020_3/2020/09/20/17-35-48-546_e1bcd196edcde9c1.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f6297ba57b7da001ee121c5?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn96@2020_3/2020/09/20/17-35-44-772_2535d4d645919101.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f6297aa323fc4001e0d6bf1?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn24@2020_6/2020/09/20/17-35-44-904_ef4dc402afce9495.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f62978057b7da001ee121bd?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn47@2020_5/2020/09/20/17-35-39-706_172bab09b8fcd979.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f62979457b7da001ee121c2?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn91@2020_3/2020/09/20/17-35-47-767_27fc834d18fcf3d1.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f62977b323fc4001e0d6bed?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn38@2020_3/2020/09/20/17-35-41-690_2840966b73146e0b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn62@2020_4/2020/09/20/17-35-46-023_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=1NJD5ctHBT8:f15hCMo_-XY:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn16@2020_6/2020/09/20/17-35-38-820_20711c8115f64441.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=1NJD5ctHBT8:f15hCMo_-XY:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn100@2020_1/2020/09/20/17-35-36-603_74414e2c7c83ae93.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=1NJD5ctHBT8:f15hCMo_-XY:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn6@2020_1/2020/09/20/17-35-39-437_cdb00baaa241e1db.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/1NJD5ctHBT8":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn78@2020_6/2020/09/20/17-35-43-876_380043f7e9167006.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1600623333153},{"createdTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","updatedTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","title":"This Green Beret had his leg shot off on a 'cursed' mission, but that didn't stop him from becoming an elite sniper","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/green-beret-who-lost-his-leg-became-special-forces-sniper-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f63a1ec57b7da001ee1248f?format=jpeg\" alt=\"John Wayne Walding\" height=\"1528\" width=\"3056\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>John Wayne Walding\n<p class=\"copyright\">Courtesy photo</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>John Wayne Walding lost his leg after a sniper round all but tore it off during the Battle of Shok Valley in eastern Afghanistan on April 6, 2008, but that didn't stop him.</li>\n<li>After recovering, Walding went through sniper training and became the first amputee to graduate from the Special Warfare Center and School sniper course.</li>\n<li>\"You don't do what I did because you like it. You do it because you love it,\" Walding said. \"There's a lot of people that quit because they just liked it. They liked the idea of being one, but that's not how I live.\"</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>On a Sunday a little over 12 years ago, on a battlefield far from home, US Army Green Beret Staff Sgt. John Wayne Walding, then in his mid-20s, suddenly found himself in an intense firefight that changed his life forever.</p><p>The mission was to capture or kill a local terrorist leader holed up in a mountain fortress occupied by Hezb-e-Islami Gulbuddin forces in eastern Afghanistan.</p><p>The plan was to insert US Special Forces soldiers and Afghan commandos into a valley below by helicopter and take the enemy by surprise. Once they were on the ground, the joint force was expected to climb into the mountains on foot, infiltrate the town, neutralize the hostiles, and get out.</p><p>Some of the troops called to execute the mission questioned whether it was too risky. Their concerns were brushed aside, and the mission moved forward as planned. A fellow Green Beret who went with Walding on the mission told Insider it was \"cursed\" from the start.</p><p>This is the story of not just that fateful mission, but Walding's refusal to give up after tragedy struck.&#160;</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f5fe2eb323fc4001e0d6261?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Ryan Wallen and John Wayne Walding\" height=\"940\" width=\"733\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>John Wayne Walding and Ryan Wallen, a fellow Green Beret who accompanied Walding on the fateful mission.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Courtesy photo</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><h2>'A very long day at the office'</h2><p>On April 6, 2008, a handful of troops with Operational Detachment Alpha 3336, 3rd Special Forces Group and a number of Afghan commandos flew into Shok Valley. It was the start of what Walding called \"a very long day at the office.\"</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f6746ca323fc4001e0d7506?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Shok Valley\" height=\"800\" width=\"1200\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Shok Valley\n<p class=\"copyright\">US Army graphic</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Their troubles began almost immediately upon arrival.</p><p>\"We couldn't even land, the terrain was so f---ing bad,\" Walding's friend and fellow Green Beret, former Staff Sgt. Ryan Wallen, recalled. \"Our helicopter just kind of hovered about 10 feet up over a freezing cold river and gigantic rocks, and we had to jump out of the back. This was already a rough start.\"</p><p>Their situation quickly got worse. As the lead element made its way toward the objective, the mountains suddenly erupted with gunfire. A large force of several hundred enemies ambushed the American and Afghan troops, upending the mission and turning it into a terrifying fight for survival.</p><p>\"Gunfire just opened up on us,\" Wallen said. He was positioned down by the river near the base of the mountain when the bullets started to fly.</p><p>\"I took a [rocket-propelled grenade] and kind of got blown out,\" Wallen continued. \"I was laying half in the water, bleeding out of my throat and chest, beaten up a little bit. The overpressure kind of f---ed me up.\"</p><p>Nothing vital had been damaged in the blast, so the team's medic, Staff Sgt. Ron Shurer, was able to get him patched up and back in the fight. Farther up the mountain, the lead element was pinned down and taking heavy fire.</p><p>An Afghan interpreter had been killed, and two US soldiers, Staff Sgt. Dillon Behr and Staff Sgt. Luis Morales, were severely wounded. Supporting, Walding moved into position between them and the incoming fire. \"That's when I got shot,\" he said.</p><p>An enemy sniper shot Walding in the leg, nearly tearing it from his body. \"It was hanging on by like a tendon or two,\" Wallen said. \"I've never seen an injury that looked that bad.\"</p><p>\"I never will forget falling forward and then rolling over to see that leg just hanging there by only about an inch of flesh,\" Walding recalled. \"It was the worst pain I've ever felt in my life.\"</p><p>Walding was not done fighting though. After putting a tourniquet in place to stop the bleeding, he used his boot laces to strap the bottom part of his leg to his thigh, picked up his rifle, and got back to it.</p><p>Most of the US Special Forces team suffered wounds of one kind or another, but \"as f---ed up as everybody was, we didn't have time for anybody to lay there bleeding and dying,\" Wallen said.</p><p>American planes were called into conduct dozens of danger-close airstrikes with large bombs that Walding said blacked out the sun with debris.</p><p>Unable to move forward with their mission, the US and Afghan troops fought fiercely for hours just to stay alive until they could be pulled out.</p><p>Wallen and a few others helped get Walding down the mountain and to the evacuation point. \"As the medevac birds were coming in, we were dragging casualties across the river, and it was freezing,\" he said.&#160;</p><p>They tried a couple of times to get Walding on a helicopter but were unsuccessful, as the helos were either full or taking rounds, and each time they failed, they had to carry him back across the river to a safe position shielded from the gunfire.</p><p>\"Finally, a third bird came in, and we took JW back across the river a fifth time,\" Wallen said. \"We were finally able to get him on that bird, but we ended up giving John hypothermia along with all of his damn injuries. It was like bad things kept stacking up.\"</p><p>All of the US troops that went into Shok Valley made it out alive. Some of the Afghans, however, did not. Although they were unable to complete the mission, the US and Afghan forces left behind hundreds of enemy dead.</p><p>Ten members of Walding's team, himself included, would later be awarded the Silver Star. Not since Vietnam had that many Silver Stars been awarded for a single engagement. And, two of the soldiers who were in Shok Valley <a href=\"https://mohmuseum.org/battle-of-shok-valley/\">later received</a> the Medal of Honor for their courage under fire.</p><p>The immediate aftermath was no celebration though. Walding, who had hoped that his leg could be saved, went into surgery. \"I never will forget waking up the next day,\" he recalled. He said he was afraid to look down. When he finally did, he cried.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f63a1a0323fc4001e0d6eb6?format=jpeg\" alt=\"John Wayne Walding\" height=\"1506\" width=\"1000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>John Wayne Walding\n<p class=\"copyright\">US Army Photo by Capt. David Chace</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><h2><strong>'A leg was not going to stop me'</strong></h2><p>John Wayne Walding was born on the Fourth of July in Texas. His father named him after the famous actor who starred in classic Westerns and war movies because, in his words, if \"you have a cool birthday, you need a cool name.\"</p><p>But while Walding was named after the man who directed and starred in the 1968 film \"The Green Berets,\" he never thought much about the military until he was about 20 years old and realized he needed a real job.</p><p>Walding talked to a recruiter who asked him if he wanted to shoot missiles. He said \"Hell yeah\" and joined the Army as a Patriot missile operator.</p><p>He found his true calling after he joined up though. \"As soon as I saw the Green Berets and what the tip of the spear really is, that really got my gears spinning,\" he told Insider.</p><p>Wallen met Walding when the latter joined his team as a Green Beret, and they quickly became good friends.</p><p>\"It was one of those connections that, just right away, we just kind of hit it off,\" Wallen said. \"We developed a really strong bond, and then it was just solidified when we were baptized in blood together.\"</p><p>Wallen said he was one of the first people to see Walding when he came out of surgery after being wounded in Shok Valley.</p><p>Walding had been torn apart in battle, something not easily overcome, something that some never overcome, but he determined he was not done being an elite soldier. \"Donning that Green Beret was one of the most profound moments of my life, and a leg was not going to stop me from doing that,\" he told Insider.</p><p>Being a Green Beret meant being a part of something special, something meaningful that's bigger than any one person. Reflecting on the events that unfolded in Shok Valley, Walding said, \"We didn't get through that day because I was great or any of our guys. It was because we were willing to fight to the death to keep each other alive.\"</p><p>\"You don't just wake up the day after all of that and say, 'Well, I guess I'll hang up the hat.'\"</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f601560323fc4001e0d62ad?format=jpeg\" alt=\"John Wayne Walding\" height=\"819\" width=\"1224\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>John Wayne Walding\n<p class=\"copyright\">Courtesy photo</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><h2>'You do it because you love it'</h2><p>Walding said that he tries to live his life in such a way that he is not simply good, but great. Following his recovery, he decided to become a Special Forces sniper.</p><p>Just two years after he sustained a life-altering injury, Walding began the intense seven-week Special Forces Sniper Course at the John F. Kennedy Special Warfare Center and School at Fort Bragg, North Carolina equipped with a ruggedized prosthetic and a determination to excel against all odds.</p><p>\"Why did I keep going? Because I loved it,\" Walding said.</p><p>\"You don't do what I did because you like it. You do it because you love it,\" he continued. \"To become a Green Beret, there's a lot of people that quit because they just liked it. They liked the idea of being one, but that's not how I live.\"</p><p>Snipers are essential assets who provide battlefield intelligence and long-range precision fires, and the training is challenging across the military.</p><p>For the Special Forces, sniper training can be even more demanding. Through shooting and marksmanship sessions, gun runs, stalking, fast rope training, and climbing exercises, Walding held his own despite his prosthetic. \"I never finished last,\" he said.</p><p>Walding made history in the summer of 2010 by becoming the first amputee to graduate from the elite special warfare sniper course.</p><p>\"His story is incredible,\" Wallen said. \"I don't know that many people on the planet have the kind of resilience he does.\" That's not to say that there weren't bad days, but when times got tough, it was his faith, family and friends, and love of country that got him through.</p><p>Walding wanted to return to his team and operational status, but he ultimately decided against it, opting instead to stay on as an instructor.</p><p>\"I knew that no matter how good I was with one leg, a Green Beret with two was always going to be better,\" Walding told Insider, explaining that he would never want to be in a scenario where one of his brothers or sisters was injured or killed because of him. \"I wouldn't be able to live with myself,\" he said.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f63bc3457b7da001ee12567?format=jpeg\" alt=\"John Wayne Walding\" height=\"3840\" width=\"5760\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>John Wayne Walding\n<p class=\"copyright\">Courtesy photo</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><h2>'Forever remember the cost of freedom'</h2><p>After serving 12 years in the military, Walding retired in 2013 as a Sergeant First Class. He now lives in Texas with his wife and four kids.</p><p>As a civilian, Walding continues to serve.</p><p>He started Gallantry Global Logistics, a company named after the words on the back of his Silver Star, which reads \"for gallantry in action.\" He hopes to see it become the largest veteran employer in Texas. He is also the co-founder of Live to Give, a water bottle company that donates half of all profits to veteran and first responder charities.</p><p>Walding named his shipping company after his Silver Star, but the Purple Heart he was awarded for the injuries he suffered in Afghanistan has tremendous meaning too.</p><p>\"I wear that Purple Heart figuratively every day,\" Walding said. \"Every single day, I wake up and I see my leg is missing. I will forever remember the cost of freedom. It really is a driving factor for me to not be good, but be great.\"</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a Pickrell)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f63a1ec57b7da001ee1248f?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn20@2020_2/2020/09/20/17-35-48-808_bb85d9549864ecfb.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f5fe2eb323fc4001e0d6261?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn87@2020_1/2020/09/20/17-35-49-316_14d606725a44daf3.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f6746ca323fc4001e0d7506?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn43@2020_6/2020/09/20/17-35-35-686_524ee7bf2eeda2c2.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f63a1a0323fc4001e0d6eb6?format=jpeg":null,"https://i.insider.com/5f601560323fc4001e0d62ad?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn46@2020_1/2020/09/20/17-35-35-697_b6085a82d263fba7.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f63bc3457b7da001ee12567?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn35@2020_3/2020/09/20/17-35-39-520_4c982f41610b8c0c.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn62@2020_4/2020/09/20/17-35-46-023_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=l42UYmXAetU:Y7qJGcTdxj0:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn70@2020_1/2020/09/20/17-35-39-032_4da3867d2b5918e8.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=l42UYmXAetU:Y7qJGcTdxj0:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn38@2020_1/2020/09/20/17-35-43-671_b4c938996bdb2667.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=l42UYmXAetU:Y7qJGcTdxj0:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn13@2020_5/2020/09/20/17-35-39-328_8fa104591af16ca2.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/l42UYmXAetU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn72@2020_1/2020/09/20/17-35-46-848_97a6eacc98672fd6.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1600623333148},{"createdTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","updatedTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","title":"A motivational guru on how to easily audit what you spend your time and money on to make sure it's going toward the things you truly value","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/motivational-guru-on-how-to-audit-your-time-and-money-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f613015323fc4001e0d6779?format=jpeg\" alt=\"IMG_0023\" height=\"3648\" width=\"4864\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Jay Shetty (left) and Dan Schawbel (right)\n<p class=\"copyright\">Courtesy of Dan Schawbel</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Jay Shetty, an author and podcaster, <strong>recently appeared on the&#160;</strong><strong>\"</strong><a href=\"https://danschawbel.com/category/podcasts/\" data-analytics-module=\"summary_bullets\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"0\" data-uri=\"61767f77c3a9dc00e9b5b3e40f8608de\"><strong>5 Questions with Dan Schawbel</strong></a><strong>\" podcast.</strong></li>\n<li>Shetty talked about the importance of figuring out your values, which you can do through auditing how you spend your time and money.</li>\n<li>It's also key to get to the root of the fear you're experiencing, and address it head-on.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/author/dan-schawbel\" data-analytics-module=\"summary_bullets\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"0\" data-uri=\"a9b8a57b54e3680a33a0ef80b7e9dfe5\"><strong>Dan Schawbel</strong></a><strong>&#160;is a bestselling author, speaker, entrepreneur, and host of the \"</strong><a href=\"https://danschawbel.com/category/podcasts/\" data-analytics-module=\"summary_bullets\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"0\" data-uri=\"61767f77c3a9dc00e9b5b3e40f8608de\"><strong>5 Questions with Dan Schawbel</strong></a><strong>\" podcast, where he interviews world-class humans by asking them just five questions in under 10 minutes.</strong></li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>After hearing a monk give a lecture when he was 21, Jay Shetty's life completely changed. For three years, he says he spent half his summer vacations working for corporations and the other half living like a monk in India.</p><p>Along his journey, Jay applied the mindsets and practices he learned as a monk to everyday life, with a mission to make wisdom go viral by creating videos — which are now viewed by billions of people worldwide.</p><p>More recently, he incorporated his journey, and the lessons he learned along the way, into his first book, \"<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/a-practical-approach-to-finding-meaning-in-your-work-2020-9\">Think Like a Monk: Train Your Mind for Peace and Purpose Every Day</a>.\"&#160;</p><p>In our conversation, Jay talks about uncovering your personal values, following your own life journey, the importance of intentions, overcoming fear and his best career advice.</p><p><strong>You start your book talking about values. How do you figure out what your values are and then start to notice those values in other people?</strong></p><p>If you want to really know your values, look at where you spend your time, and look at where you spend your money. That is a genuine view of what your values are. People say, \"Oh, do a reflection exercise,\" or, \"Look inside yourself and ask yourself what your values are.\"</p><p>The truth is your values are what you spend your time, and what you spend your money, and what you spend your energy on. So let's look at time, for example. We spend a <a href=\"https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/science-explains-why-we-really-do-need-to-sleep-a-third-of-our-lives-away/\">third of our lives in bed</a>. We spent countless hours getting ready every day. You're spending all of that time over a lifetime just taking care of your body.</p><p>Most of us spend most of our money on rent; <a href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2018/06/06/how-much-of-your-income-you-should-be-spending-on-housing.html\">25% or 30% of our money is spent on rent</a>. So our values are dictated by where we spend our time, and where we spend our money. And what I recommend to everyone in this book is do an audit of where you spend your time and money, and ask yourself whether that feels right. If you do that activity and you're like, \"Oh, wow, this is exactly what I believe in,\" then you're winning. If you do that activity and you're getting scared by the numbers, then it's time you need to switch.</p><p><strong>There are so many different things competing for our time now, especially with social media and the fear of missing out. How do we decide what to listen to and move in a direction that's authentic to us, while avoiding distractions?</strong></p><p>I read somewhere that we're exposed to more negative information today in 24 hours than we were in our whole lifetime 25 years ago. That's insane, if you think about it.</p><p>So the amount we're having to process, whether it's notifications, alerts, news messages, it's just completely sensationalized and catapulted in terms of volume. That's where our values become so important, because if you don't have a core set of values that you've defined, it means you're constantly being guided by everyone else's.</p><p>There's a beautiful statement in the Bhagavad Gita that I quote in \"Think Like a Monk.\" The verse says: \"Better to live your own life imperfectly then to impersonate someone else's life perfectly.\"&#160;</p><p>I think all of us, at some point in our life come to a moment of reflection where we think, \"I think I'm living someone else's life.\" I'm doing someone else's job. I'm doing someone else's career. I'm doing someone else's passion. I'm not actually living the life I want to live.</p><p>It would be great to get to a point where I get an opportunity and I can say, \"Actually, Dan would be better at this opportunity, why don't I give it to him?\"</p><p>That would actually be maturing in your values, and that would actually be maturing in knowing what's right for you and what's right for someone else. You're able to look at something and say, \"That is definitely for me because my values are so aligned, but actually I could find things that my friends would do better at, and I should be able to introduce them to that.\"&#160;</p><p><strong>Can you talk a little bit about setting intentions and then following through on them, because a lot of people talk a big game, but action doesn't follow?&#160;</strong></p><p>Intention is the why behind what you do. I have two separate clients who give a lot in charity every single year.</p><p>Let's say that their charity amount, every single year, is in the one to five million dollar range. They both give the same amount in charity. One does it for press and publicity, and the other one does it because they really believe in the cause and then we really want to serve and support the people that they're donating money to. The second one is the happier person.</p><p>The intention doesn't affect whether the kids are helped, whether the money received at the end helps the people change their lives or whether the money has an impact, because that happens either way. But the intention defines whether you are happy, and that's what I love so much about it.</p><p><strong>One of my favorite parts of the book is when you talk about getting to the root of the problem and you say, ask why, why, why, why. Can you give an example about how you did that in your own life?</strong></p><p>In the book, I talk about how to build a \"why ladder,\" because mostly what we're dealing with is our superficial fears, or we're dealing with the latest trend and news that's upsetting us, but we're not really dealing with the root.</p><p>And the problem is if you're not dealing with the root, you can't really solve it; you're just dealing with another symptom.</p><p>An example is, let's say I was scared of going off to become a monk and worried about what that meant. I asked myself, \"Why am I scared of that?\" Answer: \"Because I may never get a job again.\"</p><p>Okay, why am I scared that I may never get a job again? Because I may never be able to make money or support my family.</p><p>Okay. Well, why am I scared of that? Well, because I don't want to let my parents down. It's like, well, why don't I want to let my parents down? Because I don't want to let my parents down.</p><p>And then all of a sudden it hit you that that is the root cause of why you're not taking this moment. Now, you can actually focus your energy on overcoming that fear rather than what you thought the fear was, which was that you're scared of becoming a monk.</p><p>And so, so many of us are not making that career change because we think we're scared of something, but we haven't really found the root of our fear and so we don't deal with the root of our fear — and that way it consumes us.&#160;</p><p><strong>What's your best piece of career advice?&#160;</strong></p><p>Go really deep in becoming an expert in your passion. I have this rule right now, where every year I should be doing something that I love. So there should be something in my life that I'm loving. Right now what I'm loving is my podcast \"On Purpose.\" I'm in love with doing it because I've been doing it for a year and I've got into the flow.</p><p>Every year, you should be doing something that you're learning. So you should always be learning about what you want to do the next year. If you're not learning a year in advance, that dream is not happening. So when I was writing the book, I learned how to write a book the year before, so that made writing easier. The year before I launched the podcast, I was learning how to launch a podcast. And then every year you should be launching something. So this book is what I'm launching this year.&#160;</p><p>Every year, pick something that you're loving, something that you're learning, and something that you're launching. The loving gives you satisfaction and happiness, the learning gives you excitement and curiosity, and the launching gives you a new learning curve, a new risk, and a new excitement.</p><p><strong>Watch the full video interview on </strong><a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wE5uo2SodR4\"><strong>YouTube</strong></a><strong>&#160;</strong></p><iframe width=\"560\" height=\"315\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/wE5uo2SodR4\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen></iframe><p>&#160;</p><p><strong>Listen to the audio podcast:</strong></p><div 01:35:33","updatedTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","title":"Jerry Nadler says Democrats should 'immediately' move to expand the Supreme Court if the GOP pushes a lame duck vote","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/jerry-nadler-house-judiciary-democrats-republicans-ginsburg-supreme-court-expansion-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f665bf9323fc4001e0d74ef?format=jpeg\" alt=\"GettyImages 1227815172\" height=\"3712\" width=\"5568\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>House Judiciary Committee Chairman Jerry Nadler (D-N.Y.) questions Attorney General William Barr at a hearing in July.\n<p class=\"copyright\">MATT MCCLAIN/POOL/AFP via Getty Image</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>House Judiciary Committee Chairman Jerry Nadler voiced support for adding new justices to the US Supreme Court if Senate Republicans fill the seat of the late Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg during a lame duck session.</li>\n<li>\"Filling the SCOTUS vacancy during a lame duck session, after the American people have voted for new leadership, is undemocratic and a clear violation of the public trust in elected officials,\" Nadler tweeted.</li>\n<li>As a member of the House of Representatives, Nadler does not have the ability to vote on Supreme Court nominees, but as a leading voice on judicial matters on Capitol Hill, his voice holds immense sway.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>On Saturday, House Judiciary Committee Chairman Jerry Nadler voiced support for adding new justices to the US Supreme Court if Senate Republicans fill the seat of the late Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg during a lame duck session, which would occur after the November election but before new members arrive in January.</p><p>Nadler tweeted, \"If Sen. McConnell and <a href=\"https://twitter.com/SenateGOP\" data-focusable=\"true\">@SenateGOP</a> were to force through a nominee during the lame duck session—before a new Senate and President can take office—then the incoming Senate should immediately move to expand the Supreme Court.\"</p><p>As a member of the House of Representatives, Nadler does not have the ability to vote on Supreme Court nominees, but as a leading voice on judicial matters on Capitol Hill, his voice holds immense sway.</p><p>Nadler, a New York Democrat, is not generally known for pushing for dramatic institutional changes. He was elected to the House in 1992 and has been chairman of the Judiciary Committee since 2019.</p><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" data-cards=\"\" data-conversation=\"\">&#8212;Rep. Nadler  (@RepJerryNadler) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/mims/statuses/1307380156189814789?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">September 19, 2020</a></blockquote><script async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script><p>In the hypothetical scenario Nadler suggested, Joe Biden could potentially be elected to the presidency, along with an incoming Democratic-controlled Senate set to take over in January; a lame duck Republican-controlled Senate could push through a conservative nominee in November or December anyway.</p><p>Another complication: Mark Kelly, the Democratic nominee for the Arizona Senate seat currently held by Republican Martha McSally, could be sworn in by late November if he wins the race, which could tank Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell's efforts to fill Ginsburg's seat. Kelly and McSally are running in a special election for the seat held by the late Sen. John McCain.</p><p>Nadler then tweeted, \"Filling the SCOTUS vacancy during a lame duck session, after the American people have voted for new leadership, is undemocratic and a clear violation of the public trust in elected officials. Congress would have to act and expanding the court would be the right place to start.\"</p><p>Ginsburg, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/supreme-court-justice-ruth-bader-ginsburg-has-died-2019-8\">who died</a> on Friday at the age of 87, was appointed to the Supreme Court in 1993 by then-President Bill Clinton and was a pillar of the court's liberal bloc for 27 years. If Senate Republicans were able to confirm a successor, the court would have six justices appointed by Republican presidents and three appointed by Democratic presidents.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/jerry-nadler-house-judiciary-democrats-republicans-ginsburg-supreme-court-expansion-2020-9'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=QECUsmy2gu4:m8_cSpPPLbU:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=QECUsmy2gu4:m8_cSpPPLbU:F7zBnMyn0Lo\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=QECUsmy2gu4:m8_cSpPPLbU:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=QECUsmy2gu4:m8_cSpPPLbU:V_sGLiPBpWU\"
