border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=QECUsmy2gu4:m8_cSpPPLbU:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=QECUsmy2gu4:m8_cSpPPLbU:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/QECUsmy2gu4\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sun, 20 Sep 2020 00:24:06 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f665c01323fc4001e0d74f0?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"df2cba405f92cf259302d2ee3308222b","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn52@2020_1/2020/09/20/17-35-50-714_db6c7375c8a9118d.webp","destWidth":4949,"destHeight":3712,"sourceBytes":298712,"destBytes":298712,"author":"insider@insider.com (John L. Dorman)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f665bf9323fc4001e0d74ef?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn37@2020_1/2020/09/20/17-35-36-773_c331506896511076.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn62@2020_4/2020/09/20/17-35-46-023_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=QECUsmy2gu4:m8_cSpPPLbU:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn53@2020_2/2020/09/20/17-35-35-854_adab1b1a0085e8ae.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=QECUsmy2gu4:m8_cSpPPLbU:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn86@2020_2/2020/09/20/17-35-38-478_230f3e96b013abe7.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=QECUsmy2gu4:m8_cSpPPLbU:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn17@2020_2/2020/09/20/17-35-35-889_2e20582da869ee55.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/QECUsmy2gu4":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn84@2020_4/2020/09/20/17-35-48-362_4e8fa3f19be7b22e.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1600623333157},{"createdTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","updatedTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","title":"Students are in a lose-lose situation during the pandemic, and Trump is to blame","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-administration-leadership-college-students-covid-19-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f5fd19757b7da001ee1185e?format=jpeg\" alt=\"trump president\" height=\"1000\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>US President Donald Trump speaks to the press before boarding Air Force One at Joint Base Andrews in Maryland on August 6, 2020.\n<p class=\"copyright\">JIM WATSON/AFP via Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Trump's leadership in the White House has left students in a lose-lose situation.</li>\n<li>Either schools will do virtual learning with the risk of students falling behind, or they can reinstate in-person learning and face the obvious health risks.</li>\n<li>Joe Biden is much better equipped to handle a crisis like this.</li>\n<li>Rachel Palermo is a J.D. candidate at Notre Dame Law School.</li>\n<li>This is an opinion column. The thoughts expressed are those of the author.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Back-to-school season used to be one of the most exciting times of year. This year, it's a complete disaster. Classrooms around the country are either empty, or they are unsafe. And the worst part is that it didn't have to be this way.</p><h2>Pick your poison</h2><p>When the pandemic first caused schools to go virtual in the spring, our nation's leaders should have sprung into action. They had a responsibility to the American people to take the virus seriously. But they failed to act. Instead, the Trump administration has repeatedly tried to<a href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/there-isnt-a-coronavirus-second-wave-11592327890\"> spread the dangerous message</a> that the crisis is overblown.</p><p>Last week, Trump recklessly <a href=\"https://apnews.com/5d306f8176972692ce700b569b01cd73\">held an indoor rally</a> in Nevada in blatant defiance of state regulations and public health guidance. And earlier, news broke that Donald Trump admitted in March to <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/live/2020/09/09/us/trump-vs-biden/trump-acknowledges-report-that-he-played-down-the-threat-of-the-virus-calling-himself-a-cheerleader\">intentionally downplaying the virus</a>, even though he was aware that the virus is \"deadly\" and more threatening than the seasonal flu. Since Trump first started lying about the threat, nearly <a href=\"https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/health/2020/09/09/covid-updates-astrazeneca-vaccine-trial-honolulu-trump/5754245002/\">200,000 Americans</a> have died from COVID-19.&#160;</p><p>Trump's only concern seems to be the optics of his re-election campaign, putting the safety of students in the crosshairs. Students have been thrust into a lose-lose situation. Either schools can choose to convert to virtual learning and let students fall behind academically, or they can return to in-person classes while risking their communities' health. Either way, students are the ones who lose.</p><p>Virtual learning isn't working, and it's<a href=\"https://www.mckinsey.com/industries/public-and-social-sector/our-insights/covid-19-and-student-learning-in-the-united-states-the-hurt-could-last-a-lifetime#\"> widening the gap</a> between students based on factors like socioeconomic status and race. Parents are expected to work full-time jobs on top of re-learning algebra they haven't seen since the '90s. And students with family members at home during the day are the lucky ones — many students don't have parents who have the ability to work remotely.</p><p>Additionally, some students have even struggled through virtual learning without having internet access at home. Just recently, a photo went viral of two students who resorted to<a href=\"https://twitter.com/kdeleon/status/1299386969873461248\"> sitting outside of a Taco Bell</a> to connect to their online classes.</p><p>On the other hand, I've seen firsthand that in-person learning during the pandemic isn't the solution either. Since we returned to the University of Notre Dame for classes on campus less than a month ago,<a href=\"https://here.nd.edu/our-approach/dashboard/\"> 654 members</a> of our community have already tested positive for COVID-19.</p><p>After an immediate spike less than two weeks into classes, the school had to temporarily revert to virtual learning to get the virus under control. Notre Dame is doing everything it can to keep us safe, but there's no way to contain the virus when it is relentlessly spreading from coast to coast. Notre Dame's not alone — take a look at other colleges and universities across the country. From the<a href=\"https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/they-put-us-all-danger-unc-chapel-hill-students-outraged-n1237200\"> University of North Carolina-Chapel Hill</a> to the<a href=\"https://www.cnn.com/2020/08/29/us/university-of-alabama-covid-19-cases-trnd/index.html\"> University of Alabama</a>, infection rates skyrocketed once students returned to campus, and the outcomes could be deadly.</p><p>On top of the impact on our learning this year, the pandemic is going to harm our career trajectories for years to come. Trump's mismanagement of the coronavirus crisis has cost millions of Americans their jobs, forced small businesses to close, and destroyed our economy.</p><p>Students have already felt the economic impacts of COVID-19 after<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/coronavirus-internships-cancelled-college-student-job-2020-3\"> losing their internships</a> and summer jobs. For those of us who worked virtually this summer, missing out on critical in-person professional experiences and networking opportunities is bound to stagnate our growth when we begin our careers.&#160;</p><h2>We can fix this at the ballot box&#160;</h2><p>The coronavirus touched my own family this spring. My great-uncle checked into a hospital after experiencing coronavirus symptoms in March, and he never saw a member of our family again. He passed away several weeks later — a solitary and painful death. My story isn't unique – people around the world have suffered loss from the virus. By failing to act, the Trump administration told us that those lives weren't worth saving. I had a semblance of hope that Trump would see the death toll and respond by taking action, but instead he dismissed our losses,<a href=\"https://www.cnn.com/2020/08/04/politics/trump-covid-death-toll-is-what-it-is/index.html\"> saying</a>, \"It is what it is.\"&#160;</p><p>When a crisis happens, the most important part of being a leader is having a plan. But Trump failed to have a plan in the early days of the pandemic, and he still doesn't have one now. Back-to-school season is a nightmare this year because we are suffering the consequences of Trump's failure to protect the American people.</p><p>Students deserve steady leadership to address this crisis. We need a President who will put his constituents first by creating a plan informed by science. We need a leader who will believe that my great-uncle's life was one that was worth saving.&#160;</p><p>From the early days of the pandemic, Joe Biden immediately created a<a href=\"https://joebiden.com/beat-covid19/\"> roadmap</a> to steer our nation out of this crisis. He put forth a<a href=\"https://joebiden.com/school-reopening/\"> plan</a> for reopening schools safely — something Trump should have done long ago. Under the leadership of the Biden-Harris administration, schools won't be forced into the same no-win situation next time around. We will finally have leaders who will take concrete steps to ridding us of this virus once and for all.</p><p>Joe Biden leads with purpose. He listens to the advice of public health experts. Biden has the empathy to understand the pain that students are going though, and he will restore the soul of our nation. Students need Joe Biden in the White House.</p><p><em>Rachel Palermo is a J.D. candidate at Notre Dame Law School. She previously served as the Assistant Press Secretary &#38; Director of Women's Media at the Democratic National Committee.</em></p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f5fd19457b7da001ee1185d?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"dd4687608f50f3fd4970b63699201b97","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn32@2020_2/2020/09/20/17-35-50-465_2272b54742531cab.webp","destWidth":1774,"destHeight":1331,"sourceBytes":53130,"destBytes":53130,"author":"insider@insider.com (Rachel Palermo)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f5fd19757b7da001ee1185e?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn14@2020_6/2020/09/20/17-35-44-201_7fea76638ba8ba08.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn62@2020_4/2020/09/20/17-35-46-023_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=gbKJ8YhaiZg:PRVrU02-0Ok:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn76@2020_2/2020/09/20/17-35-47-874_5b76de4be80397fc.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=gbKJ8YhaiZg:PRVrU02-0Ok:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn70@2020_4/2020/09/20/17-35-35-708_8dcc759bae78436a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=gbKJ8YhaiZg:PRVrU02-0Ok:gIN9vFwOqvQ":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/gbKJ8YhaiZg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn26@2020_2/2020/09/20/17-35-35-744_f3c00dbcb666d48a.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1600623333157},{"createdTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","updatedTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","title":"Restaurants need to brace for 18 more months of extreme challenges — and the election is about to make things worse","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/restaurants-face-another-sales-drag-the-2020-election-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5ea3062838bf237267439da2?format=jpeg\" alt=\"A restaurant remains open despite the coronavirus pandemic in Bristow, Oklahoma, March 24, 2020. Nick Oxford for The Washington Post via Getty Images\" height=\"686\" width=\"914\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A restaurant remains open in Bristow, Oklahoma.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Nick Oxford/The Washington Post via Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Restaurants are going to be facing extreme challenges until 2022, according to Oliver Wright, the global head of Accenture's consumer goods and services practice.&#160;</li>\n<li>Nearly 100,000 restaurants have closed across the US since the pandemic began, according to the National Restaurant Association.</li>\n<li>Heading in to the fall, restaurants will face new hurdles, including reduced unemployment benefits, colder weather, and people skipping on dining out because of the election.&#160;</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>To describe 2020 as a bad year for restaurants is an understatement.&#160;</p><p>Nearly 100,000 restaurants have closed across the US since the pandemic began, <a href=\"https://www.restaurant.org/news/pressroom/press-releases/100000-restaurants-closed-six-months-into-pandemic\">according</a> to the National Restaurant Association. That's roughly one in six of all restaurants across the country.&#160;</p><p>And according to the association, 43% of full-service operators say it is unlikely their business will still be open in six months if conditions created by the coronavirus pandemic do not improve. Unfortunately, experts say that actual improvement is a long way off.&#160;</p><p>\"It's very clear now that it's not a 2020 problem,\" Oliver Wright, the global head of Accenture's consumer goods and services practice, told Business Insider.</p><p>Data indicates that disposable income levels are unlikely to return to 2019 figures by early to mid-2022, Wright said. As a result, restaurant sales will likely not return to pre-pandemic levels until around the same time.&#160;</p><p>\"The next 15 months, at a minimum, and probably next 18 months are going to be extremely challenging,\" for restaurants, especially smaller independents, Wright said.&#160;</p><h2>2020 is about to get even worse for restaurants&#160;</h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5eb309403dac9a0f566db623?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Moes BBQ Georgia restaurants reopening coronavirus\" height=\"1667\" width=\"2223\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Chandan Khanna/AFP via Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Fall is bringing with it more bad news for restaurants, especially sit-down and full-service options.&#160;</p><p>In a research note this week, Gordon Haskett analyst Jeff Farmer listed a number of reasons why same-store sales improvement is set to slow in the fall, including reduced unemployment benefits and colder weather reducing outdoor seating.</p><p>One factor Farmer lists that hasn't been discussed as widely as other factors is the election. Farmer says the drop in restaurant sales around presidential elections can be tied to uncertainty and the \"CNN effect,\" when people stay at home to watch the news instead of going out to eat.</p><p>Farmer discussed this trend in another research report earlier this year.</p><p>\"Restaurant sales growth rates (especially for casual dining) slowed materially in 2008, 2012 and 2016 over the 6-month period leading into the November election,\" he wrote in a note in January.&#160;</p><p>Last year, restaurant industry consultant Malcolm Knapp <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/death-of-american-dream-transforms-restaurant-industry-2019-10\">told Business Insider</a> the fact that almost half of Americans said they were not eating out as much as they want to could be linked to the nation's growing anxiety over issues such as political polarization and income inequality. High levels of anxiety convince people to order in, instead of going out to eat.</p><p>\"Everything that happens in society turns up in the restaurant business,\" Knapp said.&#160;&#160;</p><div +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5ea86d264bca632daf49ae15?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"59fa8862292dcdf0505221b2b3768595","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn94@2020_1/2020/09/20/17-35-50-368_e323cb7d686ded27.webp","destWidth":1777,"destHeight":1333,"sourceBytes":148188,"destBytes":148188,"author":"ktaylor@businessinsider.com (Kate Taylor)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5ea3062838bf237267439da2?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn80@2020_2/2020/09/20/17-35-46-319_17de78a0fdb5c595.webp","https://i.insider.com/5eb309403dac9a0f566db623?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn28@2020_4/2020/09/20/17-35-38-838_493e30bfd936d2b2.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn62@2020_4/2020/09/20/17-35-46-023_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=8UtHxjqQGHI:01cejw8OIpU:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn91@2020_5/2020/09/20/17-35-49-341_985233a88d7093de.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=8UtHxjqQGHI:01cejw8OIpU:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn25@2020_1/2020/09/20/17-35-39-589_1b2cfd2caa3452c1.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=8UtHxjqQGHI:01cejw8OIpU:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn22@2020_5/2020/09/20/17-35-38-084_953d282c5153760e.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/8UtHxjqQGHI":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn54@2020_6/2020/09/20/17-35-45-151_b4d0cc3bdd400fee.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1600623333136},{"createdTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","updatedTime":"2020-09-21 01:35:33","title":"Democrats fundraised more than $91 million hours after Ruth Bader Ginsburg's death","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/actblue-donations-surged-after-rbgs-death-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f665d86323fc4001e0d74f1?format=jpeg\" alt=\"ruth bader ginsburg vigil\" height=\"1969\" width=\"3939\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Flowers and light candies outside the Supreme Court Friday, Sept. 18, 2020, in Washington, after the Supreme Court announced that Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg died of metastatic pancreatic cancer at age 87.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Alex Brandon/AP</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Democrats raised more than $91 million in approximately one day following the death of Ruth Bader Ginsburg, fundraising platform ActBlue said in a statement late Saturday.&#160;</li>\n<li>More than $70 million of those donations rolled in on Saturday, breaking the service's all-time record for funds raised in a single day, ActBlue said.</li>\n<li>In the 9 p.m. hour on Friday, ActBlue candidates and causes raised some $6.2 million, and in the 10 p.m. hour, it raised $6.3 million, The New York Times first reported.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Donations to the Democratic fundraising platform ActBlue surged immediately following the death of Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, smashing multiple records since the service first launching and bringing in more than $90 million.</p><p>According to ActBlue, some 1.5 million contributions were made to Democratic candidates and causes that totaled $91.4 million from 8 p.m. on Friday until the end of the day on Saturday. More than $70 million of those donations rolled in on Saturday, breaking the service's all-time record for funds raised in a single day, ActBlue said.</p><p>With 1.2 million contributions received on Saturday, ActBlue said it surpassed the record number of contributions received in a single day since it was founded in 2004. It also broke the record for the number of contributions received in a single hour, with 104,466 contributions during the 10 p.m. hour on Friday.</p><p>\"Amid the devastating loss of Justice Ginsburg, it is inspiring to see people taking action to honor her legacy,\" Erin Hill, ActBlue's executive director said in a statement. \"The record-breaking response we've seen from small-dollar donors shows that the left is eager to fulfill her final wish and ready to fight back against Trump and McConnell's vow to push through a Supreme Court nominee.\"</p><p>As <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/live/2020/09/18/us/trump-vs-biden#the-winner-of-the-arizona-senate-race-could-be-seated-in-time-for-a-vote-on-a-supreme-court-pick\">The New York Times</a> first reported, from 9 p.m. until 10 p.m. on Friday, ActBlue pulled in some $6.2 million in donations — the most it has raised in a single hour. Then, from 10 p.m. to 11 p.m., ActBlue surpassed the record again, bringing in $6.3 million in donations. As The Times noted, ActBlue does not clearly specify the allocation of the donated funds.&#160;</p><p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/supreme-court-justice-ruth-bader-ginsburg-has-died-2019-8\">Ginsburg died Friday at the age of 87 due to complications stemming from metastatic pancreatic cancer</a>. She spent the last 27 years of her life on the Supreme Court. <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/supreme-court-justice-ruth-bader-ginsburg-has-died-2019-8\"></a></p><p>Ginsburg's death triggered a political firestorm, as Democrats and Republicans have clashed in recent days over whether President Donald Trump should appoint a successor and if the GOP-controlled Senate should vote on his nomination.</p><p>In 2016, following the death of Justice Antonin Scalia, Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell refused to allow the Senate to debate or vote on President Barack Obama's nominee, Judge Merrick Garland.&#160;</p><p>But on Friday, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/mcconnell-confirms-senate-will-vote-on-ruth-bader-ginsburg-replacement-2020-9\">McConnell said the Senate would vote on a nominee put forth by President Trump</a>. And on Saturday, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-nominate-rbg-replacement-reports-say-2020-9\">the president tweeted that it was his \"obligation\" to name a new justice to the court</a>, and he told reporters he intends to announce his pick next week and that it will <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-supreme-court-pick-announcement-most-likely-woman-2020-9\">\"most likely\" be a woman</a>.</p><p>Democrats, meanwhile, have <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/chuck-schumer-senate-democrats-republicans-supreme-court-ginsburg-vote-mcconnell-2020-9\">urged the Senate to wait until after the November election</a> to vote to confirm a new justice, and <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/lisa-murkowski-wouldnt-vote-to-confirm-scotus-nominee-before-election-2020-9\">at least two Republican senators previously suggested they would not vote to confirm a nominee until after the election</a>. The GOP will need a simple majority to confirm a new justice and the party currently holds a majority with 53 seats.</p><p>NPR previously reported that <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ruth-bader-ginsburg-dies-wish-not-be-replaced-new-president-2020-9\">Ginsburg's \"fervent\" last wish was that she \"not be replaced until a new president is installed.\"</a></p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/actblue-donations-surged-after-rbgs-death-2020-9'>Business Insider</a></div><div Perrett)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f665d86323fc4001e0d74f1?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn70@2020_6/2020/09/20/17-35-45-311_265597d7d5216b9e.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn62@2020_4/2020/09/20/17-35-46-023_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=31cwde0lzd4:DRdCitlJ5wc:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn6@2020_2/2020/09/20/17-35-35-670_5f0bf6601ede7d8a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=31cwde0lzd4:DRdCitlJ5wc:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn68@2020_3/2020/09/20/17-35-46-046_f4c695514d70c608.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=31cwde0lzd4:DRdCitlJ5wc:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn37@2020_5/2020/09/20/17-35-35-698_cd6884889f8ca0d0.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/31cwde0lzd4":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn32@2020_4/2020/09/20/17-35-47-915_3b7ab9f4789dddd5.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1600623333163},{"createdTime":"2020-09-21 lives","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/rv-camper-van-travel-trailer-makers-changing-digital-nomads-2020-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f57e8a8e6ff30001d4e79ba?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Blacksford Winnebago Sprinter RV Rental\" height=\"1668\" width=\"2223\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Blacksford&#39;s van.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.blacksford.com/\" target=\"_blank\">Blacksford</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>The pandemic and the subsequent rise in remote workers has encouraged many Americans to take up the \"digital nomad\" or \"work from anywhere\" lifestyle.</li>\n<li>Many camper van, RV, and travel trailer makers have noticed the rising popularity of this community and are tapping into the potential client base by adding updates on existing builds or creating new floor plans.</li>\n<li>Companies like Bowlus Road Chief and Leisure Travel Vans already have remote work-friendly builds, but will continue adding updates as needed.</li>\n<li>Road travel makers Winnebago and Airstream are taking a different approach by creating completely new designs, some of which will be unveiled soon.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Many RV, camper van, and travel trailer makers have started catering their road travel builds to accommodate the rising popularity of digital nomads and \"work from anywhere\" crowd amid the pandemic.</p><p>A<a href=\"https://s29814.pcdn.co/wp-content/uploads/2019/02/StateofIndependence-ResearchBrief-DigitalNomads.pdf\">&#160;study by MBO Partners</a> found that 4.8 million Americans called themselves \"digital nomads\" in 2018. And now that the pandemic has forced 42% percent of US workers to work from home full-time — <a href=\"https://news.stanford.edu/2020/06/29/snapshot-new-working-home-economy/\">according to data from Stanford economist Nicholas Bloom</a> — this number may continue skyrocketing.</p><p>It's also no industry secret that the pandemic and this subsequent work from home movement has caused a road travel reawakening among Americans. In recent months, many <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/camper-van-conversion-companies-resilience-in-sales-despite-the-coronavirus-2020-5\">camper van</a> and RV makers have <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/rv-sales-skyrocketing-as-lockdown-ends-2020-6\">reported skyrocketing interest messages, inquiries, and sales</a> amid the pandemic's presence in the US.</p><p>This rise in sales amid an unprecedented time, combined with an increasing number of permanent and long-term remote workers, has put a spotlight on the digital nomad community. And despite how recent this development has been, the impact can already be seen by camper van rental platforms such as Europe-based Indie Campers, which reported a 66% increase in requests from digital nomads looking to book camper vans from July to September comparing data from 2019 to 2020.</p><p>As a result, this popular trend is now being observed and tapped into by the industry that enables the \"work from anywhere\" community</p><p>This includes <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/flippie-diy-ikea-based-ram-promaster-van-built-less-than-1000-2019-10\">Ram Promaster</a> van conversion company Dave and Matt Vans, which has about a quarter of its customer base using its vans for digital nomad purposes, according to the company.</p><p>\"Particularly since COVID, it's been really cool to track the clients who use [our] vans to work remotely,\" Matt Felser, co-founder of Dave and Matt Vans, told Business Insider. \"They still have a home base, whatever that may be, but they have identified the van as their chance to be able to go to the mountains for a week at a time … [and] do their job, and have purchased these vehicles to work remotely for weeks at a time.\"</p><h2>Old amenities for a new market</h2><p>Several road travel makers, such as Dave and Matt Vans, have been in the \"work from anywhere\" market since before the pandemic by including amenities like bathrooms, tables, and internet and phone connectivity packages.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f57f0167ed0ee001e25e126?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Bowlus Road Chief&#39;s Endless Highways Performance Edition. 1\" height=\"1162\" width=\"1549\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Bowlus Road Chief&#39;s Endless Highways Performance Edition.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://bowlusroadchief.com/endless-highways-performance-edition/\" target=\"_blank\">Bowlus Road Chief</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>For these makers, it's more about adding updates as they come instead of completely changing any existing floor plans.</p><p>\"The customer we designed for's ultimate vacation does include still being connected in some way,\" luxury trailer maker <a href=\"https://bowlusroadchief.com/blog/travel-guides/behind-the-adventurer-helena-mitchell/\">Bowlus Road Chief's head of sales</a> Helena Mitchell-Long Bowlus told Business Insider.</p><p>According to Mitchell-Long, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/bowlus-road-chief-luxury-225000-rv-trailer-off-grid-weeks-2020-5\">Bowlus Road Chief's Endless Highways trailer</a> already has a floor plan that is suitable for remote digital nomads. Therefore, instead of creating a new product that will only cater to the \"work from the road\" crowd, the company will add updates to its existing trailer. This includes, for example, the potential addition of a stronger WiFi router when it becomes available in the market.</p><p>The \"update-based\" model is also being employed by Leisure Travel Vans, which once specialized in building a wide variety of RVs and travel trailers before pivoting to smaller <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/leisure-travel-vans-2021-unity-rv-mercedes-benz-sprinter-2020-8\">luxury Class C RVs — such as the Unity RV —</a> in order to match the recent rising demands of smaller van-based builds.&#160;</p><p>\"[The updates] are continuing, and it's always going to be continuing,\" Dean Corrigal of Leisure Travel Vans told Business Insider. \"It's a big growing segment.\"</p><p>According to Corrigal, about 30 to 40% of emails that Leisure Travel Vans has been receiving have come from customers who have asked specifically about the vans' mobile office capabilities.</p><p>As of now, the company estimates that 20% of its customers are currently using their Leisure Travel Vans as a mobile office, but Corrigal predicts this number will continue increasing in the future.</p><p>\"It's a huge amount of first-time buyers sending request emails to us ... people that want to work from their RVs are right behind that,\" Corrigal said. \"I think it's a huge growing segment, and the longer this COVID-19 thing lasts, the more the RV industry is going to go forward and push in sales.\"</p><h2>New amenities for old players</h2><p>Moving forward, several other makers who haven't traditionally catered their products to the digital nomad segment will now start planning updates and floor plans in-part around the community.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f57f08c7ed0ee001e25e128?format=jpeg\" alt=\"The GlamperRV Business Line.\" height=\"1666\" width=\"2222\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The GlamperRV Business Line.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.glamperrv.co.uk/glamperrvs/glamperrv-business-line/\" target=\"_blank\">GlamperRV</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Some road travel makers have altered the design of their tiny homes on wheels to be remote work-friendly. This includes <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/glamperrv-rv-with-luxury-office-workspace-2020-7\">GlamperRV's $93,450 Business Line RV</a>, which was created amid the pandemic to meet the demands for \"flexible home offices,\" according to the UK-based RV maker.</p><p>\"As we learned more about the Class B van business, we started to see those demands for connectivity,\" vice president at Winnebago Brian Hazelton told Business Insider. \"That customer group was really pushing us to do … a lot of those things before the COVID pandemic started.</p><p>\"But obviously with COVID, we're ramping up the pace and really trying to look at the product and say, 'Okay, how can we not take the traditional RV and make it into an office, but maybe start designing the office and make it into a traditional RV',\" Hazelton continued.</p><p>For Winnebago, this means designing an office-capable RV — or updating prior builds — with options like improved soundproofing, quieter power systems, and ergonomic seating.</p><p>The motorhome maker has yet to implement all of these changes amid the pandemic, especially because Winnebago wants to create a space that is customizable by offering different floor plans, according to Hazelton. It has, however, recently included remote work-friendly ticket items — such as larger countertops and a quieter generator — into several of its currently existing builds, and will be revealing new products in the fall.</p><h2>RVs now need to be designed to work in</h2><p>\"Work from home is now one of the big boxes that product development has to check when they're considering a new product,\" Hazelton said.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f57f0ce7ed0ee001e25e12b?format=jpeg\" alt=\"AIRMKT 2021 Flying Cloud 23FB Exterior Bug Eye_80832 WEB\" height=\"1690\" width=\"2253\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The 2021 Flying Cloud.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.airstream.com/blog/refreshing-the-flying-cloud-decor-for-2021/\" target=\"_blank\">Airstream</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Airstream is also taking a similar approach to Winnebago by updating existing floor plans to be more inclusive of the remote workers segment, president and CEO of Airstream Bob Wheeler told Business Insider.</p><p>According to Wheeler, the road travel company was originally planning to cater to its existing \"work from anywhere\" client base, but the pandemic expedited these plans.</p><p>\"We tried to look at some of our floor plans and say, 'where could we carve out a dedicated work area so you don't have to clean up your workday in order to have a meal [at the dinette table]?'\" Wheeler said.</p><p>The new layouts will feature a compact desk with \"stowaway seating\", USB and 110-volt outlets, and desk storage. But in order to create space for the desk, the company will have to make adjustments to pre-existing amenities, such as decreasing the size of dinettes or removing a secondary bed.</p><p>According to Wheeler, the Airstream is hoping to have these new floor plans available by this month. As of now, it will <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/airstreams-new-2021-flying-cloud-and-international-interiors-2020-6\">only be in the Flying Cloud travel trailer</a>, specifically in the 30-foot option, 27-foot front bedroom, 25-foot front bedroom, and 23-foot corner bed floor plans.&#160;</p><p>\"It's not overkill,\" Wheeler said. \"You don't need a five-foot-wide slab [desk] in your travel trailer, but we find that when we talk to people about the option to have this area where they can set up and leave their work set up and still live in the rest of the trailer, that's really appealing.\"</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/rv-camper-van-travel-trailer-makers-changing-digital-nomads-2020-9'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=5zEITx8EN9s:G7tWeN81bzY:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img
